开始理论
Beginning theory

起点

系列编辑： Peter Barry 和 Helen Carr

Beginnings

Series editors: Peter Barry and Helen Carr

“起点”是一系列书籍，旨在为开始应对英语、文学研究和文化研究的最新发展的学生提供实际帮助。该系列的书籍

‘Beginnings’ is a series of books designed to give practical help to students beginning to tackle recent developments in English, Literary Studies and Cultural Studies. The books in the series

展示并鼓励对新事物的质疑；
demonstrate and encourage a questioning engagement with the new;
提供有关每个主题的背景和历史的基本信息；
give essential information about the context and history of each topic covered;
展示如何发展一种最新的并受理论启发的实践。
show how to develop a practice which is up-to-date and informed by theory.

每本书都毫不妥协地关注其读者的需求，他们有权期望清晰和清晰是一本书的显着特征，其中包括标题中的“开始”一词。

Each book focuses uncompromisingly upon the needs of its readers, who have the right to expect lucidity and clarity to be the distinctive feature of a book which includes the word ‘beginning’ in its title.

每个目标都旨在为深入理解的初始原则奠定坚实的基础，作为进一步学习的基础，并致力于在不过分简化的情况下，以适合初学者需求的方式解释该学科的新方面。

Each aims to lay a firm foundation of well understood initial principles as a basis for further study and is committed to explaining new aspects of the discipline without over-simplification, but in a manner appropriate to the needs of beginners.

最后，每本书的目标都是对其所讨论的主题领域进行介绍和贡献。

Each book, finally, aims to be both an introduction and a contribution to the topic area it discusses.

也在系列中
Also in the series

开始电影研究

安德鲁·迪克斯

开始理论

Beginning theory

文学与文化理论导论

An introduction to literary and cultural theory

彼得·巴里

致谢

Acknowledgements

你最好不要往下看，

You’d better not look down,

如果你想一直飞

If you want to keep flying

伟大的 BB King 如此说道。这是极好的建议，并且努力坚持它帮助我完成了这本书。曼彻斯特大学出版社人文学科编辑安妮塔·罗伊 (Anita Roy) 的建议和专业知识也给我很大帮助。Annie Eagleton 是一位细致且乐于助人的文字编辑，Alison Abel 在校对阶段提供了宝贵的帮助。

So says the great B. B. King. It is excellent advice, and trying to stick to it helped me to complete this book. I was also greatly helped by the advice and expertise of Anita Roy, Humanities Editor at Manchester University Press. Annie Eagleton was a meticulous and helpful copy-editor, and Alison Abel provided valuable help at the proof-reading stage.

许多章节都是基于我在路易斯安那州立大学的“文学概论”和“批评概念”课程中使用的材料。前者由多位同事组成的“团队事工”教授，过去几年我非常感谢他们的评论和建议。我尤其要感谢 Gillian Skinner 阅读了手稿的某些部分并提出了一些非常有用的建议，所有这些我都采纳了。Nicola King 提供了“女权主义评论家做什么”清单，我在所有章节中都采用了这个想法。当然，书中遗留的所有错误完全由我自己负责。

Many of the chapters are based on material I used on the ‘Introduction to Literature’ and ‘Concepts of Criticism’ courses at LSU. The former is taught by a ‘team-ministry’ of various colleagues, whose comments and advice I have been most grateful for over the past few years. In particular, I must thank Gillian Skinner for reading sections of the manuscript and making a number of extremely useful suggestions, all of which I have acted upon. Nicola King supplied the ‘What feminist critics do’ checklist, and I have adopted this idea for all the chapters. Of course, all the faults which remain in the book are entirely my own responsibility.

当我的技术专长证明无法胜任从我（我认为）巧妙改编的磁盘制作硬拷贝的任务时，史蒂夫·多尼救了我。玛丽安和汤姆让我经常从 Sainsbury's 和“Playdays”休假，从而使我能够写这本书。这本书是给我母亲的，也是为了纪念我的父亲弗朗西斯·巴里。

Steve Dorney rescued me when my technical expertise proved unequal to the task of producing hard copy from my (as I thought) cunningly adapted disks. Marianne and Tom enabled me to write the book by giving me frequent periods of study leave from Sainsbury’s and ‘Playdays’. The book is for my mother and in memory of my father, Francis Barry.

我非常希望收到本书用户的来信（通过曼彻斯特大学出版社，或直接致英语系，UCW, Aberystwyth, Ceredigion SY23 3DY, Wales, UK (ptb@aber.ac 。英国））。如果本书中的任何内容看起来不清楚、不必要、歪曲、错误遗漏，或未能承认来源，我将努力在任何后续版本中改进或纠正问题。

I will be most interested to hear from any users of this book who might wish to write to me (either via Manchester University Press, or directly to English Department, UCW, Aberystwyth, Ceredigion SY23 3DY, Wales, UK (ptb@aber.ac.uk)). If anything in the book seems unclear, or unnecessary, or misrepresented, or wrongly omitted, or fails to acknowledge a source, I will endeavour to improve or rectify matters in any subsequent edition.

第3 章的部分以前曾出现在The Use of English和The English Review中（形式略有不同） 。

Sections of Chapter 3 have previously appeared (in a slightly different form) in The Use of English and The English Review.

路易斯安那州立大学彼得巴里

Peter Barry

LSU

第二版前言

Preface to the second edition

自本书第一版（写于 1990 年代初期）以来，文学理论一直在不断变化和发展。为了反映这些发展，我增加了一个关于生态批评的新章节，使之成为同类书籍中第一本记录了人们对“绿色”文学方法日益增长的兴趣的书籍。
Since the first edition of this book (which was written in the earlier part of the 1990s) literary theory has continued to change and develop. To reflect these developments, I have added a new chapter on ecocriticism, making this the first book of its kind to register the increasing interest in ‘Green’ approaches to literature.

当然，我自己对各种理论的感受也发生了一些变化。特别是，我现在发现结构主义比后结构主义更有趣，为了反映这一点，我增加了一个关于叙事学的新章节，这是结构主义理论的一个分支，很容易产生令人愉快和发人深省的实际应用。除了这些新章节之外，第二版与第一版是同一本书，但更新了参考书目。

Of course, my own feelings about the various kinds of theory have changed a bit too. In particular, I now find structuralism rather more interesting than post-structuralism, and to reflect this I have added a new chapter on narratology, a branch of structuralist theory which lends itself very readily to enjoyable and thought-provoking practical applications. Apart from these new chapters, the second edition is the same book as the first, but with up-dated bibliographies.

我和我在 Aberystwyth 的同事一起教授一系列理论课程，特别是“RTRT”模块（“阅读理论/阅读文本”），我帮助将其最初的 27 个小主题减少到四个更大的主题。这或多或少是结构主义者列维-斯特劳斯和托多罗夫想要对弗拉基米尔·普罗普提出的 31 种叙事功能所做的（见第 12 章），这表明我们在 Aber 是多么热衷于将文学理论的教训应用到我们的作品中。日常教学生活。我非常感谢我的同事和学生，感谢我们就“RTRT”进行的所有讨论，并感谢过去几年选择“短篇小说”选项的学生，他们与他们一起尝试了各种叙事理论方法。

With my colleagues at Aberystwyth I teach on a range of theory courses, notably the ‘RTRT’ modules (‘Reading Theory/Reading Text’), whose original twenty-seven mini-topics I helped reduce to four somewhat larger ones. This is more or less what the structuralists Lévi-Strauss and Todorov wanted to do to the thirty-one narrative functions posited by Vladimir Propp (see Chapter 12), which shows how keen we are at Aber to apply the lessons of literary theory to our everyday teaching lives. I am very grateful to my colleagues and students for all the discussions we have had about ‘RTRT’, and to students on the ‘Short Story’ option over the past few years with whom the various theoretical approaches to narrative have been tried out.

第 217 页的卡通叙述由英国玛氏 2001 分部 Pedigree Masterfoods 营销部 Gray Dudek 提供。 Beginnings 系列），以及几乎所有其他内容，致 Marianne 和 Tom（他们从第一版“Playdays”毕业到“Gameboy Advance”）。

The cartoon narrative on page 217 is supplied courtesy of Gray Dudek, Marketing Division of Pedigree Masterfoods, a division of Mars UK 2001. I am very grateful to Matthew Frost at MUP for his tireless promotion of this book (which is now part of the ‘Beginnings’ series), and, for nearly everything else, to Marianne and Tom (who has graduated since the first edition from ‘Playdays’ to ‘Gameboy Advance’).

阿伯里斯特威斯英语系
English Department, Aberystwyth

第三版前言

Preface to the third edition

与第二版一样，第三版Beginning Theory是扩展版，而不是严格意义上的修订版，尽管对整本书进行了更正，并更新了阅读清单。本书的第一版是在 1990 年代建立在 80 年代“理论战争”期间打下的基础之上的。无情地剥离其所有时代特征可能会从根本上改变建筑物的特征，从而降低其可能具有的任何价值。所以我选择听从电视财产节目的建议，并建立了几个扩展章节。
The third edition of Beginning Theory is, like the second, an expanded edition rather than a revised edition in the strictest sense, though corrections have been made throughout and reading lists updated. The first edition of this book was built in the 1990s on foundations laid down during the ‘theory wars’ of the 1980s. A ruthless stripping out of all its period features would risk altering the character of the building too fundamentally, and thereby reducing whatever value it might have. So I have opted instead to follow the advice of the property programmes on television and have built a couple of extension chapters.

新的第一章以新的方式讲述了理论的“故事”，利用了时间流逝允许的更广阔的视角。第二部分介绍了自 2000 年左右以来出现在现场的一些新“主义”。总的来说，我涵盖的那些构成了新历史主义和文化唯物主义以及文体学和叙事学的更新，我选择它们的部分原因是它们因此延续了我在第一版中开始讲述的理论故事。由于这是一本关于入门理论的书，我没有试图涵盖伦理理论、空间理论和身体理论等领域的最新发展。

The first new chapter tells the ‘story’ of theory in a new way, taking advantage of the wider perspective which the passage of time allows. The second takes an introductory look at some of the new ‘isms’ which have appeared on the scene since the year 2000 or so. Collectively, those I cover constitute updatings of new historicism and cultural materialism and of stylistics and narratology, and I chose them partly because they thereby continue the theory story which I started telling in the first edition. As this is a book about beginning theory, I have not attempted to cover recent developments in such fields as ethical theory, space theory, and body theory.

感谢我的同事 Sarah Prescott 对新材料的讨论，感谢 Aber 的理论团队对“阅读理论/阅读文本”（众所周知的 EN30930）的持续刺激。一如既往地感谢玛丽安和汤姆（他现在正处于与“A”级别的李尔王较量的阶段，尽管到目前为止他还没有觉得有任何需要寻求他父亲的书的帮助）。

I am grateful to my colleague Sarah Prescott for discussions about the new material, and to the theory team at Aber for the continuing stimulus of ‘Reading Theory/Reading Text’, or EN30930, as it is fondly known. Thanks, as always, to Marianne, and to Tom (who is now at the stage of wrestling with King Lear at ‘A’ Level, though he has not so far felt any need to enlist the aid of his dad’s book).

彼得·巴里，阿伯里斯特威斯
Peter Barry, Aberystwyth

介绍

Introduction

关于本书

About this book

80 年代可能见证了文学理论的高潮。那十年是理论的“时刻”，当时这个话题很流行也很有争议。在 1990 年代，出现了源源不断的书籍和文章，其标题如“理论之后”（Thomas Docherty，1990 年）或“后理论”（Nicolas Tredell，在“关键十年”中， 1993 年）。正如这些标题所暗示的，“理论时刻”可能已经过去。那么，为什么今天这么晚才推出另一本理论“入门书”呢？

The 1980s probably saw the high-water mark of literary theory. That decade was the ‘moment’ of theory, when the topic was fashionable and controversial. In the 1990s there was a steady flow of books and articles with titles like After Theory (Thomas Docherty, 1990) or ‘Post-Theory’ (Nicolas Tredell, in The Critical Decade, 1993). As such titles suggest, the ‘moment of theory’ has probably passed. So why another ‘primer’ of theory so late in the day?

简单的答案是，在理论的时刻之后，不可避免地会出现理论的“时刻”，当它不再是专注于少数人的排他性关注，而是作为课程中理所当然的一部分进入知识分子的血液中. 在这个阶段，魅力消退，魅力被“常规化”，学习或教授（或两者）这种材料成为相当多的人的日常工作。把事情简单化显然是危险的，因此给第一次遇到这个话题困难的学生提供虚假的保证。尽管如此，任何尝试编写这样一本书的人的主要责任是满足清晰解释和论证的需求。如果任务不可能完成，理论之山只能由专家攀登，

The simple answer is that after the moment of theory there comes, inevitably, the ‘hour’ of theory, when it ceases to be the exclusive concern of a dedicated minority and enters the intellectual bloodstream as a taken-for-granted aspect of the curriculum. At this stage the glamour fades, the charisma is ‘routinised’, and it becomes the day-to-day business of quite a large number of people to learn or teach (or both) this material. There are evident dangers of over-simplifying things and so offering a false reassurance to students facing the difficulties of this topic for the first time. All the same, the main responsibility of anyone attempting a book like this one is to meet the demand for clear explanation and demonstration. If the task were impossible, and the mountain of theory could be climbed only by experts, then the whole enterprise of establishing it on undergraduate courses would have been a mistake.

强调实践意味着这是一本“练习册”，而不仅仅是一本“教科书”。当你阅读时，你会发现标题为“停下来思考”的建议活动，旨在给你一些文学理论及其问题的“实践”经验。你不会只是阅读它，将理论简化为一种只有超级巨星才能参加的观赏性运动，而是开始为自己做这件事。以这种方式成为参与者将帮助您获得一些个人的理论意义，并且我希望会增加您的信心，即使您怀疑您的实际努力仍然相当初级。如果本书与批判理论的教学课程结合使用，还希望“停下来思考”活动能够为发起研讨会讨论提供基础。

The emphasis on practice means that this is a ‘work-book’, not just a ‘text-book’. As you read you will find suggested activities, headed ‘STOP and THINK’, which are designed to give you some ‘hands-on’ experience of literary theory and its problems. You will not just be reading about it, reducing theory to a kind of spectator sport played only by superstars, but starting to do it for yourself. Becoming a participant in this way will help you to make some personal sense of theory, and will, I hope, increase your confidence, even if you suspect that your practical efforts remain fairly rudimentary. It is also hoped that the ‘STOP and THINK’ activities will provide the basis for initiating seminar discussion if this book is being used in connection with a taught course on critical theory.

本书中描述的所有批判方法都是对之前发生的事情的反应，并且不能假设对这些事情有先验知识。因此，我从对“自由人文主义”的描述开始，从广义上讲，所有这些较新的批判方法都针对它来定义自己。同样，当前成功的马克思主义、女权主义、精神分析和语言批评的版本都将自己定义为反对这些批评的早期版本，因此我在每种情况下都试图首先解释早期版本。我认为目前学生在理论方面遇到的许多困难都是因为试图错过这个阶段。我的方法相当于让你陷入浅水区。

All the critical approaches described in this book are a reaction against something which went before, and a prior knowledge of these things cannot be assumed. Hence, I start with an account of the ‘liberal humanism’ against which all these newer critical approaches, broadly speaking, define themselves. Likewise, the currently successful versions of Marxist, feminist, psychoanalytic, and linguistic criticism all define themselves against earlier versions of each of these, and therefore I try in each case to explain the earlier versions first. I think that many of the current difficulties students have with theory arise from trying to miss out this stage. My approach amounts to throwing you in at the shallow end. Potentially this is more painful than being thrown in at the deep end – the technique used in most other student introductions to literary theory – but it does reduce the risk of drowning.

也许应该强调的是，现在可用的其他一般性理论介绍与这本不同。它们对整个领域提供了均匀而全面的覆盖，但对应用程序的实际讨论方式相对较少。我发现它们非常有用，但在我看来，它们似乎是对文学理论的概括，通常是从哲学而非文学的角度出发，而不是对它的介绍。覆盖面的均匀性意味着节奏永远不会变化，因此没有机会停下来以反思的方式详述一个例子。相比之下，我并没有尝试做到面面俱到，我确实尝试通过选择问题、示例或关键论文来提供节奏上的变化，以便进行更深入的处理。一般来说，行动中的文学研究和林恩的文本和背景（参见进一步阅读部分）。这两本书都是有趣但古怪的书，其相当零散的格式阻止了任何真正的讨论或解释。

It should, perhaps, be stressed that the other general introductions to theory that are now available are different from this one. They offer an even and comprehensive coverage of the entire field, but with relatively little in the way of practical discussion of applications. I find them very useful, but they seem to me to be recapitulations of literary theory, often from a viewpoint more philosophical than literary, rather than introductions to it. The evenness of the coverage means that the pace never varies, so that there is no opportunity to stop and dwell upon an example in a reflective way. By contrast, I haven’t tried to be comprehensive, and I do try to provide variation in pace by selecting questions, or examples, or key essays for closer treatment. Generally, the available introductions don’t grapple with the problems of teaching or learning theory: until recently, the only two that tried to do so were Durant and Fabb’s Literary Studies in Action and Lynn’s Texts and Contexts (see Further reading section). Both these are interesting but eccentric books whose rather fragmented format prevents any real flow of discussion or explanation.

在本科阶段，主要问题是确定初学者可以合理处理多少理论。时间不是无限的，需要考虑现实的教学大纲而不是理想的教学大纲。理论家和小说家一样多得令人望而生畏，除非我们将理论学科纳入以学生为中心的教学大纲，否则理论学科不可能在课堂和研讨会上取得成功。正如评论家 FR Leavis 所提倡的那样，如今我们对教授主要小说家的“伟大传统”的想法不屑一顾。但利维斯的伟大传统本质上是一个教学大纲，可以在为期一年的小说本科课程中掌握。在那段时间内阅读并充分讨论奥斯汀、艾略特、詹姆斯、康拉德和劳伦斯的一两部小说是可能的。

At undergraduate level the main problem is to decide how much theory can reasonably be handled by beginners. Time is not unlimited, and there is a need to think about a realistic syllabus rather than an ideal one. Theorists, like novelists, are dauntingly plentiful, and the subject of theory cannot succeed in lecture rooms and seminars unless we fashion it into a student-centred syllabus. We are rightly dismissive these days of the notion of teaching a ‘Great Tradition’ of key novelists, as advocated by the critic F. R. Leavis. But Leavis’s Great Tradition was essentially a syllabus, manageable within a yearlong undergraduate course on the novel. It is possible to read and adequately discuss a novel or two by Austen, Eliot, James, Conrad, and Lawrence within that time. We need to make sure that what is presented as theory today likewise makes teaching sense.

当我们即将进入新事物时，明智的做法是首先评估我们已经拥有的东西，如果只是为了以后可以测量行进的距离。因此，在本书的第一章中，我邀请您以批判和反思的方式回顾您之前的文学研究训练。然后，我们继续研究传统文学批评背后的假设，或理论家通常称之为“自由人文主义”的假设。

When we are about to move into something new it is sensible to first take stock of what we already have, if only so that the distance travelled can later be measured. So in the first chapter of this book I invite you to look back critically and reflectively on your previous training in literary studies. We then go on to look at the assumptions behind traditional literary criticism, or ‘liberal humanism’ as theorists usually call it.

“自由人文主义”一词在 20 世纪 70 年代流行起来，作为一种速记（主要是敌对的）方式来指代在理论之前占据主导地位的那种批评。这个表述中的“自由”一词大致意味着政治上不激进，因此在政治问题上通常回避和不承诺。“人道主义”暗示着类似的东西；它暗示了一系列负面属性，例如“非马克思主义”和“非女权主义者”以及“非理论”。这也意味着自由人文主义者相信“人性”是伟大文学所表达的固定不变的东西。自由人文主义者并没有（通常也不）使用这个名字来称呼自己，但是，一个有影响力的思想流派说，如果你从事文学批评并且不称自己为马克思主义批评家、结构主义者或文体主义者，或一些这样的，

The term ‘liberal humanism’ became current in the 1970s, as a shorthand (and mainly hostile) way of referring to the kind of criticism which held sway before theory. The word ‘liberal’ in this formulation roughly means not politically radical, and hence generally evasive and non-committal on political issues. ‘Humanism’ implies something similar; it suggests a range of negative attributes, such as ‘non-Marxist’ and ‘non-feminist’, and ‘non-theoretical’. There is also the implication that liberal humanists believe in ‘human nature’ as something fixed and constant which great literature expresses. Liberal humanists did not (and do not, as a rule) use this name of themselves, but, says an influential school of thought, if you practise literary criticism and do not call yourself a Marxist critic, or a structuralist, or a stylistician, or some such, then you are probably a liberal humanist, whether or not you admit or recognise this.

在解释当今流行的一些主要批判思想的过程中，本书提供了一些摘要或描述的重要理论论文。但我想在一开始就强调，亲身阅读一些主要理论家的作品也很重要。然而，一旦你开始翻阅巴特、拉康、福柯或德里达的书页，你就会遇到看起来极其困难和令人生厌的写作。那么，如何应对呢？

In the course of explaining some of the major critical ideas now current, this book provides summaries or descriptions of a number of important theoretical essays. But I want to stress at the outset that it is important, too, that you read some of the major theorists at first hand. Yet as soon as you begin to turn the pages of Barthes, Lacan, Foucault, or Derrida you will encounter writing which looks dauntingly difficult and off-putting. How, then, to cope?

我建议精读理论书比广泛阅读要好得多。我的意思是，一章又一章地阅读一本对你毫无意义的书，你将收获甚微。如果您使用相同的阅读时间将一个重要且经常被提及的章节或文章自己多读几遍，您将收获更多。详细了解一个著名论点的实际内容，了解论点如何展开以及它是如何限定或上下文化的，对你来说比从评论或文章中获得肤浅的整体印象要有用得多。来自绝望的略读。无论材料多么令人生畏，你都必须让你的阅读变得冥想、反思和个人化。尝试成为一个慢读者。此外，这种类型的一些精读将使您能够引用所有评论中引用的少数几行以外的行。最重要的是，你对事物的看法将是你自己的，也许是古怪和不完整的，但至少不仅仅是某些已发表的评论员预打包版本的回声和残余。简而言之，精读往往比泛读更有用。“英语研究”建立在文本细读的概念之上，虽然在 20 世纪 70 年代末和 80 年代初期这个想法经常遭到贬低，但毫无疑问，如果没有文本细读，这个学科就不会发生任何有趣的事情.

I suggest that it is much better to read intensely in theory than to read widely. By this I mean that you will gain little from reading chapter after chapter of a book that is making little sense to you. You will gain much more by using the same amount of reading time to read one crucial and frequently mentioned chapter or article several times for yourself. Having a detailed knowledge of what is actually said in the pages of a well-known argument, being aware of how the argument unfolds and how it is qualified or contextualised, will be far more useful to you than a superficial overall impression gained from commentaries or from desperate skim-reading. However daunting the material, you have to make your reading meditative, reflective, and personal. Try to become a slow reader. Further, some intensive reading of this kind will enable you to quote lines other than the handful that are cited in all the commentaries. And most importantly, your view of things will be your own, perhaps quirky and incomplete, but at least not just the echo and residue of some published commentator’s prepacked version. In a nut-shell, intensive reading is often more useful than extensive reading. ‘English studies’ is founded on the notion of close reading, and while there was a period in the late 1970s and early 1980s when this idea was frequently disparaged, it is undoubtedly true that nothing of any interest can happen in this subject without close reading.

因此，我建议您自己尝试一种有用的精读形式，即所谓的“SQ3R”技术。这将困难的章节或文章的阅读分为五个阶段，如通常给出的字母“SQRRR”或“SQ3R”所示。这五个阶段是：

I suggest, therefore, that you try out for yourself a useful form of intensive reading, the technique known as ‘SQ3R’. This breaks down the reading of a difficult chapter or article into five stages, as designated by the letters ‘SQRRR’, or ‘SQ3R’, as is it usually given. The five stages are:

S – 也就是说，相当快速地浏览整个章节或部分，浏览它以粗略地了解论点的范围和性质。请记住，信息在整篇文章中的分布并不均匀。它往往集中在开头和结尾的段落（您通常会在此处获得有用的整体摘要），以及文章的“铰链点”论点通常出现在段落的开头和结尾句中。
S – That is, Survey the whole chapter or section fairly rapidly, skimming through it to get a rough sense of the scope and nature of the argument. Remember that information is not evenly spread throughout a text. It tends to be concentrated in the opening and closing paragraphs (where you often get useful summaries of the whole), and the ‘hinge points’ of the argument are often indicated in the opening and closing sentences of paragraphs.
Q – 浏览了全部内容后，给自己设置一些问题，一些您希望从阅读的内容中找到的东西。这使你成为一个“主动”的读者而不是被动的读者，并给你的阅读一个目的。
Q – Having skimmed the whole, set yourself some Questions, some things you hope to find out from what you are reading. This makes you an ‘active’ reader rather than a passive one, and gives your reading a purpose.

R1 – 现在阅读整篇文章。如果副本是你自己的，请用铅笔在关键点、查询难点、值得记住的短语等下划线。不要只是坐在书页前。如果这本书不是你自己的，那么在你阅读时在纸上记下一些东西，无论多么小。

R1 – Now Read the whole piece. Use a pencil if the copy is your own to underline key points, query difficulties, circle phrases worth remembering, and so on. Don’t just sit in front of the pages. If the book is not your own jot something down on paper as you read, however minimal.

R2 – 现在，合上书并回忆你读过的内容。记下一些总结要点。询问您的起始问题是否已得到回答，或者至少得到澄清。说出一些仍然存在的困难。通过这种方式，您可以记录一些具体的阅读结果，这样您的时间就不会在合上书后就白白浪费了。

R2 – Now, close the book and Recall what you have read. Jot down some summary points. Ask whether your starting questions have been answered, or at least clarified. Spell out some of the difficulties that remain. In this way, you record some concrete outcomes to your reading, so that your time doesn’t simply evaporate uselessly once the book is closed.

R3 – 最后阶段是审查。它发生在自阅读以来经过一段时间后。您可以尝试，但首先尝试在第二天进行。无需再次翻开这本书，也无需回顾你的笔记，回顾你从阅读中获得的收获；提醒自己你自己提出的问题，你在回忆阶段记下的要点，以及文章中的任何重要短语。如果这产生的很少，请返回查看您的笔记。如果他们没有什么意义，那么重复调查阶段，并通过阅读文章的第一段和最后一段，并在铅笔标记的帮助下略读主体部分来进行加速阅读。

R3 – This final stage is the Review. It happens after an interval has elapsed since the reading. You can experiment, but initially try doing it the following day. Without opening the book again, or referring back to your notes, review what you have gained from the reading; remind yourself of the question you set yourself, the points you jotted down at the Recall stage, and any important phrases from the essay. If this produces very little, then refer back to your notes. If they make little sense, then repeat the Survey stage, and do an accelerated Read, by reading the first and last paragraphs of the essay, and skim-reading the main body assisted by your pencilled markings.

您可能已经发展出类似这样的学习技巧。这真的只是常识。但这将有助于确保您从理论文本中有所收获，无论它最初可能多么令人生畏。
You may well have evolved a study technique something like this already. It is really just common sense. But it will help to ensure that you gain something from a theoretical text, no matter how intially forbidding it might be.

最后，我希望，不言而喻，这样的格式不可能具有全面性。很明显，这本书并没有包含你需要了解的所有理论知识，它本身（没有它所指的阅读材料）也不构成文学理论的“课程”。它遗漏了很多东西，而且交易相当活跃有很多话题。这是一个入门包，旨在让您了解理论的全部内容，并建议它如何影响您的文学研究。最重要的是，它旨在让您在理论上感兴趣。

Finally, it will, I hope, go without saying that no comprehensiveness is possible in a format such as this. Clearly, also, this book does not contain all you need to know about theory, and it does not in itself (without the reading it refers you to) constitute a ‘course’ in literary theory. It leaves out a good deal, and it deals fairly briskly with many topics. It is a starter-pack, intended to give you a sense of what theory is all about, and suggest how it might affect your literary studies. Above all, it aims to interest you in theory.

接近理论

Approaching theory

如果你在学习了媒体研究、传播研究或社会语言学等课程后不久就开始学习文学理论，那么新的文学理论方法的一般“感觉”可能看起来很熟悉。你已经“调准”到他们的特点之一是强调思想；您不会因他们使用技术术语而气馁，也不会因他们强烈的社会和政治利益而感到惊讶。另一方面，如果你选修了“直接”的“A”级文学或“通达”课程，主要强调教材，那么本书中包含的大部分内容对你来说可能是全新的。最初，您会遇到了解这些不同的阅读文学方式的波长的问题。正如您在学位学习中所期望的那样，

If you are coming to literary theory soon after taking courses in such subjects as media studies, communications studies, or socio-linguistics, then the general ‘feel’ of the new theoretical approaches to literature may well seem familiar. You will already be ‘tuned in’ to the emphasis on ideas which is one of their characteristics; you will be undaunted by their use of technical terminology, and unsurprised by their strong social and political interests. If, on the other hand, you took a ‘straight’ ‘A’ Level literature or ‘Access’ course with the major emphasis on set books, then much of what is contained in this book will probably be new to you. Initially, you will have the problem of getting on the wave-length of these different ways of looking at literature. As you would expect in studying at degree level, you will encounter problems which do not have generally agreed solutions, and it is inevitable that your understanding of the matters discussed here will remain partial, in both senses of that word, as everybody’s does.

但无论您属于这两类中的哪一类，我想在一开始就向您保证，您对本材料的疑虑和不确定性可能不是由于：

But whichever of these two categories you fall into, I want to assure you at the outset that the doubts and uncertainties you will have about this material are probably not due to:

1. 你自己的任何假定的智力无能，例如，你没有“哲学头脑”，或者没有那种可以穿透行话并看到其含义的 X 射线智力，或者

1. any supposed mental incapacity of your own, for example, to your not having ‘a philosophical mind’, or not possessing the kind of X-ray intellect which can penetrate jargon and see the sense beneath, or

2. 你的学校教育没有包括语言学或哲学等方面的强化学习，或者

2. the fact that your schooling did not include intensive tuition in, say, linguistics or philosophy, or

3. 材料本身固有的和不可降低的难度（我们将回过头来）。

3. the innate and irreducible difficulty of the material itself (a point we will come back to).

相反，几乎所有你遇到的困难都是理论写作方式和写作方式的直接结果。对于文学理论，必须强调的是，并非天生难。文学中很少有内在复杂的想法理论。相反，统称为“理论”的全部著作都是基于十几个想法，这些想法本身并不困难。（其中一些列于第 33-5 页。）然而，困难的是理论语言。许多主要的理论作家都是法国人，所以我们读到的大部分内容都是翻译的，有时是相当笨拙的翻译。作为一种罗曼语，法语的大部分词汇直接来自拉丁语，它缺乏令人安心的盎格鲁-撒克逊词汇层，而后者为我们提供了许多简短、熟悉的日常术语。因此，法语学术文本的接近英文翻译将包含大量较长的拉丁语单词，这总是被英语读者认为是困难的来源。这些特征比例高的写作可能会令人反感和厌倦，并且很容易失去耐心。

Rather, nearly all the difficulties you will have will be the direct result of the way theory is written, and the way it is written about. For literary theory, it must be emphasised, is not innately difficult. There are very few inherently complex ideas in existence in literary theory. On the contrary, the whole body of work known collectively as ‘theory’ is based upon some dozen or so ideas, none of which are in themselves difficult. (Some of them are listed on pp. 33–5.) What is difficult, however, is the language of theory. Many of the major writers on theory are French, so that much of what we read is in translation, sometimes of a rather clumsy kind. Being a Romance language, French takes most of its words directly from Latin, and it lacks the reassuring Anglo-Saxon layer of vocabulary which provides us with so many of our brief, familiar, everyday terms. Hence, a close English translation of a French academic text will contain a large number of longer Latinate words, always perceived as a source of difficulty by English-speaking readers. Writing with a high proportion of these characteristics can be off-putting and wearying, and it is easy to lose patience.

但我一开始建议的心态是三方面的。首先，我们必须对写作的困难表面有一些初步的耐心。我们必须避免过于现成的结论，即文学理论只是毫无意义的、自命不凡的行话（也就是说，理论有问题）。其次，另一方面，出于显而易见的原因，我们必须抵制我们自己在智力上无法应对它的观点（也就是说，我们有错）。第三，也是至关重要的，我们不能假设理论写作的困难总是深刻思想的外衣——只是它可能有时是，这给我们留下了歧视的责任。总结一下这种态度：在文学理论中，我们正在寻找我们可以使用的东西，而不是会使用我们的东西。我们不应该开具空白支票的理论来为我们花费时间。（如果我们这样做，它肯定会超出我们的承受能力。）那么，不要对理论无休止地耐心等待。要求它清晰明了，并期望它从长远来看能够提供一些可靠的东西。不要像许多人看起来那样满足于仅仅将其视为“具有挑战性”的传统做法或以某种从未完全明确的方式“质疑”它。挑战很好，但它们最终必须有所作为。

But the frame of mind I would recommend at the outset is threefold. Firstly, we must have some initial patience with the difficult surface of the writing. We must avoid the too-ready conclusion that literary theory is just meaningless, pretentious jargon (that is, that the theory is at fault). Secondly, on the other hand, we must, for obvious reasons, resist the view that we ourselves are intellectually incapable of coping with it (that is, that we are at fault). Thirdly, and crucially, we must not assume that the difficulty of theoretical writing is always the dress of profound ideas – only that it might sometimes be, which leaves the onus of discrimination on us. To sum up this attitude: we are looking, in literary theory, for something we can use, not something which will use us. We ought not to issue theory with a blank cheque to spend our time for us. (If we do, it will certainly spend more than we can afford.) Do not, then, be endlessly patient with theory. Require it to be clear, and expect it, in the longer term, to deliver something solid. Don’t be content, as many seem to be, just to see it as ‘challenging’ conventional practice or ‘putting it in question’ in some never quite specified way. Challenges are fine, but they have to amount to something in the end.

停下来思考：回顾你迄今为止的文学研究

STOP and THINK: reviewing your study of literature to date

在我们继续之前，进入一个很可能是你参与文学的新阶段之前，“盘点一下”是明智的并反思一下迄今为止我们文学教育的性质。这样做的目的是开始使您已经变得如此熟悉（可能可以追溯到您上中学的时候）以至于不再可见的方法和程序可见，从而接受审查完全是一种独特的智力实践。但不幸的是，盘点并不是我们正常智力活动的一部分，而且这是一件困难且要求很高的事情。但是请不要跳过这一部分，因为除非您自己感到需要，否则理论对您来说永远没有任何意义。我希望你做的是通过回忆：

Before we go on, into what may well be a new stage in your involvement with literature, it would be sensible to ‘take stock’ and reflect a little on the nature of our literary education to date. The purpose of doing this is to begin the process of making visible, and hence open to scrutiny, the methods and procedures which have become so familar to you (probably going back to the time when you began secondary school) that they are no longer visible at all as a distinct intellectual practice. But stock-taking is not part of our normal intellectual routine, unfortunately, and it is a difficult and demanding thing to do. Yet please do not skip this section, since theory will never make any sense to you until you feel the need for it yourself. What I would like you to do is to try to become conscious of the nature of your own previous work in English, by recalling:

1.最初是什么让你决定学习英语，你希望从中获得什么，这个希望是否实现了；

1. what first made you decide to study English, what you hoped to gain from doing so, and whether that hope was realised;

2. 选择了哪些书籍和作者进行研究，他们有什么共同点；

2. which books and authors were chosen for study and what they had in common;

3. 哪些书籍和作者现在似乎明显缺席；

3. which books and authors now seem conspicuously absent;

4. 一般而言，您之前的研究教会了您什么（关于“生活”，例如，行为，或文学本身）。

4. what, in general terms, your previous study taught you (about ‘life’, say, or conduct, or about literature itself).

这样做将帮助您开始了解您迄今为止的文学经历。花一个小时左右的时间去做。作为本书写作过程的一部分，我自己也进行了类似的练习，部分结果如下所示。它更多的是作为一种提示而不是一种模式，我没有以任何系统的方式回答以上四个问题。复制它可能有助于“个性化”这本书背后的声音，但我让你自己决定是在自己做之前还是之后看这个。
Doing this will help you to begin to obtain a perspective on your experience of literature to date. Spend an hour or so doing it. I carried out a similar exercise myself as part of the process of working on this book, and some of the result is given below. It is intended more as a prompt than a model, and I have not responded in any systematic way to the four questions above. Reproducing it will perhaps help to ‘personalise’ the voice behind this book, but I leave you to decide whether you want to look at this before or after doing your own.

我自己的“盘点”

My own ‘stock-taking’

由于文学理论是本书的主题，我将集中详细介绍我对它的认识过程。事实上，我在 1960 年代后期在伦敦大学读本科时，对文学理论一无所知。我采取了直截了当的“Wulf-to-Woolf”英语课程（从Beowulf到 Virgina Woolf）以及必修的古英语和中古英语论文。我现在意识到，我在 1960 年代后期学习的英语课程基本上保留了一个多世纪前在伦敦大学开设的先锋英语学位课程的形式和前景。

Since literary theory is the topic of this book I will concentrate on detailing the course of my acquaintanceship with it. In fact, I heard nothing at all about literary theory as an undergraduate at London University in the late 1960s. I took a straightforward ‘Wulf-to-Woolf’ English course (Beowulf to Virgina Woolf) with compulsory Old and Middle English papers. Essentially, I now realise, the English course I followed in the late 1960s retained the shape and the outlook of the pioneer English degree courses established at London University more than a century before.

伦敦英语教学的一项创新是认识到美国文学的存在，并任命一名讲师*教它。由于参加了这门美国课程，我成为了一系列美国诗人的狂热爱好者，他们是当时“另类文化”的一部分。与此同时，在之后的几年里，我也或多或少地尝试写这种诗歌。很快就很明显，传统的批评对这样的诗歌几乎无能为力。因此，到 20 世纪 70 年代初，我开始关注比我在大学里遇到的那些新的批判方法。但那时我并不是文学理论的倡导者，因为“理论”本身在当时的文学研究中是一个不存在的范畴。

The one innovation in English teaching at London was to recognise the existence of something called American literature and to appoint a lecturer* to teach it. As a result of taking this American course I became an enthusiast for a range of American poets who were part of the ‘alternative culture’ of the time. At the same time, and for several years afterwards, I was also trying to write poetry of more or less this kind. It quickly became apparent that conventional criticism could make very little of poetry like this. So by the early 1970s I was beginning to look at newer critical approaches than those I had encountered at university. But I wasn’t at that time an advocate of literary theory, since ‘theory’ as such was then a non-existent category in literary studies.

1973 年左右，我自己的案例似乎发生了重点的变化，当时“结构主义”和“符号学”这两个词开始出现在我所读内容的注释中，以及我感兴趣的书籍和文章的标题中。结构主义，我们当时正在学习，是一种新的文学理论，最近在法国变得很重要，符号学（“符号科学”）是它的一个分支。我与弗兰克·克默德 (Frank Kermode) 在成为伦敦大学学院的英语教授后发起的伦敦研究生研讨会有松散的联系。该小组讨论了结构主义者罗兰巴特的作品，并引起了克莫德的热情。我购买并阅读了巴特当时在英国印刷的所有作品，这没什么大不了的，因为所有可用的东西都是写作零度和Elements of Semiology，可能是他最无趣和最难读到的书。1973 年，他的更具吸引力的系列神话以英文出现在 Paladin 印记中。1973 年也是泰晤士报文学副刊将两期（10 月 5 日和 12 日）的主要部分用于“符号学调查”，其中包括翁贝托·艾柯、茨维坦·托多罗夫和朱莉娅·克里斯蒂娃 (Julia Kristeva) 是这些新型批判理论的主要人物，当时（就我而言）是第一次遇到。这种对理论的兴趣在 1981 年得到巩固，当时我被要求设计一门文学理论课程作为我以前大学文学学士课程的一部分，反过来，大约十年的课程教学促成了这本书。

The change of emphasis seems to have happened in my own case around 1973, when the words ‘structuralism’ and ‘semiotics’ begin to feature in notes about what I was reading and in the titles of the books and articles I was interested in. Structuralism, we were then learning, was a new kind of literary theory which had recently become prominent in France, and semiotics (‘the science of signs’) was one of its sub-branches. I was loosely connected with the London Graduate Seminar started by Frank Kermode after he became Professor of English at University College, London. The group debated the work of the structuralist Roland Barthes and caught Kermode’s enthusiasm for it. I bought and read everything by Barthes then in print in England, no great undertaking since all that was available was Writing Degree Zero and Elements of Semiology, probably his least interesting and least accessible books. His much more engaging collection Mythologies appeared in English in 1973 in the Paladin imprint. 1973 was also the year when The Times Literary Supplement devoted the major part of two issues (5 and 12 October) to a ‘Survey of Semiotics’, with articles by Umberto Eco, Tzvetan Todorov, and Julia Kristeva, major names in these new kinds of critical theory and encountered then (in my case) for the first time. This interest in theory was consolidated in 1981 when I was asked to devise a course on literary theory as part of the BA programme at my previous college, and, in turn, a decade or so of teaching that course has led to this book.

1

“理论”之前的理论——自由人文主义

1

Theory before ‘theory’ – liberal humanism

英语研究史

The history of English studies

如果不了解英语作为一门学科是如何发展的，就很难理解自由人文主义（即传统的英语研究方法，见导言，第 3 页）。这就是接下来几页的主题。

It is difficult to understand liberal humanism (that is, the traditional approach to English studies, see the Introduction, p. 3) without knowing something about how English developed as an academic subject. So this is the topic of the next few pages.

停下来想一想

STOP and THINK

下面的多项选择题表明了本节涉及的范围。在进一步阅读之前在您认为正确的答案下划线，然后在继续阅读时根据需要更正您的答案：

The multiple choice questions below indicate the scope of what is touched upon in this section. Underline what you think are the right answers before reading further, and then correct your answers, if necessary, as you read on:

1. 你认为英语最早在英国作为学位课程教授是什么时候？是 1428 年、1528 年、1628 年、1728 年、1828 年还是 1928 年？

1. When do you think English was first taught as a degree subject in England?: was it 1428, 1528, 1628, 1728, 1828, or 1928?

2. 英国最早在哪个机构教授英语作为学位课程？是牛津大学、剑桥大学、伦敦大学、南安普顿大学，还是都不是？

2. At which institution was English first taught as a degree subject in England?: was it Oxford University, Cambridge University, London University, Southampton University, or none of these?

3. 直到十九世纪，你必须是圣公会（圣公会）教会的成员并且是男性才能在英国获得学位。对或错？

3. Until the nineteenth century you had to be a member of the Anglican (Episcopalian) Church and male to take a degree in England. True or false?

4. 直到 19 世纪，英国学位课程的讲师必须是未婚的英格兰教会神职人员。对或错？

4. Until the nineteenth century lecturers on degree courses in England had to be unmarried Church of England clergy. True or false?

5. 直到 19 世纪，女性才被允许在英国攻读学位。对或错？

5. Until the nineteenth century women were not allowed to take degrees in England. True or false?

6. 在二十世纪初期，女性可以在英国攻读学位课程，但不允许获得学位。对或错？

6. In the early twentieth century women could take degree courses in England, but were not allowed to receive degrees. True or false?

为了解释英语研究的兴起，我们需要简要说明 19 世纪前 25 年英国的高等教育情况。简短的回答是，这是英格兰教会的垄断。只有两所大学，牛津和剑桥。这些被分成小型的独立学院，像修道院机构一样运作。当然，只有男性才能参加，而且学生必须是圣公会教徒并参加大学礼拜堂。老师们都是被任命为牧师的，他们必须未婚，这样他们才能住在学院里。可用的科目是经典（古希腊和拉丁文学）、神学（那些寻求圣职的人选修的）和数学。任何天主教徒、犹太教徒、卫理公会教徒或无神论者都被禁止入境，因此，实际上，被禁止进入专业和公务员队伍。那么，就高等教育而言，可以说直到 1820 年代，高等教育的组织形式自中世纪以来一直没有改变。
To explain the rise of English studies we need to indicate briefly what higher education was like in England until the first quarter of the nineteenth century. The short answer is that it was a Church of England monopoly. There were only two universities, Oxford and Cambridge. These were divided into small individual colleges which were run like monastic institutions. Only men could attend them, of course, and students had to be Anglican communicants and attend the college chapel. The teachers were ordained ministers, who had to be unmarried, so that they could live in the college. The subjects available were the classics (ancient Greek and Latin literature), divinity (which was taken by those seeking ordination) and mathematics. Anyone who was Catholic, Jewish, or Methodist, or atheist was barred from entry, and hence, in effect, barred from the professions and the Civil Service. As far as higher education was concerned, then, you could say that right up to the 1820s, the organisation of higher education had not changed since the Middle Ages.

改革形势、扩大高等教育、将实用学科纳入课程等方面进行了许多尝试，但都遇到了根深蒂固的保守势力。突破发生在 1826 年，当时一所大学学院在伦敦成立，其章程授予所有宗教或无宗教信仰的男女学位。从 1828 年开始，英语作为一门学科被提供，他们在 1829 年任命了第一位英语教授。然而，它并不是我们所知道的真正的英语。它主要是英语语言的研究，仅仅使用文学作为语言例子的来源。1831 年，伦敦国王学院（后来成为伦敦大学的另一所学院）首次教授英国文学。

Many attempts were made to reform the situation, expand higher education, and introduce practical subjects into the curriculum, but they all came up against entrenched conservative forces. The break-though came in 1826 when a University College was founded in London with a charter to award degrees to men and women of all religions or none. From 1828 English was offered as a subject for study, and they appointed the first English Professor of English in 1829. However, it was not really English as we know it. It was mainly the study of English language, merely using literature as a source of linguistic examples. English literature as such was first taught at King’s College, London (another college of what later became London University) beginning in 1831.

1840 年，FD Maurice 被任命为国王学院教授。他介绍了固定书籍的研究，他的就职演讲奠定了自由人文主义的一些原则；英语学习文学将有助于“将我们从……我们这个时代特有的观念和习惯中解放出来”，将我们与“固定和持久的东西”联系起来。莫里斯认为文学是中产阶级特有的财产，是他们价值观的体现。对他来说，中产阶级代表了英国人的本质（贵族是国际精英的一部分，穷人需要全力以赴确保生存）所以中产阶级教育应该是英国特色的，因此应该以英语为中心文学。莫里斯很清楚这一切的政治层面。受过如此教育的人会觉得他们属于英格兰，他们拥有一个国家。“政治鼓动者”可能会问“当他的邻居坐着马车而他步行时”这意味着什么，但是“不管他们怎么说，他都会觉得他的国籍是真实的”。简而言之，学习英语将使人们有利于维持政治没有任何财富再分配的现状。

In 1840 F. D. Maurice was appointed Professor at King’s. He introduced the study of set books, and his inaugural lecture lays down some of the principles of liberal humanism; the study of English literature would serve ‘to emancipate us … from the notions and habits which are peculiar to our own age’, connecting us instead with ‘what is fixed and enduring’. Maurice regarded literature as the peculiar property of the middle class and the expression of their values. For him the middle class represents the essence of Englishness (the aristocracy are part of an international elite, and the poor need to give all their attention to ensuring mere survival) so middle-class education should be peculiarly English, and therefore should centre on English literature. Maurice was well aware of the political dimension of all this. People so educated would feel that they belonged to England, that they had a country. ‘Political agitators’ may ask what this can mean ‘when his neighbour rides in a carriage and he walks on foot’, but ‘he will feel his nationality to be a reality, in spite of what they say’. In short, learning English will give people a stake in maintaining the political status quo without any redistribution of wealth.

由此可见，英国文学研究正在被视为宗教的一种替代品。众所周知，中产阶级以下的教会出席人数非常零散。令人担忧的是，下层阶级会觉得他们与国家没有利益关系，并且没有宗教教给他们道德和克制，他们会反抗，并且会发生类似法国大革命的事情。1830 年代的宪章运动被认为是这一切的开始，第一批英语课程恰好在同一时间开设。

You can see from this that the study of English literature is being seen as a kind of substitute for religion. It was well known that attendance at church below middle-class level was very patchy. The worry was that the lower classes would feel that they had no stake in the country and, having no religion to teach them morality and restraint, they would rebel and something like the French Revolution would take place. The Chartist agitation of the 1830s was thought to be the start of this, and the first English courses are put in place at exactly the same time.

对英语学科起源的常规解读是，这种思想始于1850年代的马修·阿诺德，到1921年《英国英语教学纽博尔特报告》的发表达到顶峰。从材料中可以看出就像莫里斯的就职演讲一样，这发生得更早。然而，我不接受这样一种简单化的观点，即英语的创始人只是出于对意识形态控制的渴望。这无疑是他们的动机之一，但现实要复杂得多。在早期英语教学的背后，明显地混合了维多利亚时代对社会不平等的阶级罪恶感、为每个人改善事物的真诚愿望、一种传播文化和启蒙的传教士热情，

The conventional reading of the origins of the subject of English is that this kind of thinking begins with Matthew Arnold in the 1850s and reaches its height with the publication of the Newbolt Report on the Teaching of English in England in 1921. It is evident from material like Maurice’s inaugural lecture that this was happening much earlier. However, I do not accept the simplistic view that the founders of English were motiviated merely by a desire for ideological control. This was undoubtedly one of their motives, but the reality was much more complicated. There was, behind the teaching of early English, a distinctly Victorian mixture of class guilt about social inequalities, a genuine desire to improve things for everybody, a kind of missionary zeal to spread culture and enlightenment, and a self-interested desire to maintain social stability.

伦敦大学的学位是通过外部许可在主要工业城市的大学学院教授的——利物浦、伯明翰、曼彻斯特、谢菲尔德、利兹等等，所有这些地方最终都凭借自己的实力成为主要大学。因此，该学科在整个国家的学位水平上传播。然而，牛津和剑桥对英语这门新学科持怀疑态度并一直反对，牛津直到 1894 年，剑桥直到 1911 年。

London University degrees were taught by external licence at university colleges in major industrial cities – Liverpool, Birmingham, Manchester, Sheffield, Leeds, and so on, all these places eventually becoming major universities in their own right. Hence the spread of the subject at degree level throughout the country. However, Oxford and Cambridge were suspicious of the new subject of English and held out against it, Oxford until 1894 and Cambridge until 1911.

在 19 世纪的最后 25 年里，为在牛津设立英语教席进行了激烈的讨论和运动。1887 年，第一次尝试在很大程度上因为历史学教授爱德华·弗里曼 (Edward Freeman) 在大会上的一次演讲而失败。弗里曼的演讲是另一份重要文件：它涉及到英语中几个尚未解决的问题。他说：

In the last quarter of the nineteenth century there was vigorous discussion and campaigning to establish a Chair in English at Oxford. In 1887 the first attempt was defeated largely because of a speech in the Convocation by the Professor of History, Edward Freeman. Freeman’s speech is another key document: it touches upon several problems in English which are still unresolved. He said:

我们被告知，文学研究“培养品味，培养同情心，开阔心智”。这些都是极好的东西，只是我们无法检验品味和同情。审查员必须有技术和积极的信息才能审查。
We are told that the study of literature ‘cultivates the taste, educates the sympathies and enlarges the mind’. These are all excellent things, only we cannot examine tastes and sympathies. Examiners must have technical and positive information to examine.

这是一个从来没有用英语完全解决的问题。它的知识成分到底是什么？早期的支持者提倡语言的系统学习，作为一种附加特定的技术信息的学习英语的方式，但早期的英语支持者希望将文学和语言学习分开，做到二者缺​​一不可。弗里曼的著名回应是：“如果文学是指对名著的研究，而不仅仅是关于雪莱的闲聊，那么将文学与语言区分开来意味着什么？”

This is a problem which has never been entirely solved in English. What, exactly, is its knowledge component? As a way of attaching specific and technical information to the study of English, early supporters had advocated the systematic study of language, but early advocates of English wanted to separate literature and language study, so that the one could be done without the other. Freeman’s famous response was: ‘what is meant by distinguishing literature from language if by literature is meant the study of great books, and not mere chatter about Shelley?’

弗里曼赢得了争论。文学必须与语言一起研究，否则它根本就不是一门学科。因此，当 1894 年牛津大学最终设立英语课程时，它包含了非常重的历史语言研究元素——盎格鲁-撒克逊语、哥特语、莱托-斯拉夫语、中古英语等，它至今仍未能摆脱这些因素完全。

Freeman won the argument. Literature had to be studied along with language, otherwise it would not be an academic subject at all. So when the English course was finally set up at Oxford in 1894 it contained a very heavy element of historical language study – Anglo-Saxon, Gothic, Letto-Slavonic, Middle English, etc., from which it has still not managed to free itself entirely.

20 年代剑桥英语学校赋予英语更大的方向感。因为剑桥英语成立时间最近，从1911年才成立，所以传统的分量最轻，所以改变起来相对容易。这一变化的工程师是一群开始教书的人20 年代的剑桥。他们是：IA Richards、William Empson 和 FR Leavis。

A greater sense of direction was given to English in the Cambridge English school in the 1920s. Because Cambridge English was the most recently founded, dating only from 1911, it had the least weight of tradition to fight against, so change was relatively easy. The engineers of this change were a group of people who began teaching at Cambridge in the 1920s. They were: I. A. Richards, William Empson, and F. R. Leavis.

IA Richards 是一种学习英语的方法的创始人，这种方法在今天仍然是常态。首先，它在语言和文学之间做出了决定性的决裂。理查兹开创了称为实践批评（他 1929 年著作的书名）的技术。通过将文本与历史和上下文隔离开来，这使得对文学的仔细研究成为可能。例如，学生不必将文艺复兴时期作为一个独特的历史时期及其独特的观点、社会形态等进行研究，而是可以学习实用批评的技巧并简单地分析“页面上的文字”。这样做的好处是，不再可能提供模糊的、华丽的、隐喻性的热情并称其为批评。理查兹认为，应该更加密切地关注文本的精确细节。

I. A. Richards was the founder of a method of studying English which is still the norm today. Firstly, it made a decisive break between language and literature. Richards pioneered the technique called Practical Criticism (the title of his 1929 book). This made a close study of literature possible by isolating the text from history and context. Instead of having to study, say, the Renaissance period as a distinct historical moment, with its characteristic outlook, social formations, and so on, students could learn the techniques of practical criticism and simply analyse ‘the words on the page’. The gain from this was that it was no longer possible to offer a vague, flowery, metaphorical effusion and call it criticism. Richards argued that there should be much more close attention to the precise details of the text.

剑桥大学的第二位先驱是理查兹的学生威廉·恩普森 (William Empson)，他向他的导师赠送了这本书的手稿，该书于 1930 年出版，书名是七种类型的歧义。这本书将理查兹的密切语言分析方法运用到了许多人认为是极端的地方。恩普森确定了诗歌中七种不同类型的语言困难（这就是他所说的歧义），并给出了它们的例子，并进行了分析。另一位剑桥评论家 FR Leavis 在一篇评论中说，这是一本非常令人不安的书，因为它像对待数学一样认真地在诗歌中使用智慧。并不是每个人都喜欢这种超近距离的阅读方式。TS Eliot 将其称为柠檬榨汁机批评学派，他自己的批评写作总是处于更为普遍的水平。

A second Cambridge pioneer was a pupil of Richards, William Empson, who presented his tutor with the manuscript of the book which was published in 1930 with the title Seven Types of Ambiguity. This book took the Richards method of close verbal analysis to what many felt to be an extreme. Empson identified seven different types of verbal difficulty in poetry (which is what he meant by ambiguity) and gave examples of them, with worked analyses. Another Cambridge critic, F. R. Leavis, said in a review that it is a highly disturbing book because it uses intelligence on poetry as seriously as if it were mathematics. Not everybody liked this ultra-close form of reading. T. S. Eliot called it the lemon-squeezer school of criticism, and his own critical writing is always on a much more generalised level.

最后一位剑桥先驱是 FR Leavis，他可能是 20 世纪英国批评界最具影响力的人物。1929 年，他遇到并结婚了 QD Roth，后来被称为 QD Leavis。他的博士论文是关于新闻与文学的关系。她写的是通俗小说。这些都是革命性的话题，在 1930 年代，这对夫妇充满了兴奋和魅力。1932 年，他们创办了一份重要的期刊，名为《审视》(Scrutiny )，并共同创办了 21 年。正如标题所暗示的，它将“细读”方法从诗歌扩展到小说和其他材料。

The last of these Cambridge pioneers was F. R. Leavis, probably the most influential figure in twentieth-century British criticism. In 1929 he met and married Q. D. Roth, subsequently known as Q. D. Leavis. He had written his doctoral thesis on the relationship between journalism and literature. She had written hers on popular fiction. These were revolutionary topics, and a certain excitement and glamour attached to this couple in the 1930s. In 1932 they founded an important journal called Scrutiny and produced it together for twenty-one years. As the title implies, it extended the ‘close-reading’ method beyond poetry to novels and other material.

利维斯作为批评家的错误在于，他的文本细读往往包含冗长的引文，而评论却少得令人惊讶。假设有能力的读者会在那里看到 Leavis 看到的东西。正如对他所说的那样，他经常给人的印象是他在分析文本，而实际上他只是在解释文本。其次，他对文学的态度绝对是道德的。它的目的是教给我们关于生活的知识，传递人文价值。他的批评术语从来没有被恰当地定义过。著名的是，他拒绝了 1930 年代评论家勒内·韦莱克 (René Wellek) 提出的邀请，即他应该“以比迄今为止更明确的方式阐明他运作所依据的原则”。结果是文学研究更加孤立。在刚刚考察的成长时期，它声称独立于语言研究、历史考虑和哲学问题。从 1930 年代到 1960 年代，将这一主题统一起来的共识取决于对这些分界线的接受。从 1960 年代开始的“理论”“计划”本质上是在文学研究与这三个学术领域之间重新建立联系，而这三个领域已经坚决地从中分离出来。

Leavis’s faults as a critic are that his close readings often turn out to contain lengthy quotations on which there is surprisingly little comment. The assumption is that the competent reader will see there what Leavis sees. As has been said of him, he often gives the impression that he is analysing the text when he is really just paraphrasing it. Secondly, his approach to literature is overwhelmingly moral; its purpose is to teach us about life, to transmit humane values. His critical terms are never properly defined. He famously refused the invitation offered by the critic René Wellek in the 1930s that he should ‘spell out the principles on which he operated in a more explicit way than hitherto’. The result was one more degree of isolation for literary studies. In the period of its growth just surveyed, it claimed independence from language studies, from historical considerations, and from philosophical questions. The consensus which held the subject together from the 1930s to the 1960s rested upon the acceptance of these demarcations. The ‘project’ of ‘theory’ from the 1960s onwards is in essence to re-establish connections between literary study and these three academic fields from which it had so resolutely separated itself.

自由人文主义的十大原则

Ten tenets of liberal humanism

第 8-10 页的个人帐户主要回答前面给出的四个问题中的第二个和第三个问题。我现在要扩展第四个问题的含义，它问的是，当我们以传统方式“做”英语时，我们到底学到了什么。当然，我们学习的是关于特定书籍和作者的东西，但我在这里指的是我们从英语中吸收的更普遍的价值观和态度，当所有这些具体细节都被遗忘时，它们仍然作为该学科的一种提炼本质。这些通常不会被表述和陈述，但从某种意义上说，它们更加真实，同时具有普遍性和无形性。它们只能通过有意识的意志努力浮出水面，就像我们现在正在努力做的那样。因此，接下来是一些元素的列表，这些元素似乎构成了这个主题的“提炼出来的本质”，也就是我们在做这些事情时可能不知不觉中收集到的态度、假设和想法的语料库。这些似乎是我们在学习时所学的学习英语——这些是构成该学科半隐藏课程的价值观和信念：

The personal account on pp. 8–10 mainly responds to the second and third of the four questions given earlier. I’m now going to expand on the implications of the fourth question, which asked what it is, exactly, that we learn when we ‘do’ English in the traditional way. Of course, we learn things about specific books and authors, but I mean here the more general values and attitudes which we absorb from English, and which remain as a kind of distilled essence of the subject when all these specific details have been forgotten. These are not usually formulated and stated, but they are, in a sense, all the more real for that, being simultaneously both pervasive and invisible. They can only be brought to the surface by a conscious effort of will, of the kind we are now trying to make. So what follows is a list of some of the elements which seem to constitute this ‘distilled essence’ of the subject, that is, the corpus of attitudes, assumptions, and ideas which we pick up, probably unawares, as we do it. These seem to have been what we were learning when we studied English – these are the values and beliefs which formed the subject’s half-hidden curriculum:

1、首先自然是对文学本身的态度；好的文学具有永恒的意义；它以某种方式超越了它所处时代的局限性和特殊性，从而说明了人性中不变的东西。这样的写作“不是为了一个时代，而是为了所有时代”（正如本·琼森对莎士比亚的评价）：它是“新闻就是新闻”（埃兹拉·庞德对文学的定义）。

1. The first thing, naturally, is an attitude to literature itself; good literature is of timeless significance; it somehow transcends the limitations and peculiarities of the age it was written in, and thereby speaks to what is constant in human nature. Such writing is ‘not for an age, but for all time’ (as Ben Jonson said of Shakespeare): it is ‘news which stays news’ (Ezra Pound’s definition of literature).

2. 第二点是第一点的逻辑结果。文学文本本身就包含着自己的意义。它不需要任何将其置于上下文中的复杂过程，无论是：

2. The second point is the logical consequence of the first. The literary text contains its own meaning within itself. It doesn’t require any elaborate process of placing it within a context, whether this be:

(a)社会政治——特定社会“背景”或政治局势的背景，或
(a) Socio-political – the context of a particular social ‘background’ or political situation, or
(b)文学历史——作品可以被视为其他作家的文学影响的产物，或者被特定流派的惯例所塑造，或者
(b) Literary-historical – whereby the work could be seen as the product of the literary influences of other writers, or as shaped by the conventions of particular genres, or
(c)自传式——即由作者生活和思想的个人细节决定。
(c) Autobiographical – that is, as determined by the personal details of the author’s life and thought.
当然，作为学者，大多数学者会主张研究这些背景的价值，但作为批评家，他们坚持坚持“纸上文字”的首要性和自给自足的方法，这使他们致力于这一过程称为“视读细读”。从本质上讲，这从所有这些上下文中删除了文本，并将其呈现为“看不见的”，以供训练有素的头脑进行独立解释。
Of course, as scholars, most academics would assert the value of studying these contexts, but as critics their adherence to the approach which insists upon the primacy and self-sufficiency of the ‘words on the page’ commits them to the process which has been called ‘on-sight close reading’. Essentially, this removes the text from all these contexts and presents it ‘unseen’ for unaided explication by the trained mind.

3. 要很好地理解文本，就必须脱离这些上下文并孤立地研究。需要的是在没有事先意识形态假设、政治先决条件或任何形式的特定期望的情况下对文本进行仔细的语言分析，因为所有这些都可能致命地干扰 19 世纪批评家马修阿诺德所说的内容批评的真正目的是“如实看待对象本身”。

3. To understand the text well it must be detached from these contexts and studied in isolation. What is needed is the close verbal analysis of the text without prior ideological assumptions, or political pre-conditions, or, indeed, specific expectations of any kind, since all these are likely to interfere fatally with what the nineteenth-century critic Matthew Arnold said was the true business of criticism, ‘to see the object as in itself it really is’.

4、人性本质上是不变的。同样的激情、情绪，甚至情境在整个过程中一次又一次地出现人类历史。由此可见，文学的连续性比创新更重要、更有意义。因此，18 世纪一个著名的诗歌定义认为，诗歌是“经常被想到但从未被如此恰当地表达出来的东西”。同样，著名的塞缪尔·约翰逊 (Samuel Johnson) 诋毁斯特恩 (Sterne) 的小说《项狄传 ( Tristram Shandy )》的新颖性，即原创性。

4. Human nature is essentially unchanging. The same passions, emotions, and even situations are seen again and again throughout human history. It follows that continuity in literature is more important and significant than innovation. Thus, a well-known eighteenth-century definition of poetry maintains that it is ‘what oft was thought but ne’er so well expressed’. Likewise, Samuel Johnson famously denigrated Sterne’s novel Tristram Shandy on the grounds of its novelty, that is, its originality.

5. 个性是我们每个人都牢牢拥有的东西，作为我们独特的“本质”。这超越了我们的环境影响，虽然个性可以改变和发展（就像小说中的人物一样），但它不能被改变——因此我们对那些涉及“改变性格中的“心”，使整个人格因环境的力量而转移到一个新的维度——守财奴改变了他的方式，或者好男人或女人被财富腐蚀了。这样的场景暗示了性格本质上的可塑性，这与英语研究的这一基本假设不一致。作为一个整体，该学科相信现在所谓的“先验主体”，即个人（“主体”）先于，

5. Individuality is something securely possessed within each of us as our unique ‘essence’. This transcends our environmental influences, and though individuality can change and develop (as do characters in novels), it can’t be transformed – hence our uneasiness with those scenes (quite common, for instance, in Dickens) which involve a ‘change of heart’ in a character, so that the whole personality is shifted into a new dimension by force of circumstance – the miser is transformed and changes his ways, or the good man or woman becomes corrupted by wealth. Such scenes imply a malleability in the essence of character which is at odds with this underlying assumption of English studies. The discipline as a whole believed in what is now called the ‘transcendent subject’, which is the belief that the individual (‘the subject’) is antecedent to, or transcends, the forces of society, experience, and language.

6. 文学的目的本质上是提高生活水平和传播人文价值；但不是以一种有计划的方式：如果文学和批评变得公开和直接政治化，它们必然倾向于宣传。正如济慈所说，“我们不相信对我们有明显设计的文学”，也就是说，文学太明显想要改变我们或影响我们的观点。

6. The purpose of literature is essentially the enhancement of life and the propagation of humane values; but not in a programmatic way: if literature, and criticism, become overtly and directly political they necessarily tend towards propaganda. And as Keats said, ‘we distrust literature which has a palpable design upon us’, that is, literature which too obviously wants to convert us or influence our views.

7. 文学的形式和内容必须以有机的方式融合在一起，这样一个不可避免地从另一个发展。文学形式不应该像一个装饰品，外加于一个完整的结构。例如，意象或任何其他以这种方式与作品的实质分离而不是与之结合的诗歌形式仅仅是“幻想的”而不是真正的“想象的”（柯勒律治在传记中做出的区分文学）。

7. Form and content in literature must be fused in an organic way, so that the one grows inevitably from the other. Literary form should not be like a decoration which is applied externally to a completed structure. Imagery, for instance, or any other poetic form which is detachable from the substance of the work in this way, rather than being integrated with it, is merely ‘fanciful’ and not truly ‘imaginative’ (the distinction made by Coleridge in the Biographia Literaria).

8. 关于有机形式的这一点首先适用于“真诚”。真诚（包括对经验的真实性，对客户的诚实自我，以及人类同理心和同情心的能力）是一种存在于文学语言中的品质。这不是事实或背后的意图例如，可以通过将诗人对事件的看法与其他更“真实”的版本进行比较，或者通过发现有关作者的历史或行为的独立的外部信息来收集作品。相反，在避免陈词滥调或过度夸张的表达形式等方面，应在文本中发现真诚；它表现在使用第一手资料、个人主义的描述、低调的情感表达，从而（最好）允许情感从事件的呈现中隐含地浮现出来。而且，当语言达到这些品质时，真正真诚的诗人才能超越语言与材料之间的距离感，使语言看起来像是在“表演”它所描绘的，从而显然消除了词与物之间的必要距离。

8. This point about organic form applies above all to ‘sincerity’. Sincerity (comprising truth-to-experience, honesty towards the self, and the capacity for human empathy and compassion) is a quality which resides within the language of literature. It isn’t a fact or an intention behind the work, which could be gleaned by comparing, say, a poet’s view of an event with other more ‘factual’ versions, or from discovering independent, external information about an author’s history or conduct. Rather, sincerity is to be discovered within the text in such matters as the avoidance of cliché, or of over-inflated forms of expression; it shows in the use of first hand, individualistic description, in the understated expression of feeling, whereby (preferably) the emotion is allowed to emerge implicitly from the presentation of an event. Moreover, when the language achieves these qualities, then the truly sincere poet can transcend the sense of distance between language and material, and can make the language seem to ‘enact’ what it depicts, thus apparently abolishing the necessary distance between words and things.

9. 同样，下一个想法来自上一个想法。文学所看重的是对某事的“无声”展示和论证，而不是对它的解释或说说。因此，在给出“制定”的具体体现之前，这样的想法在文学中是毫无价值的。因此，文学史上经常引用的一些明确的评论和表述包含对思想本身的特定诋毁，并具有明显的反智色彩。在这里，我们看到了触觉制定的特征“Eng Lit”理念的提升，感觉的直接性，思想的具体表现等等。根据这个想法（当然，它本身就是一个想法，尽管所讨论的想法是对想法的自称不信任），词语应该模仿、展示、表演、或说出它们的意思，而不是仅仅以抽象的方式表示它。这个想法在 FR Leavis 的著作中得到了特别热烈的阐述。（对于“制定”观点的批评，请参阅本作者在1980 年 7 月的批评论文中的“制定谬误” 。有关一般性讨论，请参阅 James Gribble 的文学教育：重新评估，剑桥大学出版社，1983 年,第 2 章。）

9. Again, the next idea follows from the previous one. What is valued in literature is the ‘silent’ showing and demonstrating of something, rather than the explaining, or saying, of it. Hence, ideas as such are worthless in literature until given the concrete embodiment of ‘enactment’. Thus, several of the explicit comments and formulations often cited in literary history contain specific denigrations of ideas as such and have a distinct anti-intellectual flavour to them. Here we see the elevation of the characteristic ‘Eng Lit’ idea of tactile enactment, of sensuous immediacy, of the concrete representation of thought, and so on. According to this idea (which is, of course, itself an idea, in spite of the fact that the idea in question is a professed distrust of ideas) words should mime, or demonstrate, or act out, or sound out what they signify, rather than just representing it in an abstract way. This idea is stated with special fervency in the work of F. R. Leavis. (For a critique of the ‘enactment’ idea see ‘The Enactment Fallacy’, by the present author, in Essays in Criticism, July 1980. For a general discussion see James Gribble’s Literary Education: A Re-evaluation, Cambridge University Press, 1983, chapter 2.)

10.批评的工作是解释文本，在文本和读者之间进行调停。对阅读本质的理论解释，或一般文学，在批评中没有用，如果尝试，只会用“先入为主的想法”阻碍批评家，这将阻碍他们和文本。或许在“先入为主的观念”这个短语中，我们又一次瞥见了自由人文主义中这种普遍存在的对观念的不信任的本质，因为似乎有这样一种观念，即所有的观念在某种程度上都是“先入为主的”，从某种意义上说，它们将介于读者和文本，如果有一半的机会。事实上，这里有所谓的“英国经验主义”的明显标志，它可以被定义为只相信感官上显而易见的或直接体验到的东西的决心。最终，这种态度至少可以追溯到 John Locke（1632-1704）的哲学，它给出了一种哲学表达。他的书《人类理解论》（169​​0）提出了思想是当来自世界的直接感官印象印在头脑中时形成的观点。然后头脑将这些组合起来，从而产生思考的过程。洛克拒绝将内省思辨作为有效知识的来源，并坚持需要对事物的直接经验和证据。我们可以说，传统的英语研究在这个意义上一直是洛克式的。

10. The job of criticism is to interpret the text, to mediate between it and the reader. A theoretical account of the nature of reading, or of literature in general, isn’t useful in criticism, and will simply, if attempted, encumber critics with ‘preconceived ideas’ which will get between them and the text. Perhaps in this phrase ‘preconceived ideas’ we get another glimpse into the nature of this pervasive distrust of ideas within liberal humanism, for there seems to be the notion that somehow all ideas are ‘preconceived’, in the sense that they will come between the reader and text if given half a chance. There is, in fact, the clear mark here of what is called ‘English empiricism’, which can be defined as a determination to trust only what is made evident to the senses or experienced directly. Ultimately this attitude goes back at least to the philosophy of John Locke (1632–1704), which gives a philosophical expression to it. His book Essay Concerning Human Understanding (1690) puts forward the view that ideas are formed when direct sense impressions from the world are imprinted on the mind. The mind then assembles these, so giving rise to the process of thinking. Locke rejected introspective speculation as a source of valid knowledge and insisted on the need for direct experience and evidence of things. Traditional English studies, we might say, has always been Lockean in this sense.

上面的列表包含了一系列的命题，我认为如果他们习惯于明确他们的假设，那么从整体上来说，许多传统批评家会赞同这些命题。像这样的想法，以及随之而来的文学实践，现在通常被称为“自由人文主义”。
The above list contains a series of propositions which I think many traditional critics would, on the whole, subscribe to, if they were in the habit of making their assumptions explicit. Together, ideas like these, and the literary practice which went with them, are now often referred to as ‘liberal humanism’.

从亚里士多德到利维斯的文学理论——一些关键时刻

Literary theorising from Aristotle to Leavis – some key moments

到目前为止，我可能给人的印象是，关于文学的理论立场从来没有被自由人文主义者明确表述过，至少在英国是这样，而且一切都是含蓄的。然而，英语研究从一开始就存在广泛流行的理论著作，并且经常在书籍和论文中引用它。直到 1970 年代，“Eng Lit”的普通学生或老师可能与此有相当有限的直接接触工作主体，因为该主题的整个主旨远离这种普遍的立场。

So far I have perhaps given the impression that theoretical positions about literature were never explicitly formulated by liberal humanists, at least in Britain, and that everything remained implicit. Yet a widely current body of theoretical work existed from the start within English studies, and references were often made to it in books and essays. The average student or teacher of ‘Eng Lit’ up to the 1970s would probably have had a fairly limited direct contact with this body of work, since the whole thrust of the subject was away from this kind of generalised position-taking.

那么，是什么构成了作为文学研究的可用基础而存在了多个世纪的文学理论体系，即使文学专业的学生很少对它有任何广泛的第一手资料？好吧，这些材料可以追溯到希腊语和拉丁语原文。事实上，批评理论早于对个别作品的文学批评。最早的理论著作是亚里士多德的《诗学》（公元前4 世纪)，尽管它的标题是关于文学本身的本质：亚里士多德提供了著名的悲剧定义，坚持认为文学是关于性格的，而性格是通过行动揭示的，他试图确定悲剧中所需的阶段情节的进展。亚里士多德也是第一个发展“以读者为中心”的文学方法的批评家，因为他对戏剧的思考试图描述它如何影响观众。他说，悲剧应该激发怜悯和恐惧的情绪，粗略地说，是对主人公困境的同情和同情。这些情绪的结合产生了亚里士多德称之为“宣泄”的效果，即当观众认同中心人物的困境时，这些情绪得到锻炼，而不是被驱散。

What, then, constituted the body of theory about literature that has existed for many centuries as an available under-pinning for the study of literature, even if literary students seldom had any extensive first hand acquaintance with it? Well, the material goes back to Greek and Latin originals. Critical theory, in fact, long predates the literary criticism of individual works. The earliest work of theory was Aristotle’s Poetics (4th century BC), which, in spite of its title, is about the nature of literature itself: Aristotle offers famous definitions of tragedy, insists that literature is about character, and that character is revealed through action, and he tries to identify the required stages in the progress of a plot. Aristotle was also the first critic to develop a ‘reader-centred’ approach to literature, since his consideration of drama tried to describe how it affected the audience. Tragedy, he said, should stimulate the emotions of pity and fear, these being, roughly, sympathy for and empathy with the plight of the protagonist. By the combination of these emotions came about the effect Aristotle called ‘catharsis’, whereby these emotions are exercised, rather than exorcised, as the audience identifies with the plight of the central character.

关于文学的英文著作中第一个享有盛誉的名字是菲利普·西德尼爵士 (Sir Philip Sidney)，他大约在 1580 年写下了他的《为诗歌辩护》。西德尼打算扩展拉丁诗人奥维德 (43) 首次提出的古代文学定义的含义。公元前–公元17 年），他曾说过它的使命是“docere delictendo” ——以愉悦的方式进行教学（大致意思是通过娱乐）。西德尼还引用了贺拉斯（公元前 65-8年)，大意是说，一首诗是“一幅会说话的图画，为此目的，是为了教导和取悦”。因此，这里允许给予快乐在文学阅读中处于中心位置，这与哲学不同，哲学被含蓄地打上了有价值和令人振奋的烙印，但没有太多乐趣。文学给人带来快乐的概念现在似乎是一种平凡的情感，但西德尼的目标是将文学与其他写作形式区分开来的革命性目标，因为文学的主要目的是给读者带来快乐，任何道德或说教因素都必然从属于它，或者至少，没有它就不可能成功。在宗教时代，对一切形式深表怀疑小说、诗歌和再现，并且总是可能谴责它们是魔鬼的作品，这是迈出的非常重要的一步。因此，在英语中，批评理论也先于实践批评，因为西德尼写的是一般文学，而不是个别作品或作家。

The first prestigious name in English writing about literature is that of Sir Philip Sidney, who wrote his ‘Apology for Poetry’ in about 1580. Sidney was intent on expanding the implications of the ancient definition of literature first formulated by the Latin poet Ovid (43 BC–AD 17), who had said that its mission is ‘docere delictendo’ – to teach by delighting (meaning, approximately, by entertaining). Sidney also quotes Horace (65–8 BC), to the effect that a poem is ‘a speaking picture, with this end, to teach and delight’. Thus, the giving of pleasure is here allowed a central position in the reading of literature, unlike, say, philosophy, which is implicitly stigmatised as worthy and uplifting, but not much fun. The notion of literature giving pleasure will now seem an unremarkable sentiment, but Sidney’s aim was the revolutionary one of distinguishing literature from other forms of writing, on the grounds that, uniquely, literature has as its primary aim the giving of pleasure to the reader, and any moral or didactic element is necessarily either subordinate to that, or at least, unlikely to succeed without it. In a religious age, deeply suspicious of all forms of fiction, poetry, and representation, and always likely to denounce them as the work of the devil, this was a very great step to take. In English too, then, critical theory came before practical criticism, as Sidney is writing about literature in general, not about individual works or writers.

18 世纪塞缪尔·约翰逊 (Samuel Johnson) 大大推进了西德尼之后的文学理论。约翰逊的诗人传记和莎士比亚序言既可以看作是批评理论向前迈出的又一大步，也可以看作是英国实践批评传统的开端，因为他是第一个对单个作者的作品进行详细评论的人. 在约翰逊之前，唯一受到这种严格审查的文本是圣经，以及其他宗教的同等圣书。将这种做法扩展到那些被认为是神圣灵感的直接产物以外的作品，标志着世俗人道主义发展的重要进步时刻。

Literary theory after Sidney was significantly advanced by Samuel Johnson in the eighteenth century. Johnson’s Lives of the Poets and Prefaces to Shakespeare can be seen both as another major step forward in critical theory, and as the start of the English tradition of practical criticism, since he is the first to offer detailed commentary on the work of a single author. Prior to Johnson, the only text which had ever been subjected to this intensive scrutiny was the Bible, and the equivalent sacred books of other religions. The extension of this practice to works other than those thought to be the direct product of divine inspiration marks a significant moment of progress in the development of secular humanism.

约翰逊之后，浪漫主义诗人华兹华斯、柯勒律治、济慈和雪莱的作品中出现了批评理论的重要萌芽。主要文本之一是华兹华斯的抒情歌谣序言。华兹华斯在这篇序言中所写的是他与柯勒律治共同讨论的产物。在 1798 年出版的第一版民谣遇到困惑后，该介绍被添加到 1800 年出版的第二版民谣中。这本书融合了高雅文学和通俗文学，因为它包含以普通乡下人的流行口头歌谣为蓝本的文学歌谣。抒情歌谣的原始读者也不喜欢放弃言语礼仪的惯例。这些约定对诗歌语言施加了高度的人为性，使其与普通日常语言尽可能不同。因此，专门的诗歌词汇倾向于禁止使用简单的日常用语，复杂的韵律系统和高度压缩的语法形式产生了比普通语言密度大得多的语言结构。突然间，两位雄心勃勃的年轻诗人试图让他们的诗歌语言尽可能地像散文，避免长期占据主导地位的措辞和语言结构的惯例。因此，这本书是文学理论中众多重要的批评著作之一直接目的是为批评家自己的诗歌作品提供一个基本原理，并为它教育观众。它还预见了当代批评理论非常感兴趣的问题，例如诗歌语言与“普通”语言之间的关系，以及“文学”与其他类型写作之间的关系。

After Johnson came a major burgeoning of critical theory in the work of the Romantic poets: Wordsworth, Coleridge, Keats, and Shelley. One of the main texts is Wordsworth’s Preface to Lyrical Ballads. What Wordsworth wrote in this preface was the product of collaborative discussions between himself and Coleridge. The introduction was added to the second edition of the ballads, published in 1800, after the first, of 1798, had been met with puzzlement. The book blends high literature and popular literature, since it contains literary ballads constructed on the model of the popular oral ballads of ordinary country people. The original readers of Lyrical Ballads also disliked the abandonment of the conventions of verbal decorum. These conventions had imposed a high degree of artificiality on poetic language, making it as different as possible from the language of ordinary everyday speech. Thus, a specialised poetic vocabulary had tended to enjoin the avoidance of simple everyday terms for things, and an elaborate system of rhyme and a highly compressed form of grammar had produced a verbal texture of much greater density than that of ordinary language. Suddenly, two ambitious young poets were trying to make their poetic language as much like prose as possible, avoiding the conventions of diction and verbal structure which had held sway for so long. Thus, this book is one of a number of significant critical works in literary theory whose immediate aim is to provide a rationale for the critic’s own poetic work, and to educate the audience for it. It also anticipates issues of great interest to contemporary critical theory, such as the relationship between poetic language and ‘ordinary’ language, and that between ‘literature’ and other kinds of writing.

浪漫主义时期的第二部重要作品是柯勒律治的误导性标题Biographia Literaria。这个标题可能会让我们期待像约翰逊的诗人生活这样的作品，但实际上它的大部分内容直接解决了华兹华斯序言中包含的想法，通过仔细考虑他的作品的各个方面，可以看出华兹华斯在最远离坚持他自己的诗歌应该是什么的理论时写出了他最好的诗歌。事实上，在他和柯勒律治作为朋友逐渐疏远的那些年里，他们对诗歌的本质也持有截然不同的看法。柯勒律治完全不同意诗歌语言必须努力变得更像散文语言的观点。他认为这是诗意效果的贫乏，最终必须证明是自杀。这个论点与已经引用的作品完全吻合：如果文学和其他作品在目标和效果上有所不同，正如亚里士多德和西德尼所坚持的那样，如果诗歌与其他类型的写作不同，旨在通过娱乐来教学，那么娱乐的主要方式必须是通过其编写的语言。语言以其“虚构”的品质来娱乐——这是审美效果的来源。类似这样的东西在雪莱的作品中也有暗示A Defense of Poetry (1821)，它认为诗歌本质上参与了一群二十世纪的俄罗斯评论家后来称之为“陌生化”的事情。雪莱预见到了这个术语，因为对他来说，诗歌“揭开了世界熟悉的面纱……它从我们内心的视线中清除了熟悉的电影……它迫使我们去感受我们所感知的，并想象我们所知道的”。这份非凡的批评性文件还预见了 TS Eliot 的非人格概念（在他 1919 年的论文“传统与个人才能”中提出），即作者（作品背后的人）（我们可能称之为）之间存在区别和作者（可以说，是书中的“人”工作）。在艾略特看来，两者之间的分离越大越好，因为“艺术家越完美，他就越完全分离”受苦和创造的思想”，因此诗歌不仅仅是将个人经历有意识地转化为文字。一百年前，雪莱在他极具权威的散文中记录了这一切：

A second significant work from the Romantic era was Coleridge’s misleadingly titled Biographia Literaria. The title might lead us to expect a work like Johnson’s Lives of the Poets, but in fact much of it directly addresses the ideas contained in Wordsworth’s Preface, showing by a close consideration of aspects of his work that Wordsworth writes his best poetry when he is furthest away from adherence to his own theories of what poetry should be. Indeed, in the years during which he and Coleridge had drifted apart as friends, they had also taken radically different views about the nature of poetry. Coleridge came to disagree completely with the view that the language of poetry must strive to become more like the language of prose. He saw this as an impoverishment of the poetic effect which must ultimately prove suicidal. The argument dovetails neatly with the works already cited: if literature and other works differ in their aims and effects, as Aristotle and Sidney had maintained, and if poetry, unlike other kinds of writing, aims to teach by entertaining, then the major way in which the entertaining is done must be through the language in which it is written. The language entertains by its ‘fictive’ qualities – this is the source of the aesthetic effect. Something like this is also connoted in Shelley’s A Defence of Poetry (1821), which sees poetry as essentially engaged in what a group of twentieth-century Russian critics later called ‘defamiliarisation’. Shelley anticipates this term, since for him poetry ‘strips the veil of familiarity from the world … it purges from our inward sight the film of familiarity … It compels us to feel that which we perceive, and to imagine that which we know’. This remarkable critical document also anticipates T. S. Eliot’s notion of impersonality (put forward in his 1919 essay ‘Tradition and the Individual Talent’) whereby there is a distinction between (as we might call it) the author (who is the person behind the work) and the writer (who is, so to speak, the ‘person’ in the work). In Eliot’s view, the greater the separation between the two the better, since ‘the more perfect the artist, the more completely separate in him will be the man who suffers and the mind which creates’, so that poetry is not simply the conscious rendering of personal experience into words. Shelley registers all this a hundred years earlier in his characteristically magisterial prose:

创作中的思想就像一块褪色的煤炭，一些无形的影响，就像一阵无常的风，唤醒了短暂的光明；这种力量从内部产生，就像花朵的颜色随着它的发展而褪色和变化，我们本性的有意识部分对于它的接近或离开是不可预知的。
the mind in creation is as a fading coal, which some invisible influence, like an inconstant wind, awakens to transitory brightness; this power arises from within, like the colour of a flower which fades and changes as it is developed, and the conscious portions of our natures are unprophetic either of its approach or of its departure.

（辩护，第 999-1003 行，我的斜体）

(A Defence, lines 999–1003, my italics)

这里也预示着弗洛伊德的心灵概念是由有意识和无意识的元素组成的。事实上，无意识的概念是浪漫主义的一个基本概念，并且隐含在另一位主要浪漫主义者约翰济慈所写的关于诗歌的所有作品中。济慈并没有像华兹华斯、柯勒律治和雪莱那样写出正式的文学理论，但他确实在他的书信中以持续的方式反思诗歌。他也提出了无意识运作的概念，例如在 1817 年 11 月 22 日给贝利的一封信中，他谈到“简单的想象力如何通过重复其自身的无声工作而不断地在精神上得到回报”突然之间很好'。头脑的“无声工作”是无意识，它爆发的“精神”是有意识的。济慈关于“消极能力”的想法也相当于赋予无意识同样的特权，同样希望让它发挥作用，消极能力是“当一个人能够处于不确定、神秘、怀疑之中，而不急躁地追寻事实”和理由”（给他兄弟的信，1817 年 12 月 21 日）。因此，在浪漫主义的批评著作中，有许多对当今批评理论所关注的问题的预期。

There is also an anticipation here of the Freudian notion of the mind as made up of conscious and unconscious elements. Indeed, the idea of the unconscious is an essential one in Romanticism, and implicit in everything written about poetry by another major Romanticist, John Keats. Keats did not write formal literary theory in the way Wordsworth, Coleridge, and Shelley did, but he did reflect on poetry in a sustained way in his letters. He too formulates a notion of the workings of the unconscious, for instance in a letter to Bailey of 22 November 1817 when he speaks of how ‘the simple imaginative Mind may have its rewards in the repetition of its own silent Working coming continually on the Spirit with a fine suddenness’. The ‘silent working’ of the mind is the unconscious and the ‘spirit’ into which it erupts is the conscious. Keats’s idea of ‘negative capability’ also amounts to this same privileging of the unconscious, this same desire to allow it scope to work, negative capability being ‘when a man is capable of being in uncertainties, mysteries, doubts without any irritable reaching after fact and reason’ (letter to his brothers, 21 December 1817). In the critical writings of the Romantics, then, there are many anticipations of the concerns of critical theory today.

浪漫主义之后，批判理论的主要发展是维多利亚时代中期和后期的乔治·艾略特、马修·阿诺德和亨利·詹姆斯的著作。乔治·艾略特的批评作品广泛涉及古典和欧陆作家以及哲学问题，柯勒律治也是如此。值得强调这一点，因为英语批评的发展有两条截然不同的“轨道”。一条轨道通过塞缪尔约翰逊和马修阿诺德通往 TS 艾略特和 FR 利维斯。这可能被称为“实践批评”轨道。它倾向于以对特定作家作品的仔细分析为中心，并赋予我们熟悉的“文本细读”传统。另一条轨道穿过西德尼、华兹华斯、柯勒律治、乔治·艾略特和亨利·詹姆斯。这条赛道非常“以思想为主导”而不是“以文字为主导”：它倾向于解决与文学有关的大的一般性问题——文学作品是如何构成的？它们如何影响读者或观众？文学语言的本质是什么？文学如何与当代以及政治和性别问题相关？从哲学的角度来看文学可以说些什么？文学创作行为的本质是什么？这些“第二轨道”的关注点与 1960 年代后变得突出的批判理论家的关注点非常相似，重要的是要认识到，这些关注点并不是对“本土”英美文学方法的异国强加，而是，相反，从一开始就参与其中。

After the Romantics the main developments in critical theory were the work of mid and late Victorians, George Eliot, Matthew Arnold, and Henry James. George Eliot’s critical work ranges widely over classical and continental writers, and philosophical issues, as did Coleridge’s. It is worth emphasising this, since there are two distinct ‘tracks’ in the development of English criticism. One track leads through Samuel Johnson and Matthew Arnold to T. S. Eliot and F. R. Leavis. This might be called the ‘practical criticism’ track. It tends to centre upon the close analysis of the work of particular writers, and gives us our familiar tradition of ‘close reading’. The other track lies through Sidney, Wordsworth, Coleridge, George Eliot, and Henry James. This track is very much ‘ideas-led’ rather than ‘text-led’: it tends to tackle big general issues concerned with literature – How are literary works structured? How do they affect readers or audiences? What is the nature of literary language? How does literature relate to the contemporary and to matters of politics and gender? What can be said about literature from a philosophical point of view? What is the nature of the act of literary composition? These ‘track two’ preoccupations are very similar to the concerns of the critical theorists who became prominent from the 1960s onwards, and it is important to realise that these concerns are not an exotic imposition upon ‘native’ Anglo-American approaches to literature but, rather, have been part of it from the beginning.

1920 年代坚持“文本细读”的做法部分源于马修·阿诺德 (Matthew Arnold) 在上个世纪的著作。阿诺德一直是英国批评史上的重要经典人物，部分原因是 FR Leavis 采纳并改编了他的一些想法和态度，并使它们在 20 世纪流行起来。阿诺德担心宗教的衰落会留下一个日益分裂的社会，没有共同的信仰、价值观和形象体系，这可能会带来灾难性的后果。在这方面，他认为文学可以替代宗教，但认为民主的负担和责任主要落在中产阶级身上，他们已经逐渐被唯物主义和市侩所贬低。

The insistence upon ‘close reading’ in the 1920s sprang partly from the work of Matthew Arnold in the previous century. Arnold has remained a key canonical figure in the history of English criticism, partly because F. R. Leavis adopted and adapted several of his ideas and attitudes and gave them twentieth-century currency. Arnold feared that the decline of religion would leave an increasingly divided society with no common system of beliefs, values, and images, with potentially disastrous consequences. He saw literature as a possible replacement for religion in this regard, but believed that the middle classes, on whom the burden and responsibility of democracy largely fell, had been progressively debased by materialism and philistinism. The critic would help such people to recognise ‘the best that has been known and thought in the world’ and thus enable them to give individual assent to the canon of great works which had emerged through the collective wisdom of the ages.
