The distinction between ‘story’ and ‘plot’ is fundamental to narratology, but the story of narratology itself is that there are many competing groups, each tending to prefer its own terminology; hence, you will find the same distinction made with different terms. For instance, in his well-known essay ‘Analysis and interpretation of the realist text’ (in his book Working with Structuralism, RKP, 1980), David Lodge prefers the Russian Formalist terms fabula, instead of ‘story’, and sjuzhet (pronounced ‘soojay’) for ‘plot’, though I don’t myself see any advantage now in using these terms. Most current North American writing on narratology uses ‘story’, but instead of ‘plot’ the term ‘discourse’ is often preferred. This, I think, is sensible, because it isn’t just ‘plot’ in the narrow sense which is at issue, but style, viewpoint, pace, and so on, which is to say, the whole ‘packaging’ of the narrative which creates the overall effect. Gérard Genette (see below, pp. 222–31) uses yet another set of equivalent terms, these being histoire, which has the same meaning as ‘story’ or fabula, and recit, which means the same as ‘plot’ or sjuzhet.

亚里士多德

Aristotle

与叙事学相关的第二个故事是叙事学本身的故事。叙述学的截短“历史”如下，以三个为中心主要人物，其中第一个是亚里士多德。在他的《诗学》中，正如我们在第 1 章（第 20-1 页）中看到的那样，亚里士多德将“人物”和“动作”确定为故事中的基本元素，并说人物必须通过动作来揭示，也就是说通过情节的各个方面。他确定了情节中的三个关键元素，它们是（使用亚里士多德的希腊词，这里只是英语化，但没有翻译）：

A second story relevant to narratology is the story of narratology itself. A truncated ‘history’ of narratology follows, centred on three main characters, the first of whom is Aristotle. In his Poetics, as we saw in chapter 1 (pp. 20–1), Aristotle identifies ‘character’ and ‘action’ as the essential elements in a story, and says that character must be revealed through action, which is to say through aspects of the plot. He identifies three key elements in a plot, these being (using Aristotle’s Greek words, which are here simply Anglicised, but not translated):

1.错觉

1. the hamartia

2.认识论

2. the anagnorisis

3. peripeteia

3. the peripeteia

hamartia的意思是“罪恶”或“错误”（在悲剧戏剧中，这通常是致命的性格缺陷的产物，后来被称为“悲剧性缺陷”）。anagnorisis的意思是“认识”或“实现”，这是叙述中主人公认识到情况真相的时刻——通常是自我认识的时刻。peripeteia _表示命运的“转机”或“逆转”。在古典悲剧中，这通常是从高位跌落到低位，就像英雄从伟大中跌落一样。在确定他的三个关键时刻时，亚里士多德做了所有叙事学家都会做的事情，即查看许多不同的故事（在他的案例中是希腊舞台悲剧），询问它们有哪些共同点。这类似于物理学家看待不同形式的物质（山脉、湖泊、火山等）并意识到它们都是由相同的有限化学元素组成的方式。在这两种情况下，技能都在于受过训练的能力，可以看到差异背后的相似性和一致性。

The hamartia means a ‘sin’ or ‘fault’ (which in tragic drama is often the product of the fatal character-defect which came to be known as the ‘tragic flaw’). The anagnorisis means ‘recognition’ or ‘realisation’, this being a moment in the narrative when the truth of the situation is recognised by the protagonist – often it’s a moment of self-recognition. The peripeteia means a ‘turn-round’ or a ‘reversal’ of fortune. In classical tragedy this is usually a fall from high to low estate, as the hero falls from greatness. In identifying his three key moments, Aristotle did what all narratologists do, which is to look at a number of different stories (Greek stage tragedies in his case) asking what elements they have in common. This is similar to the way a physicist would look at different forms of matter (mountains, lakes, volcanoes, etc.) and realise that they are all made from the same finite set of chemical elements. In both cases the skill lies in the trained ability to see the similarities and consistencies which underlie difference.

我们甚至可以在最基本的叙述材料中看到这些亚里士多德元素的痕迹，例如对面的卡通图，这是一个非常简单的完整故事，取自一包“Brekkies”（英国猫粮品牌）。我要强调的是，亚里士多德认为所有三个元素都以“主角”（戏剧的“英雄”或“女主人公”）为中心，但接下来我将这三个元素分配给故事中涉及的人物，部分原因是我相信，在使用文学理论时，我们不必盲目地遵循创作者的指示，部分原因是期待弗拉基米尔·普罗普 (Vladimir Propp) 的方法，我将考虑下一个人物。因此，'hamartia'（或错误）是猫在桌布上留下脏爪印，这种行为会带来责备和谴责（'哦，鲍勃，不要'），并涉及'peripeteia'，或失宠，使猫失宠。坠落的标志是猫从桌子上真正下降到地板上。但是在喝茶的时候，来访的阿姨高兴地发现桌上的布是她送给侄女的礼物。当然，她不知道这件布料不是她侄女的首选，但我们作为整个事件序列的见证人，从我们的特权概览位置知道这一点。事实上，我们可以说讲故事的关键不是传授，而是隐瞒信息——读者通常知道人物不知道的事情，反之亦然，而叙述者则对两者隐瞒。故事的核心机制是延迟，具体来说，延迟传递这些信息——维多利亚时代的小说家威尔基柯林斯有一句名言，写一部成功小说的公式是“让他们笑，让他们哭——让他们等待”。

We can see traces of these Aristotelian elements in even the most rudimentary of narrative material, such as the cartoon diagram opposite, which is a very simple complete story, taken from a packet of ‘Brekkies’ (a British brand of cat food). Aristotle, I should emphasise, saw all three elements as centred on the ‘protagonist’ (the ‘hero’ or ‘heroine’ of the drama), but in what follows I distribute the three elements amongst the figures involved in the story, partly because I believe that in using literary theory we don’t have to follow the maker’s instructions slavishly, and partly in anticipation of the methods of Vladimir Propp, the next figure I will consider. So, the ‘hamartia’ (or fault) is the cat’s leaving dirty paw-prints over the table-cloth, an act which brings reproof and condemnation (‘Oh, Bob, don’t’), and involves a ‘peripeteia’, or fall from grace, so that the cat is out of favour. The fall is marked by the cat’s literal descent from the table to the floor. But during the tea, the visiting aunt notices with pleasure that the cloth now on the table is the one she gave her niece as a present. Of course, she doesn’t know that this cloth was not her niece’s first choice, but we know this from our privileged overview position as witnesses of the whole sequence of events. Indeed, we might say that the key to story-telling is not the imparting, but the withholding of information – readers often know things that characters don’t, and vice-versa, and narrators keep things back from both. The central mechanism in stories is delay, to be specific, delay in imparting this information – the Victorian novelist Wilkie Collins famously said that the formula for writing a successful novel is ‘Make them laugh, make them cry – make them wait’.

卡通中的“无意识”是猫主人的内疚（幕后）意识到她错过了在客人来喝茶时使用客人的礼物来表达感激和适当感受的机会。这带来了进一步的 peripeteia，这是猫的青睐的恢复，不是从高到低的下降，而是从低到高的恢复。恢复的标志是思想泡泡（“谢谢，鲍勃”），猫自我满足的傻笑表情，以及它现在直立到侄女膝上的有利位置。

The ‘anagnorisis’ in the cartoon is the cat-owner’s guilty (offstage) realisation that she has missed an opportunity to show gratitude and proper feeling by using the guest’s present when the guest comes to tea. This brings about a further peripeteia, which is the restoration of the cat to favour, not a fall from high to low, but a restoration from low to high. The restoration is marked by the thought bubble (‘Thanks, Bob’), by the cat’s expression of smirking self-satisfaction, and by its literal raising up now to the favoured position on the niece’s lap.

亚里士多德的三个类别本质上与故事的潜在主题和道德目的有关，非常关乎所谓的“深层内容”，因为在重要的意义上，它们都涉及“内部事件”（道德缺陷，对其存在的认识，以及后果它的存在）。这三者的存在很容易在许多叙述中辨别出来，充当其道德影响的生成力。它们通常是通灵的“原料”或“配料”，经过“烹制”和转化以构成特定的叙事“菜肴”、特定的“情节”。尽管如此，在实践中，故事中的情节可能有很多种，为了描述这些，我们似乎需要一种不同于亚里士多德的体系，它会给我们更多不同的可能行动，并且更接近于叙事表面，可以这么说。我们的三个历史标志人物中的下一个提供了类似的东西。

Aristotle’s three categories are essentially to do with the underlying themes and moral purposes of stories, being very much about what might be called ‘deep content’, since in an important sense they all concern ‘inner events’ (a moral defect, the recognition of its existence, and the consequences of its existence). The presence of these three is easy to discern beneath many narratives, acting as the generative force of their moral impact. They are often the psychic ‘raw materials’ or ‘ingredients’ which are ‘cooked’ and transformed to make up a specific narrative ‘dish’, a specific ‘plot’. All the same, in practice a great variety of plots is possible in stories, and to describe these we seem to need a different kind of system to Aristotle’s, one which would give us a greater variety of possible actions and which would operate closer to the narrative surface, so to speak. Something like this was provided by the next of our three historical-marker figures.

弗拉基米尔·普罗普

Vladimir Propp

正如我们所预料的那样，后来的叙事学家已经开发出范围更广的常量列表和曲目，这些常量可以在几乎无限变化的叙事表面下被发现。第二个重要人物是弗拉基米尔·普罗普（Vladimir Propp，1895-1970 年），一位“俄罗斯形式主义”评论家，他研究俄罗斯民间故事，确定这些故事中反复出现的结构和情况，并将他的发现发表在他的著作《民间故事的形态学》中，1928 年首次在俄罗斯出版。正如普罗普在前言中所说，“形态学”一词的意思是“对形式的研究”，所以这本书是关于这些故事的结构和情节形成的，书中没有任何内容涉及它们历史或社会意义。到 1928 年，苏联的潮流已经转向反对这种“形式主义”研究，这本书从人们的视线中消失，直到 1950 年代，结构主义者，尤其是人类学家克劳德·列维-施特劳斯 (Claude Lévi-Strauss) 重新发现了它，他在他自己的神话研究中使用了普罗普的思想。The Morphology于 1958 年首次以英文出版（由德克萨斯大学出版社出版），由 Laurence Scott 翻译，1968 年再版。

As we would expect, then, later narratologists have developed more wide-ranging lists and repertoires of the constants which can be detected beneath the almost infinitely varied surface of narratives. A second important figure is Vladimir Propp (1895–1970), a ‘Russian Formalist’ critic who worked on Russian folk tales, identifying recurrent structures and situations in such tales, and publishing his findings in his book The Morphology of the Folktale, first published in Russia in 1928. As Propp says in the Foreword, the word ‘morphology’ means ‘the study of forms’, so the book is about the structures and plot formations of these tales, and there is nothing in the book about their history or social significance. Already, by 1928, the tide in Soviet Russia was turning against this kind of ‘Formalist’ study, and the book disappeared from view until the 1950s, when it was re-discovered by the structuralists, especially the anthropologist Claude Lévi-Strauss, who used Propp’s ideas in his own studies of myth. The Morphology was first published in English in 1958 (by the University of Texas Press), translated by Laurence Scott, with a second edition in 1968.

普罗普的工作基于对他的一百个故事“语料库”的研究，他得出结论，所有这些故事都是通过从三十一个“功能”（即可能的行动）的基本曲目中选择项目来构建的。没有一个故事包含他列表中的所有项目，但都是通过从中选择项目来构建。书中给出的“功能”的完整列表如下：

Propp’s work is based on a study of his ‘corpus’ of a hundred tales, and he concluded that all these tales are constructed by selecting items from a basic repertoire of thirty-one ‘functions’ (that is, possible actions). No tale contains all the items in his list, but all are constructed by selecting items from it. The complete list of ‘functions’ given in the book is as follows:

1. 家庭成员之一离家出走。

1. One of the members of a family absents himself from home.

2. 对英雄的禁令[即禁令]。

2. An interdiction [that is, a prohibition] is addressed to the hero.

三、违反禁制令。

3. The interdiction is violated.

4. 恶棍企图侦察。

4. The villain makes an attempt at reconnaissance.

5. 恶棍收到关于他的受害者的信息。

5. The villain receives information about his victim.

6. 恶棍试图欺骗受害者以占有他或他的财物。

6. The villain attempts to deceive his victim in order to take possession of him or his belongings.

7. 受害者屈服于欺骗，从而不知不觉地帮助了他的敌人。

7. The victim submits to deception and thereby unwittingly helps his enemy.

8. 恶棍对家庭成员造成伤害或伤害/或，8a。一个家庭的成员要么缺少某样东西，要么渴望拥有某样东西。

8. The villain causes harm or injury to a member of a family/or, 8a. One member of a family either lacks something or desires to have something.

9.不幸或缺乏被告知；向英雄提出请求或命令；他被允许离开或被派遣。

9. Misfortune or lack is made known; the hero is approached with a request or command; he is allowed to go or he is dispatched.

10. 探索者[即“探索者”模式中的英雄]同意或决定反击。

10. The seeker [that is, the hero in ‘questor’ mode] agrees to or decides upon counteraction.

11、英雄离家。

11. The hero leaves home.

12. 主人公受到考验、审问、攻击等，为他接受魔法使者或助手做准备。

12. The hero is tested, interrogated, attacked, etc., which prepares the way for his receiving either a magical agent or helper.

13.英雄对未来捐赠者的行为做出反应。

13. The hero reacts to the actions of the future donor.

14.主人公获得魔法使者[即物品、动物等]的使用权。

14. The hero acquires the use of a magical agent [that is, an object, an animal, etc.].

15.主人公被转移、交付或引至搜查对象的下落。

15. The hero is transferred, delivered, or led to the whereabouts of an object of search.

16、英雄与反派直接交手。

16. The hero and the villain join in direct combat.

17.英雄是烙印。

17. The hero is branded.

18.小人败了。

18. The villain is defeated.

19. 最初的不幸或缺乏被清算。

19. The initial misfortune or lack is liquidated.

20、英雄归来。

20. The hero returns.

21、英雄被追杀。

21. The hero is pursued.

22.从追击中解救英雄。

22. Rescue of the hero from pursuit.

23. 未被认出的英雄回到家乡或另一个国家。

23. The hero, unrecognised, arrives home or in another country.

24. 假英雄提出毫无根据的主张。

24. A false hero presents unfounded claims.

25、向主人公提出了一项艰巨的任务。

25. A difficult task is proposed to the hero.

26. 任务完成。

26. The task is resolved.

27、英雄是公认的。

27. The hero is recognised.

28.假英雄或假小人被揭穿。

28. The false hero or villain is exposed.

29.英雄焕然一新。

29. The hero is given a new appearance.

30、小人受罚。

30. The villain is punished.

31、男主成亲登基。

31. The hero is married and ascends the throne.

这些是普罗普分析的故事集的基本组成部分。要制作任何给定的个人故事的情节，您可以将此列表中的一些项目放在一起。当然，没有一个故事具备全部三十一个功能；每个都有一个选择其中，此外，函数总是按列出的顺序出现：例如，一个故事可能由函数 5、7、14、18、30 和 31 组成：因此​​，恶棍收到有关英雄/受害者的信息 (5) , 并欺骗他 (7), 但英雄得到了具有神奇力量的动物的帮助 (14), 打败了恶棍 (18), 惩罚了他 (30), 然后结婚并成为国王 (31)。但是任何故事都不能有一个公式，其中的组成部分编号是乱序的，比如说，30 在 18 之前，因为（在这个例子中）恶棍在被打败之前不能受到惩罚。功能的顺序是固定的，部分原因是，正如普罗普所说，事件往往有一个适当的顺序（目击者可能不同意他们看到的东西，但通常不会按照他们看到它的顺序 - 房子不能在它之前被盗已被闯入）。p. 21 ) – 回到之前使用的比喻，它们是不同的菜肴，都是用相同范围的食材烹制而成。

These are the basic building blocks of the collection of tales analysed by Propp. To make the plot of any given individual tale, you put together a selection of items from this list. No single tale has all thirty-one functions, of course; each one has a selection of them, and furthermore, the functions always occur in the order listed: for example, a tale may consist of functions 5, 7, 14, 18, 30 and 31: thus, the villain receives information about the hero/victim (5), and deceives him (7), but the hero receives help from an animal with magical powers (14), defeats the villain (18), has him punished (30), then marries and becomes king (31). But no tale could have a formula in which the component numbers are out of sequence, say, with 30 coming before 18, for (in this instance) the villain cannot be punished before he has been defeated. The order of the functions is fixed, partly because, as Propp says, events tend to have a due order (witnesses may disagree on what they saw, but not usually on the order in which they saw it – a house cannot be burgled before it has been broken into). The method of analysis of the tales aims to show that beneath their ‘amazing multiformity’ lies a ‘no less striking uniformity’ (p. 21) – to revert to the metaphor used earlier, they are different dishes all cooked from the same range of ingredients.

显然，我们在这里谈论的故事比亚里士多德的情况更（字面上）“肤浅”，但由于可能的表面事件的多样性大于潜在动机的多样性，普罗普有更多的变量在起作用比亚里士多德。尽管如此，即使对基本函数列表进行非常简短的研究，普罗普系统提出的一些问题也会很明显：​​例如，6 和 7 是关于恶棍欺骗受害者/英雄的两个函数，但显然，只涉及一种行为——欺骗者欺骗，被欺骗者被欺骗，因为欺骗行为需要两方参与。那么，从不同的角度来看，这两个事件实际上是同一事件。同样，在 10 和 11 中，实际上并没有两个不同的事件，因为在 10 中，主人公决定做某事，而在 11 中，他又去做了。1个

Clearly, we are talking here about stories viewed in a more (literally) ‘superficial’ way than was the case with Aristotle, but since the variety of possible surface events is greater than that of the possible underlying motives, Propp has more variables in play than Aristotle. All the same, some of the problems thrown up by Propp’s system will be evident after even a very brief study of the basic list of functions: 6 and 7, for instance, are two functions concerning deception of the victim/hero by the villain, but clearly, only one action is involved – the deceiver deceives and the deceived is deceived, for an act of deception requires two parties. These two events, then, are really the same event looked at from different points of view. Likewise, in 10 and 11, there are not really two distinct events, since in 10 the hero decides to do something, and in 11 he does it.1

对 31 个函数及其子变体的描述占据了本书迄今为止最长的一章，将近 50 页，占了正文的一半。相比之下，故事中可能的角色类型描述得更简单（在第六章的四页中），普罗普的角色主要只是围绕故事分配功能的机制。为此，他注意到这 31 个功能似乎可以自然地分组到“领域”中（例如，追捕、捕获和惩罚具有自然分组）。因此，将七个“行动领域”视为角色而不是角色更有意义，因为这反映了性格对行动的从属关系（这种从属关系也是亚里士多德叙事学的一个特征，因为亚里士多德说，在叙事中，性格只在行动中表现出来）。Propp 的七个“行动领域”是：

The description of the thirty-one functions, and their sub-variants, takes up by far the longest chapter in the book, nearly fifty pages, which is getting on for half the main text. By contrast, the possible character types in the tales are much more briefly described (in the four pages of chapter six), the characters being for Propp mainly just the mechanism for distributing the functions around the story. To this end, he notes that the thirty-one functions seem to group naturally into ‘spheres’ (for example, pursuit, capture, and punishment have a natural grouping). Hence, it makes more sense to see the seven ‘spheres of action’ as roles rather than characters, as this reflects the subordination of character to action (a subordination which is also a feature of Aristotle’s narratology, for Aristotle says that in narrative character is only expressed in action). Propp’s seven ‘spheres of action’ are:

1.恶棍

1. The villain

2.供体（提供者）

2. The donor (provider)

3.帮手

3. The helper

4.公主（被追捧的人）和她的父亲

4. The princess (a sought-for-person) and her father

5.调度员

5. The dispatcher

6.英雄（寻求者或受害者）

6. The hero (seeker or victim)

7.假英雄

7. The false hero

使用三十一个“功能”和七个“作用范围”的列表，我们可以在整个俄罗斯语料库中生成任何单个民间故事的情节，就像用英语的语法、句法和词汇武装一样（语言，在索绪尔的术语中）我们可以生成任何可能的英语话语（假释）。当然，民间故事相对简单，但是罗伯特·斯科尔斯在他的著作《文学结构主义》（耶鲁大学出版社，1974 年）中提醒我们，这样的图式的多功能性大大增加了，即'在任何给定的故事中，一个角色可能扮演不止一个这样的角色（例如，恶棍也可能是假英雄，捐赠者也可能是调度员，等等）；或者一个角色可以使用多个角色（例如多个恶棍）；但这些都是这种叙事所需要的角色，它们是许多小说的基础，在其他方面与童话故事相去甚远”（第 65 页）). 然后，这种潜在的重复打开了用于分析相对简单材料的普罗普方法，并开始暗示构成心理现实主义小说基础的特征和动机的复杂性。在现实主义小说中，角色对动作的从属关系是颠倒的，角色不能简单地划分为“英雄”和“反派”。至高无上的心理小说家亨利·詹姆斯曾说过，他写的不是善与恶，而是“善与恶”。因此，在 Henry James 的故事中，一个想成为帮助者的人可能无意中成了阻碍者，或者甚至不确定他们“真正”是谁。2个因此，普罗普的方法似乎暗示了来自更基本的叙事材料的简单原型可以为复杂的现实主义小说提供阴暗的深层基础的方式——例如，灰姑娘原型（在世界各地的文化中以某种形式发现的故事）的方式在曼斯菲尔德公园和简爱等小说之下。然而，普罗普的系统所缺乏的是叙事的呈现方式，例如观点或风格。这些是我们第三个“标记”数字所关注的领域，需要更详细地处理它们。
Using the list of thirty-one ‘functions’ and the seven ‘spheres of action’, we can generate the plot of any individual folk tale in the entire Russian corpus, just as, armed with the grammar, syntax, and vocabulary of English (the langue, in Saussure’s terms) we can generate any possible utterance in English (the parole). Folk tales are relatively simple, of course, but the versatility of a schema like this is much increased by what Robert Scholes reminds us of in his book Structuralism in Literature (Yale University Press, 1974), that ‘One character may play more than one of these roles in any given tale (e.g. the villain may also be the false hero, the donor may also be the dispatcher, etc.); or one role may employ several characters (multiple villains, for instance); but these are all the roles that this sort of narrative requires, and they are basic to much fiction which is far removed from fairy tales in other respects’ (p. 65). This potential duplication, then, opens up the Proppian methods used to analyse relatively simple material, and begins to hint at the complexities of characterisation and motivation which form the basis of psychological, realist fiction. In realist fiction, the subordination of character to action is reversed, and roles cannot be simply demarcated as ‘hero’ and ‘villain’. Henry James, the supreme psychological novelist, once said that he wrote not about good and evil, but about ‘good-and-evil’. Hence, in a Henry James story, a would-be helper may inadvertently be a hinderer, or may even be unsure which they ‘truly’ are.2 So the Proppian approach seems to hint at the way simple archetypes from much more basic narrative material can provide the shadowy deep foundations of complex realist fictions – the way, for instance, the Cinderella archetype (a tale found in some form in cultures worldwide) lies beneath novels like Mansfield Park and Jane Eyre. However, what Propp’s system lacks is anything about the way the narrative is presented, such as the viewpoint or the style. These are the areas focused upon by the third of our ‘marker’ figures, and they need to be treated in a little more detail.

热拉尔热内特

Gérard Genette

自罗兰·巴特 (Roland Barthes) 以来最杰出的叙事学家之一是热拉尔·热内特 (Gérard Genette)，他的作品关注的焦点不是故事本身，可以这么说，而是讲述故事的方式，也就是说，讲述故事本身的过程。如果我们考虑 Genette 讨论的六个特定领域（在他的书Narrative Discourse， Basil Blackwell，1972 年），这种区别的含义就会变得很明显。下面我问六关于叙述行为的基本问题，并在 Genette 确定的每种可能性范围下进行概述，并附上我自己的一些补充类别。

One of the most prominent narratologists since Roland Barthes has been Gérard Genette, whose work has as its focus, not the tale itself, so to speak, but how it is told, which is to say, the process of telling itself. What is meant by this distinction will become apparent if we consider six particular areas which Genette discusses (in his book Narrative Discourse, Basil Blackwell, 1972). In what follows I ask six basic questions about the act of narration, and sketch under each the range of possibilities identified by Genette, with some supplementary categories of my own.

1. 基本的叙事方式是“拟态”还是“剧情”？热内特在第四章

讨论了这个问题， '情绪'。“模仿”的意思是“展示”或“戏剧化”。以模仿方式呈现的叙事部分被“戏剧化”，也就是说它们以“风景”的方式呈现，具有特定的设置，并使用包含直接对话的对话。“模仿”是“慢述”，其中所做的和所说的都是为读者“上演”的，从而产生我们正在为自己“看到”和“听到”事物的错觉。相比之下，“diegesis”的意思是“讲述”或“关联”。以这种方式呈现的叙述部分以更“快速”或“全景”或“总结”的方式给出。目的是尽可能有效地为我们提供必要的或相关的信息，而不是试图制造事件正在我们眼前发生的错觉——解说员只是说发生了什么，而不是试图在它发生时展示它。3个

1. Is the basic narrative mode ‘mimetic’ or ‘diegetic’?

Genette discusses this matter in Chapter four, ‘Mood’. ‘Mimesis’ means ‘showing’ or ‘dramatising’. The parts of a narrative which are presented in a mimetic manner are ‘dramatised’, which is to say that they are represented in a ‘scenic’ way, with a specified setting, and making use of dialogue which contains direct speech. ‘Mimesis’ is ‘slow telling’, in which what is done and said is ‘staged’ for the reader, creating the illusion that we are ‘seeing’ and ‘hearing’ things for ourselves. By contrast, ‘diegesis’ means ‘telling’ or ‘relating’. The parts of a narrative which are presented in this way are given in a more ‘rapid’ or ‘panoramic’ or ‘summarising’ way. The aim is to give us essential or linking information as efficiently as possible, without trying to create the illusion that the events are taking place before our eyes – the narrator just says what happens, without trying to show it as it happens.3

当然，在实践中，出于战略原因，作家会串联使用这两种模式，从模仿到叙事，然后再返回。这部分是因为一部完全模仿的小说往往会无限长，而一部完全叙事的小说几乎不会超过几页，读起来就像情节摘要。当然，也有几乎完全以模仿模式写成的“单一场景”短篇小说——例如欧内斯特·海明威的许多短篇小说，如“山丘如白象”，这是对一对美国夫妇的“单镜头”描述在偏远的西班牙火车站等火车。他们在等待时的想法、言语和行为揭示了他们关系中的危机。我们看到他们做什么，听到他们说什么，仅此而已。4个但是较长的小说结构通常需要混合模仿和叙事，以下简短的段落说明了两种模式之间的“滑行”：

In practice, of course, writers use the two modes in tandem, moving from mimetic to diegetic, and back again, for strategic reasons. This is partly because an entirely mimetic novel would tend to be infinitely long, and an entirely diegetic one could hardly be more than a couple of pages, and would read like a plot summary. Of course, there are ‘single-scene’ short stories which are written almost entirely in mimetic mode – for example, many by Ernest Hemingway, such as ‘Hills like White Elephants’, which is a ‘single take’ account of an American couple waiting for a train at a remote Spanish railway station. Their thoughts, words, and actions as they wait reveal the crisis in their relationship. We see what they do and hear what they say, and that is all.4 But the longer structure of a novel usually requires a blending of the mimetic and the diegetic, and the following brief passage illustrates the ‘glide’ between the two modes:

五年来，马里奥每天早上都走同一条路去上班，但他再也没有见过塞尔玛。然后一天早上，当他从地铁站出来并开始沿着查令十字路走时，发生了一件非常奇怪的事情。那是一个阳光灿烂的日子，而且……
For five years Mario took the same route to work every morning, but he never saw Thelma again. Then one morning something very strange happened as he came out of the tube station and began to walk up Charing Cross Road. It was a bright, sunny day, and …

第一句话是故事情节——对一长串事件的快速总结，但所有事件都发生在“幕后”，就像它一样。显然，如果没有这种段落，就不可能有效地推进情节。段落的其余部分是模仿。“快进”之后，作者在下一个关键“场景”再次放慢速度，开始为我们构建它，告诉我们当天的天气和确切位置，让我们在自己的脑海中“看到”场景心灵的眼睛。Mimesis 和 diegesis 彼此需要，并且经常一起工作，因此很难准确辨别它们之间的连接，但很容易看出它们作为叙事的基石是多么重要。

The first sentence is diegesis – a rapid summary of a long sequence of events, but all taking place ‘off-stage’, as it were. Clearly, it would be impossible to move a plot along efficiently without passages of this kind. The remainder of the passage is mimesis. Having ‘fast-forwarded’, the writer slows down again at the next crucial ‘scene’ and begins to construct it for us, telling us about the weather that day, and the exact location, so that we ‘see’ the scene in our mind’s eye. Mimesis and diegesis need each other, and often work together so that the join between them can be difficult to discern exactly, but it is easy to see how fundamental they are as the building blocks of narrative.

2. 叙述是如何聚焦的？聚焦（在Narrative Discourse的第 189 – 94 页中

讨论）表示“观点”或“视角”，即讲述故事的观点。有很多可能性：例如，在“外部”聚焦中，视角在所描绘的角色之外，因此我们只被告知外部或可观察到的事情——也就是说，角色所说和所做的，这些是你会听到的并亲自看看您是否在所描述的场景中。相反，“内部聚焦”，重点是角色的想法和感受，这些是即使您在场也无法访问的东西。因此，“Thelma stand up and called out to Mario”这句话是对这一刻的外部聚焦表示，因为如果这些事情发生时你在场，你会看到和听到这些事情。相比之下，考虑一下“塞尔玛突然感到焦虑，因为马里奥不会去看她，会在查令十字路的另一边不知不觉地走过”。这是她的内部集中表现；它揭示了她未说出口的想法和感受，即使你站在旁边也可能完全没有意识到给她。如果整个故事的讲述主要是在塞尔玛身上的这种内部聚焦，那么她可以被称为故事的“聚焦者”（或“反射者”，用另一种叙事学术语来说）。尽管她没有以第一人称讲述自己的故事，但读者可以从她的“观点”了解事件——因此，例如，伊丽莎白·班纳特 (Elizabeth Bennet) 是《傲慢与偏见》的聚焦者（或反映者）。有时，一位小说家会自由地进入不止一个人物的思想和情感，就好像了解他们所有人的思想和感受一样。这种叙事可以说是“零聚焦”；正如杰拉尔德·普林斯 (Gerald Prince) 在他的著作中优雅地指出的那样，“当没有系统的概念或感知约束支配可能呈现的内容时”就会发生这种情况叙事学词典（内布拉斯加大学出版社，1987 年）。普林斯说，零聚焦是“传统”或“经典”叙事的特征。它更熟悉的名字是“无所不知的叙述”。

2. How is the narrative focalised?

Focalisation (discussed in pages 189–94 of Narrative Discourse) means ‘viewpoint’ or ‘perspective’, which is to say the point-of-view from which the story is told. There are many possibilities: for example, in ‘external’ focalisation the viewpoint is outside the character depicted, so that we are told only things which are external or observable – that is, what the characters say and do, these being things you would hear and see for yourself if you were present at the scene depicted. In the opposite, ‘internal focalisation’, the focus is on what the characters think and feel, these being things which would be inaccessible to you even if you had been present. Thus, the sentence ‘Thelma stood up and called out to Mario’ is an externally focalised representation of this moment, for you would see and hear these things if you were present when they happened. By contrast, consider the sentence ‘Thelma suddenly felt anxious that Mario was not going to see her and would walk by oblivious on the other side of Charing Cross Road.’ This is an internally focalised representation of her; it reveals her unspoken thoughts and feelings, which you could be completely unaware of even if you were standing next to her. If the story is told throughout mainly with this internal focalisation on Thelma, then she can be called the ‘focaliser’ of the tale (or the ‘reflector’, in another tradition of narratological terms). Though she is not telling her own tale in the first person, readers are being given the events from her ‘point-of-view’ – thus, for instance, Elizabeth Bennet is the focaliser (or reflector) of Pride and Prejudice. Sometimes a novelist will freely enter the minds and emotions of more than one of the characters, as if privy to the thoughts and feelings of all of them. This kind of narrative can be said to have ‘zero focalisation’; this occurs ‘when no systematic conceptual or perceptual constraint governs what may be presented’, as Gerald Prince elegantly puts it in his A Dictionary of Narratology (University of Nebraska Press, 1987). Prince says that zero focalisation is characteristic of ‘traditional’ or ‘classical’ narration. Its more familiar name is ‘omniscient narration’.

3. 谁在讲故事？

当然，作者是，但不一定是他或她自己的声音或角色。一种叙述者（通常与零焦点叙述相伴的那种）根本没有被识别为具有名字和个人历史的独特角色，而仍然只是一种声音或一种语气，我们可以将其简单地注册为智能，记录意识，一种纯粹的“讲述媒介”，力求中立和透明。这样的叙述者可能被称为“隐蔽的”、“隐蔽的”、“非侵入性的”或“非戏剧化的”。我们可能会不耐烦地坚持认为这只是作者直接对我们说话，但值得记住的是，这在任何意义上都不是作者的“真实”声音，因为他或她只使用这种精确的语气、节奏、细节程度、等等，在叙述小说作品时。如果我们在聚会或酒吧遇到作者，我们将无法忍受这种叙事风格超过几分钟。因此，将这种无实体的叙述者视为“作者角色”而不是作者本人是有道理的。

3. Who is telling the story?

Of course, the author is, but not necessarily in his or her own voice or persona. One kind of narrator (the kind that often goes with a zero-focalised narrative) is not identified at all as a distinct character with a name and a personal history, and remains just a voice or a tone, which we may register simply as an intelligent, recording consciousness, a mere ‘telling medium’ which strives for neutrality and transparency. Such narrators may be called ‘covert’, ‘effaced’, ‘non-intrusive’, or ‘non-dramatised’. We may impatiently insist that it is simply the author speaking to us directly, but it is worth remembering that this is not in any sense the author’s ‘true’ voice, since he or she only uses this precise tone, pace, degree of detail, and so on, when narrating a work of fiction. If we met the author at a party or in a bar we wouldn’t be able to tolerate this narrative style for more than a couple of minutes. Hence, it makes sense to think of this kind of disembodied narrator as an ‘authorial persona’, rather than as the author in person.

另一种叙述者是那种被认为是独特的、有名字的人物，具有个人历史、性别、社会阶级地位、不同的好恶等等。这些叙述者亲眼目睹、了解甚至参与了这些事件他们告诉。他们可以被称为“公开的”或“戏剧化的”或“侵入性的”叙述者，例如艾米莉·勃朗特的《呼啸山庄》中的洛克伍德先生、约瑟夫·康拉德的《黑暗之心》中的马洛和斯科特·菲茨杰拉德的《了不起的盖茨比》中的尼克·卡拉威。这些戏剧化的叙述者可以有多种类型：“异类叙事”叙述者不是他或她所讲述的故事中的角色，而是故事的局外人，例如洛克伍德先生（“异类叙事”大致是指“其他”讲述'，因为被讲述的故事是别人的故事）。相比之下，“同剧式”叙述者“在他讲述的故事中作为一个角色出现”（热内特，第 245 页）) – 例如《简·爱》('homodiegetic' 的意思大致是'相同的讲述'，因为讲述的故事是叙述者自己的故事)。请注意，第一人称叙述者可能是异故事的或同故事的，因为他们可能在讲述别人的故事，而不是他们自己的故事。无所不知的叙述者必然是异故事的。上述问题在 Genette 的第五章“声音”的小标题“人”下进行了讨论。

The other kind of narrator is the kind who is identified as a distinct, named character, with a personal history, gender, a social-class position, distinct likes and dislikes, and so on. These narrators have witnessed, or learned about, or even participated in the events they tell. They can be called ‘overt’ or ‘dramatised’ or ‘intrusive’ narrators, examples being such tellers as Mr Lockwood in Emily Brontë’s Wuthering Heights, Marlow in Joseph Conrad’s Heart of Darkness, and Nick Carraway in Scott Fitzgerald’s The Great Gatsby. These dramatised narrators can be of various kinds: the ‘heterodiegetic’ narrator is one who is not a character in the story he or she narrates, but an outsider to it, as Mr Lockwood is, for example (‘heterodiegetic’ means roughly ‘other telling’, since the story being told is that of somebody else). By contrast, the ‘homodiegetic’ narrator ‘is present as a character in the story he tells’ (Genette, p. 245) – as Jane Eyre is, for instance (‘homodiegetic’ means roughly ‘same telling’, since the story being told is the narrator’s own). Notice that first person narrators may be either heterodiegetic or homodiegetic, since they may be telling someone else’s story, rather than their own. Omniscient narrators are necessarily heterodiegetic. The above concerns are discussed in Genette’s chapter five, ‘Voice’, under the sub-heading ‘Person’.

4.故事中时间是如何处理的？

叙述通常包含前后引用，因此讲述的顺序与发生的顺序不一致。有时故事会“闪回”以讲述过去发生的事件，而这部分叙事可以称为“analeptic”（来自“analepsis”，字面意思是“回溯”）。同样，叙事可能会“向前闪现”以叙述、提及或预测稍后发生的事件：叙事的这些部分可以称为“前瞻性”（来自“prolepsis”，字面意思是“前瞻性” ). 例如，在 DH Lawrence 的短篇小说“普鲁士军官”中，一瓶酒在上菜时打翻了，这预示或暗示了将结束故事的流血事件。查尔斯狄更斯在开始时也有类似的期待时刻两城记，一桶红酒洒在大街上，预示着革命将导致的流血事件。这些是“proleptic”细节，它们以一种略微粗略的方式表明了 analepsis 和 prolepsis 在故事中建立和突出“主题”方面通常是多么重要。通常情况下，作家在讲故事时会策略性地使用 analepsis 和 prolepsis，因为开头很少是最好的开始——故事往往从中间开始（在 medias res 中，正如古典时代的理论家所说），伴随着 analeps材料勾勒出之前发生的事情，以及暗示结果会是什么的预示装置，从而吸引读者并产生基本的叙事动力。这些问题在 Genette 的第一章“秩序”的副标题“叙事时间”下进行了讨论。

4. How is time handled in the story?

Narratives often contain references back and references forward, so that the order of telling does not correspond to the order of happening. Sometimes the story will ‘flash back’ to relate an event which happened in the past, and such parts of the narrative can be called ‘analeptic’ (from ‘analepsis’, which literally means a ‘back-take’). Likewise, the narrative may ‘flash forward’ to narrate, or refer to, or anticipate an event which happens later: such parts of the narrative can be called ‘proleptic’ (from ‘prolepsis’, which literally means a ‘fore-take’). For instance, in D. H. Lawrence’s short story ‘The Prussian Officer’ a bottle of wine is spilt as a meal is served, and this gestures towards or hints at the bloodshed which will end the tale. Charles Dickens has a similar anticipating moment at the start of A Tale of Two Cities, when a barrel of red wine spilt in the street anticipates the bloodshed which will be caused by the revolution. These are ‘proleptic’ details, and they indicate in a slightly crude way how analepsis and prolepsis are often important in establishing and foregrounding ‘themes’ in a story. Typically, writers make strategic use of both analepsis and prolepsis in telling a story, for the beginning is seldom the best place to begin – stories tend to begin in the middle (in medias res, as the theorists of classical times said), with analeptic material sketching out what went before, and proleptic devices hinting at what the outcome will be, and thereby engaging the reader and generating the basic narrative momentum. These matters are discussed in Genette’s first chapter, ‘Order’, under the sub-heading ‘Narrative time’.

5. 故事是如何“包装”的？

故事并不总是“直接”呈现的。作家经常使用“框架叙述”（也称为“主要叙述”），其中包含“嵌入式叙述”（也称为“次要叙述”）。例如，亨利·詹姆斯 (Henry James) 的《拧紧螺丝》( The Turn of the Screw ) 中的主要故事嵌入了一个框架叙事，即圣诞节期间一群人围坐在乡间别墅的火炉旁讲鬼故事。在这种情况下，一位客人讲述的故事之一构成了詹姆斯故事的主旨。请注意，这里的“主要叙述”实际上只是指最先出现的叙述，而不是主要叙述叙述，实际上通常不是。“次要叙事”是排在第二位并嵌入到主要叙事中的叙事。次要叙述通常是主要故事。因此，在詹姆斯的故事中，我们首先听到了为乡间别墅圣诞节而聚集的一群人，然后我们听到了（在一个更长的叙述中）在那些情况下讲述的故事。同样，康拉德的《黑暗之心》中的主要故事嵌入了一群前深海水手在等待潮汐转变时讲述“纱线”的框架叙事。Genette 将嵌入的叙事称为“元叙事”（他说，“元叙事是叙事中的叙事”，脚注 41，第 228 页) – 因此，例如，乔叟的《坎特伯雷故事集》中的个别故事，嵌入到坎特伯雷朝圣的框架叙事中，是元叙事，即故事中的故事。

5. How is the story ‘packaged’?

Stories are not always presented ‘straight’. Often writers make use of ‘frame narratives’ (also called ‘primary narratives’), which contain within them ‘embedded narratives’ (also called ‘secondary narratives’). For instance, the main story in Henry James’s The Turn of the Screw is embedded within a frame narrative of a group of people telling ghost stories round the fire in a country house at Christmas. One of the stories told by one of the guests in these circumstances is the one which forms the substance of James’s tale. Notice that here ‘primary narrative’ really just means the narrative which comes first, rather than the main narrative, which in fact it usually isn’t. The ‘secondary narrative’ is the one which comes second and is embedded into the primary narrative. The secondary narrative is usually the main story. Thus, in James’s tale, we first of all hear about the group assembled for the country-house Christmas, then we hear (in a far longer narrative) the story which was told in those circumstances. Likewise, the main story in Conrad’s Heart of Darkness is embedded within the frame narrative of a group of former deep-sea sailors telling ‘yarns’ as they wait for the tide to turn. Genette calls the embedded narratives ‘meta-narratives’ (he says, ‘the meta-narrative is a narrative within the narrative’, footnote 41, p. 228) – so, for instance, the individual tales of Chaucer’s The Canterbury Tales, which are embedded within the frame narrative of the pilgrimage to Canterbury, are meta-narratives, that is, tales within a tale.

也有可能更进一步，将框架叙事细分为“单端”、“双端”或“侵入性”。“单端”框架叙事是当嵌入的故事完成时不会返回到框架情境的叙事。The Turn of the Screw就是这种情况：讲完家庭教师和孩子们的故事后，我们不会回到框架情境（圣诞节鬼故事设置）来听取听众的反应。显然，在这种情况下帧是单端的，因为如果我们去回到炉边小组，必须解释或辩论许多作为故事本质的关键歧义。因此，出于非常好的战略原因，该帧是单端的。相比之下，黑暗之心的框架叙事是双端的，意味着框架情况在嵌入式故事的结尾重新引入。因此，当故事结束时，我们会简短地回到听众群中，戏剧化的叙述者马洛一直在向他们讲述他在刚果的经历。当, 所以双框架被用来加强故事的主题。

It is possible, too, to go a little further and sub-classify frame narratives as ‘single-ended’, ‘double-ended’, or ‘intrusive’. A ‘single-ended’ frame narrative is one in which the frame situation is not returned to when the embedded tale is complete. This is the case with The Turn of the Screw: when the story of the governess and the children has been told, we do not return to the frame situation (the Christmas ghost story setting) to hear the reaction of the listeners. Clearly, the frame is single-ended in this case because if we went back to the fireside group, many of the crucial ambiguities which are the essence of the tale would have to be explained or debated. So the frame is single-ended for very good strategic reasons. By contrast, the frame narrative in Heart of Darkness is double-ended, meaning that the frame situation is re-introduced at the end of the embedded tale. Thus, when the tale is over we return briefly to the group of listeners to whom Marlow, the dramatised narrator, has been telling the tale of his experiences in the Congo. Of course, Conrad doesn’t attempt to ‘solve’ or elucidate the enormous moral dilemmas which have been the substance of the tale – he merely re-introduces some of the imagery (of half-light and surrounding darkness) which has been prominent throughout, so that the double frame is used to give a kind of reinforcement to the thematics of the tale.

最后，框架也可以是我们所说的“侵入性”，这意味着嵌入的故事偶尔会被打断以恢复到框架情况。这也发生在黑暗之心，当马洛打断他自己的讲述并说出那句著名的话时：“当然……你们看到的比我当时看到的多。” 你看见我，你认识谁……”这提醒我们所有讲故事都受制于观点的局限性，并表明康拉德厌恶零聚焦（“全知叙述”）的传统叙述立场。他故意选择了一位观点有明显局限性的叙述者，“侵入性”的段落继续强调听众的黑暗和孤立（“它变得如此漆黑，以至于我们听众几乎看不到对方”）。这位后来将写下马洛故事的无名记录员表达了这个故事所引发的道德不安，似乎在为我们这些读者说话，提醒我们读者需要的那种警觉和警惕（“我听了，p. 50））。那么，很明显，作者出于战略原因使用了“侵入性”框架，似乎在此处插入了一种“异化装置”，故意打破叙述的魔力，提醒我们其道德复杂性，因此我们不只是不加批判地全神贯注于把它当作一个恰好有殖民地背景的冒险故事来读。

Frames, finally, can also be what we might call ‘intrusive’, meaning that the embedded tale is occasionally interrupted to revert to the frame situation. This too happens in Heart of Darkness, when Marlow interrupts his own telling for a moment and makes the famous remark ‘Of course … you fellows see more than I could see then. You see me, whom you know…’ This reminds us of the limitations of viewpoint to which all story-telling is subject, and shows Conrad’s distaste for the traditional narrating stance of zero focalisation (‘omniscient narration’). He has deliberately chosen a narrator whose outlook has distinct limitations, and the ‘intrusive’ passage goes on to stress the darkness and isolation of the listeners (‘it had become so pitch dark that we listeners could hardly see one another’). The unnamed recorder, who will later write down Marlow’s story, voices the moral unease which the tale provokes, and seems to speak for us as readers, reminding us of the kind of alertness and guardedness which readers need (‘I listened, I listened on the watch for the sentence, for the word, that would give me the clue to the faint uneasiness inspired by this narrative that seemed to shape itself without human lips in the heavy night-air of the river’ (Penguin edition, ed. Robert Hampson, p. 50)). Again, then, it is clear that the author uses an ‘intrusive’ frame for strategic reasons, seeming to insert at this point a kind of ‘alienation device’ which deliberately breaks the spell of the narrative, reminding us of its moral complexities, so that we do not simply become uncritically engrossed in reading it as an adventure story which happens to have a colonial setting.

6. 言语和思想是如何表现的？

Genette 在他的“情绪”一章的副标题“文字的叙述”下讨论了这个问题。这方面的各种选择对作者开放。最简单的选择是呈现“直接和标记”的语音，如下所示：

6. How are speech and thought represented?

Genette discusses this matter in his ‘Mood’ chapter under the subheading ‘Narrative of Words’. Various options in this area are open to the writer. The easiest option is to present speech which is ‘direct and tagged’, like this:

'你叫什么名字？' 马里奥问她。“是塞尔玛”，她回答道。
‘What’s your name?’ Mario asked her. ‘It’s Thelma’, she replied.

这是直接语音，因为给出了实际说出的词（在引号内），并且“标记”是附加短语的名称，表明说话者是谁（如“马里奥问她”和“她回答” ). 演讲也可以“直接且无标签”地呈现，如下所示：

This is direct speech, because the actual spoken words are given (inside the inverted commas), and the ‘tagging’ is the name for the attached phrases which indicate who the speaker is (as in ‘Mario asked her’ and ‘she replied’). The speech can also be presented ‘direct and untagged’, like this:

'你叫什么名字？'

“塞尔玛。”
‘What’s your name?’

‘Thelma.’

显然，如果有两个以上的角色参与对话，或者如果交流不仅仅是一系列问题和答案，这个选项可能会变得混乱，因此首选选项可能是“直接和选择性标记”，如下所示：

Clearly, this option might become confusing if more than two characters are engaged in conversation, or if the exchange is not simply a sequence of questions and answers, so the preferred option might be ‘direct and selectively tagged’, like this:

'你叫什么名字？' 马里奥问。

“塞尔玛。”
‘What’s your name?’ asked Mario.

‘Thelma.’

这里的标记是“选择性的”，因为第一个话语被标记（用“asked Mario”），而不是第二个（没有“她回答”或等价物）。乍一看差异可能很小，但每个插入的标签都在提醒叙述者的存在，因此往往会钝化模仿的边缘，使“展示”回归“讲述”。另一种选择是“标记间接引语”，如下所示：

Here the tagging is ‘selective’ because the first utterance is tagged (with ‘asked Mario’), but not the second (there is no ‘she replied’, or equivalent). The differences may at first seem slight, but each inserted tag is a reminder of the presence of a narrator, and therefore tends to blunt the edge of the mimesis, edging the ‘showing’ back towards ‘telling’. Another option is that of ‘tagged indirect speech’, like this:

他问她叫什么名字，她告诉他叫塞尔玛。
He asked her what her name was, and she told him it was Thelma.

这里的演讲是“报告”形式的，所以我们没有得到实际的口语（例如，他实际上说“你叫什么名字？”他没有说“她叫什么名字？”）。此外，标签是“完整的”，可以这么说（换句话说，“他问她”和“她告诉他”不是与话语分开但遇到它们）。这种报告演讲的方式似乎在读者和所描述的事件之间引入了一种形式上的距离。最后一个选项可能会略微降低距离效果，即使用“自由间接引语”，如下所示：

Here the speech is in ‘reported’ form, so that we are not given the actual spoken words (for instance, he actually said ‘What is your name?’ He didn’t say ‘What was her name?’). Also, the tagging is ‘integral’, so to speak (in other words, ‘He asked her’ and ‘she told him’ are not separated from the utterances but run into them). This way of reporting speech seems to introduce an element of formal distancing between the reader and the depicted events. The distancing effect is perhaps slightly reduced by the final option, which is the use of ‘free indirect speech’, like this:

她叫什么名字？是塞尔玛。
What was her name? It was Thelma.

同样，演讲是报告的或间接的，这通过将动词从现在时态转换为过去时态来表示（因此“is”变成“was”等）。这种风格的效果非常微妙，它对作者的优势之一是它似乎适合内部聚焦的叙述，因为从它“滑行”到记录说话者的想法和感受似乎很自然，就像这样:

Again, the speech is reported or indirect, which is indicated by the switching of verbs from the present tense to the past tense (so that ‘is’ becomes ‘was’, etc.). The effect of this style is quite subtle, and one of its advantages to the writer is that it seems to suit an internally focalised narrative, since it seems natural to ‘glide’ from it into recording the thoughts and feelings of the speaker, like this:

她叫什么名字？是塞尔玛。塞尔玛，是吗？不是那种下水千船的名字。真的，更像是郊区的蕾丝窗帘之类的名字。
What was her name? It was Thelma. Thelma, was it? Not the kind of name to launch a thousand ships. More of a suburban, lace-curtain sort of name, really.

这里对名字的思考显然是提出问题的男性的思考，而不是无所不知的叙述者的概述，但叙述也可以很容易地从另一个方向的自由间接引述，给出行为和反应的外部指示. 因此，对于作者来说，它可能是一个有用的灵活工具。

Here the musings on the name are clearly those of the male who has asked the question, rather than the overview of an omniscient narrator, but the narrative can also move easily from free indirect speech in the other direction, giving external indications of actions and reactions. Hence, it can be a usefully flexible tool for the writer.

Genette 的叙述中的言语表征术语实际上比刚才描述的术语更笼统，设想了三个层次，它们逐渐远离实际所说的话，如下所示：

Genette’s terms for representations of speech in a narrative are actually slightly more generalised than those just described, envisaging three layers, which get progressively further away from the actual words spoken, as follows:

1. “我得走了”，我对她说。（模仿语）
1. ‘I have to go’, I said to her. (Mimetic speech)
2. 我告诉她我得走了。（转置语音）
2. I told her I had to go. (Transposed speech)
3. 我告诉她我必须离开。（叙述性演讲）
3. I informed her that it was necessary for me to leave. (Narratised speech)

正如 Genette 所说 ( p. 172 )，转置引语与自由间接引语并不完全相同：准确地说，它是间接引语，但它不是自由引语（因为它有陈述性动词“我告诉过”，这是一个标记形式）。转置语音和叙述语音之间的本质区别在于，前者允许我们推断出所用词语的实际形式（“我必须走了”），而后者传达的是所说内容的实质，而不是实际的口头公式（这可能是“我已经得走了”，“我不得不走”，“我别无选择，只能走”，等等）。实际上，这将生动的演讲转化为叙述的事件，并在读者与口语的直接影响和语气之间设置了最大距离。

As Genette says (p. 172), transposed speech isn’t quite the same as free indirect speech: to be precise, it’s indirect, but it isn’t free (since it has the declarative verb ‘I told’, which is a form of tagging). The essential difference between transposed and narratised speech is that the former allows us to deduce the actual form of words used (‘I have to go’), whereas the latter conveys the substance of what was said, but not the actual verbal formula (which could have been ‘I’ve got to go’, ‘I am obliged to go’, ‘I have no option but to go’, etc.). Effectively, this converts living speech into narrated event, and interposes the maximum distance between the reader and the direct impact and tone of the spoken words.

“联合”叙事学

‘Joined-up’ narratology

本章讨论的材料为您提供了一种基本的叙事学工具包。首先，我们有故事和情节之间的关键区别，这提醒我们注意叙事是如何设计的，事实上，它可能对我们有什么设计。其次，亚里士多德的分类让我们了解叙事的一些深层心理基础：第三，普罗普的系统提供了用于考虑情节的一些表面细节的数据，第四，热内特的材料将我们的注意力引向了故事是如何讲述的，它如何着手实现其设计。最后，我们可以补充一点，我们在本书前面部分（第 49-58 页）考虑过的罗兰巴特的五个“准则”可以用作所有这些的补充，因为如果亚里士多德主要关注主题，Propp 则情节和热内特的叙述，那么巴特可以说是关注读者，因为正是读者的“解码”使叙事发挥作用的所有因素都变得有意义。总而言之，在一种策略性的混合中，所有这些都可以提供一种“联合”形式的叙事学，其中可能在一个系统中被掩盖的叙事方面可以从另一个系统中得到应有的关注。

The material discussed in this chapter gives you a kind of basic narratological tool kit. Firstly, we have the crucial distinction between story and plot, which alerts us to questions of how the narrative is designed, and, indeed, what designs it might have upon us. Secondly, Aristotle’s categories tune us in to some of the deep-lying, psychic fundamentals of narrative: thirdly, Propp’s system provides data for considering some of the surface specifics of plots, and fourthly, Genette’s material directs our attention towards how the story is told, how it sets about achieving its designs. We might add, finally, that the five ‘codes’ of Roland Barthes which we considered earlier in the book (pp. 49–58) can be used as a supplement to all these, for if Aristotle is mainly focused on theme, Propp on plot, and Genette on narration, then Barthes can be said to focus on the reader, for it is the reader’s ‘de-coding’ which makes sense of all of the factors that narratives bring into play. Taken together, in a kind of strategic blending, all these can provide a ‘joined-up’ form of narratology, in which the aspects of narrative which may be glossed over in one system can receive their due attention from one of the others.

停下来想一想

STOP and THINK

叙事学最引人注目的方面之一是它倾向于为同一现象提供几个不同的术语，每个术语都是不同“学派”的创造（例如，参见“零聚焦”及其等效术语“全知叙述” '). 我们可能会说这意义不大，因为英语一直有一个“分层”的词汇表，对于同一个概念有几个不同的可用词。因此，古英语单词“blessing”具有盎格鲁-诺曼语同义词“benison”，以及拉丁语中的“benediction”。这三个词各有各的“风味”——“blessing”很朴素，“benison”有点华而不实，“benediction”明显是“churchy”。同样，目前在叙事学中最流行的术语具有明显的学术基调，它们来自希腊语和拉丁语的词汇层（例如“模仿”和“故事”），而不是来自更重确保古英语阶层。值得注意的是，从 19 世纪开始讨论写作理论的作家们往往更喜欢使用非常简单的术语——例如，乔治·艾略特和亨利·詹姆斯谈到“展示”和“说”，而不是而不是“模仿”和“叙事”，以及 EM Forster，在他的小说艺术一书中，喜欢使用看似非常公开地表达其含义的家常术语（例如他的“扁平”和“圆润”字符），而没有任何试图以其技术性或学识给我们留下深刻印象。是否有可能为叙述学家喜欢听起来博学的术语提供令人信服的辩护？

One of the most striking aspects of narratology is the way it tends to provide several different terms for the same phenomenon, each one the creation of a different ‘school’ (see, for instance, ‘zero focalisation’ and its equivalent term ‘omniscient narration’). We might say that this is of little significance, since the English language has always had a ‘layered’ vocabulary, with several different available words for the same concept. Thus, the Old English word ‘blessing’ has an Anglo-Norman synonym ‘benison’, and the Latinate equivalent ‘benediction’. The three words each have their own ‘flavour’ – ‘blessing’ is plain, ‘benison’ a bit showy and archaic, and ‘benediction’ distinctly ‘churchy’. Likewise, the terms currently most in vogue in narratology have a distinctly academic tone, being drawn from layers of the vocabulary which derive from Greek and Latin (like ‘mimesis’ and ‘diegesis’, for example), rather than from the more re-assuring Old English strata. It is very noticeable that the writers themselves, who began to discuss the theory of writing from the nineteenth century onwards, tended to prefer very plain terms – George Eliot and Henry James, for instance, spoke of ‘showing’ and ‘saying’, rather than ‘mimesis’ and diegesis’, and E. M. Forster, in his book The Art of the Novel, liked to use homely terms which seem to declare their meanings very openly (such as his ‘flat’ and ‘rounded’ characters), without any attempt to impress us with their technicality or learnedness. Is it possible to offer a convincing defence of the narratologists’ liking for learned-sounding terms?

当然，这是个人问题，您应该尝试对这个问题做出自己的回答。这是我的：我认为博学反映了叙事学家与实际讲故事的距离更大，这最终是因为他们本身通常不是有创造力的作家。这符合这样一个事实，即从业者使用的关于艺术或工艺的语言往往非常接地气，因为从业者通过不显示他们对工艺的日常熟悉程度使用技术语言。因此，一个音乐家可能被外人描述为管弦乐队中的小提琴手，但在谈话中可能会告诉你他们在乐队中拉小提琴。换句话说，叙事学术语的学术语气是可以预料的，因为它反映了与工艺本身的一定距离。但这似乎从来都不是为了给人留下深刻印象的空洞尝试，而且这些术语具有吸引人的简洁性和精确性，尤其是与后结构主义中使用更为宽松的术语方式形成鲜明对比。

This is, of course, a personal matter, and you should try to frame your own response to this question. Here is mine: I think the learnedness reflects the narratologists’ greater distance from the actual telling of stories, and that it is ultimately due to the fact that they are not usually creative writers themselves. This is in line with the fact that the language used by practitioners about an art or craft tends to be very down-to-earth, for practitioners display their everyday familiarity with the craft by not using technical language. Thus, a musician may be described by outsiders as a violinist in an orchestra, but may tell you in conversation that they play the fiddle in a band. In other words, the learned tone of narratological terminology is to be expected, since it reflects a certain distance from the craft itself. But it hardly ever seems just an empty attempt to impress, and there is an attractive concision and precision about these terms, especially in contrast to the much looser way terminology is used within post-structuralism.

叙事学家做什么

What narratologists do

1. 他们着眼于个别叙述，寻找所有叙述中反复出现的结构。

1. They look at individual narratives seeking out the recurrent structures which are found within all narratives.

2. 他们将大部分批判性注意力从故事的单纯“内容”上转移开，往往转而关注讲故事的人和讲故事的人。

2. They switch much of their critical attention away from the mere ‘content’ of the tale, often focusing instead on the teller and the telling.

3. 他们采用主要来自短篇叙事分析的类别，并对其进行扩展和细化，以便能够解释长篇小说叙事的复杂性。

3. They take categories derived mainly from the analysis of short narratives and expand and refine them so that they are able to account for the complexities of novel-length narratives.

4. 他们通过强调行动和结构来抵消传统批评强调人物和动机的倾向。

4. They counteract the tendency of conventional criticism to foreground character and motive by foregrounding instead action and structure.

5. 他们的大部分阅读乐趣和兴趣来自所有叙述之间的相似性，而不是来自少数备受推崇的例子的独特性和独创性。

5. They derive much of their reading pleasure and interest from the affinities between all narratives, rather than from the uniqueness and originality of a small number of highly-regarded examples.

叙事学：一个例子

Narratology: an example

我们将再次使用埃德加·爱伦·坡的故事“椭圆形肖像”（附录 1），并尝试给人一种印象，即刚才提到的“联合”叙事学在实践中可能是什么样子。将考虑概述的四个基本领域（情节/故事的区别、亚里士多德、普罗普和热内特），但以综合的方式而不是按顺序进行，并且不尝试使用我们讨论过的所有类别——有效使用文学理论几乎总是选择性的而不是全面的。我们将省略 Barthes 的代码，因为这些代码已在第 2 章中讨论过。

We will use Edgar Allan Poe’s tale ‘The Oval Portrait’ again (Appendix 1) and try to give an impression of how the ‘joined-up’ narratology just mentioned might look in practice. The four basic areas outlined will be considered (the plot/story distinction, Aristotle, Propp, and Genette), but in an integrated way, rather than in sequence, and with no attempt to use all the categories we have discussed – effective use of literary theory is nearly always selective rather than comprehensive. We will omit Barthes’s codes, since these were looked at in Chapter 2.

情节和故事之间的区别在故事中的事件与我们相关的方式中是显而易见的，这两个“块”以相反的时间顺序呈现：在情节中，我们首先听到内战，叙述者的伤口，他在城堡避难，以及他发现了这幅画像。随后，我们得到了肖像中女人的生活故事，这一定发生在很多年前。如果按时间顺序讲述事件，效果会大不相同，而且过渡将比这里更难管理（官员拿起书提供了一个看似自然的链接）。

The distinction between plot and story is immediately apparent in the way the events in the tale are related to us in two ‘blocks’ which are presented in reverse chronological order: in the plot, we first hear of the civil war, the narrator’s wound, his taking refuge in the castle, and his discovery of the portrait. Subsequently we are given the story of the life of the woman in the portrait, which must actually have happened many years before. Had the events been told in chronological order, the effect would have been very different, and the transition would be more difficult to manage than here (where the officer’s picking up the book provides a natural-seeming link).

故事的这两个“块”当然是“主要”或“框架”叙述（关于受伤军官的部分）和“次要”或“嵌入”叙述（关于肖像环境的部分） . 我们现在有了这些更专业的术语来描述第 1 章中更直接提到的内容作为“故事中的故事”。值得注意的是，框架和元叙事异常平衡——与嵌入的叙事相比，框架通常很小。在情感上，它们之间也有一种隐含的等价性，因此叙述者的伤口和他的感知过程的外延似乎对一个年轻生命被挥霍的悲剧故事具有几乎同等的权重。也许在第一部分中暗示着整个国家在对某种理想的错误追求中遭到蹂躏——这是我们在嵌入式叙事中看到的一种大规模等价物。

These two ‘blocks’ of the story are, of course, the ‘primary’ or ‘frame’ narrative (the part concerning the wounded officer) and the ‘secondary’ or ‘embedded’ narrative (the part concerning the circumstances of the portrait). We now have these more technical terms to describe what was mentioned more straightforwardly in Chapter 1 as the ‘story-within-the-story’. It is notable that frame and meta-narrative are unusually balanced – usually the frame is tiny in comparison with the embedded narrative. Emotionally, too, there is a kind of implied equivalence between them, so that the narrator’s wound and the denotation of his processes of perception seem to have an almost equal weighting to the tragic story of the squandering of a young life. Perhaps there is the implication in the first part that the setting is a whole country which has been ravaged in the mistaken pursuit of some ideal – a kind of large-scale equivalent of what we see in the embedded narrative.

这就提出了框架实际用途的问题，并回答说这是一种使嵌入式叙事的主题产生共鸣和更广泛适用性的方式。但框架是一种延迟装置，其作用是唤起某种情绪或气氛（如歌剧前的序曲）。如果这个故事是一个民间故事或童话故事，一般的惯例就会省去框架，故事会以“从前有一位年轻有才华的艺术家……”开始，效果也会大不相同。我们还可以在此处添加的框架是开放式的——我们不会在最后回到军官和贴身男仆，因此故事以艺术家意识到他的妻子已经死去的高潮时刻结束。显然，双端框架可能会消散这种戏剧性的影响，而且无论如何，叙述者都必须做出某种道德评论，

This raises the issue of what the frame is actually for, and answers by saying that it is a way of giving resonance and wider applicability to the themes of the embedded narrative. But the frame is a delaying device, the role of which is to evoke a certain mood or atmosphere (like the overture played before an opera). If the story had been a folk tale or a fairy tale, generic conventions would have dispensed with the frame, and the story would begin ‘There was once a young and talented artist …’ Again, the effect would be very different. The frame, we can also add here, is open-ended – we don’t go back to the officer and valet at the end, so that the story ends with the climactic moment of the artist realising that his wife is dead. Clearly, a double-ended frame would risk dissipating the dramatic impact of this, and in any case, the narrator would have to make some kind of moralising comment, perhaps along the lines that sometimes the human price of great art can be too high, the effect of which would surely be bathetic.

在这个例子中，Proppian 的材料出奇地富有成果，一种方式是暗示嵌入故事的感伤在于它将两个原型童话主题混合在一起的方式，第一个是捕获公主的故事被一个食人魔或恶棍囚禁在一座塔中，也许丧失了行动能力，瘫痪了，或被一些魔法使者入睡。随后，她被一位英雄发现并救出，英雄随后娶了她。这个故事的另一个主题似乎是关于求婚者的蓝胡子神话，他实际上是连环一夫一妻制和连环杀手，前任新娘的尸体都存放在他的地牢里。所以在 Poe 的故事中，新郎也已经结婚（“在他的艺术中已经有了新娘”）并且即将杀死他的新娘。因此，对于罗伯特·斯科尔斯提到的那种角色混合，英雄和恶棍是同一个人物，而艺术的神奇力量——英雄的艺术天赋——本应提升生活，却成了生活的破坏者。请注意，我们正在自由地调整 Propp 的函数 14（“英雄获得了对魔法代理人的使用”）以适应 Poe 故事中相当不同的焦点。

The Proppian material is surprisingly fruitful in the case of this example, a way into it being to suggest that the pathos of the embedded story lies in the way it conflates two archetypal fairy tale motifs, the first being the tale in which a princess is captured by an ogre or villain, imprisoned in a tower, and perhaps incapacitated, paralysed, or put to sleep by some magical agent. Subsequently she is discovered and rescued by a hero who then marries her. The other motif this tale seems to play with is the Bluebeard myth of the suitor who is actually a serial monogamist and a serial killer, with the bodies of previous brides stored in his dungeon. So in Poe’s tale too, the bridegroom is already married (‘having already a bride in his Art’) and is about to kill his bride. So with the kind of conflating of roles mentioned by Robert Scholes, hero and villain are the same figure, and the magical agency of art – the hero’s artistic talent – which should enhance life, instead becomes its destroyer. Notice here that we are freely adapting Propp’s function 14 (‘The hero acquires the use of a magical agent’) to the rather different focus of Poe’s tale.

转向Genette的分类，我们可以说，首先，主要叙事和嵌入叙事都主要是模仿性的，但很明显模仿。开头，就“建筑物的远程炮塔”一词而言，保留了一定程度的普遍性：例如，当贴身男仆“冒险强行进入”城堡时，该短语通常具有概括性的元素在讲述而不是展示中发现；这个短语有点“叙述”（热内特的那个有用的术语），也就是说，包装成“叙述者说话”，这样我们就不会真正“看到”发生了什么——男仆用斧头砸坏了锁，还是反复用肩膀顶住门直到它让路，或者用破损的日晷作为临时的攻城锤冲向门？还是他只是用步枪枪托打破了一楼的窗户然后爬了进去？显然，所有这些短语都会给出“完全模仿”，正如我们所说的那样，这样我们就会“看到”正在发生的事情，

Turning to Genette’s categories, we can say, firstly, that both primary and embedded narratives are mainly mimetic, but it is clear that there are degrees of mimesis. The opening, as far as the words ‘a remote turret of the building’, retains a degree of generality: for instance, when the valet ‘ventured to make forcible entrance’ to the chateau, the phrase has an element of the generalising touch usually found in telling rather than showing; the phrase is slightly ‘narratised’ (that useful term of Genette’s), that is, packaged into ‘narrator-speak’, so that we don’t actually ‘see’ what is happening – did the valet smash the lock with an axe, or shoulder the door repeatedly till it gave way, or run at it using a broken sundial as an improvised battering ram? Or did he just break a ground-floor window with the butt of his rifle and climb in? Clearly, all these phrases would give ‘full mimesis’, as we might call it, so that we would ‘see’ what is happening, whereas ‘making forcible entrance’ is a phrase which gives only a ‘partial mimesis’, leaving the actual method still a secret of the narrator’s.

对房间的描述（来自“它的装饰品”）更接近于完全模仿：装饰品“富丽堂皇，但破烂不堪，古色古香”，但当我们停下来想一想时，“装饰品”到底是什么？‘千姿百态的战利品’究竟是什么？它们是盾牌、剑、头盔、盔甲还是什么？每个有多少个，它们的确切位置在哪里？好吧，这种“中间模仿”（我们这样称呼它）并不准确，因为它的工作不是像摄像机一样在房间里慢慢摇动，而只是给我们一系列生动的印象房间的性质和气氛。以“但是产生的动作”开头的段落达到了完整的模仿，其中讲述的速度进一步放慢，并与军官印象的顺序相匹配。所以我们得到非常精确的舞台指示，将我们准确地置于军官的位置，这样我们就可以和他一起看，可以说，并产生事件正在我们眼前发生的错觉。然后故事保持完全模仿，直到军官拿起书并开始嵌入叙述，这也经历了相同的阶段，从部分模仿，到中间模仿，再到完全模仿。

The description of the room (from ‘Its decorations’) moves closer towards full mimesis: the decorations are ‘rich, yet tattered and antique’, but what exactly, when we stop to think about it, are ‘decorations’? What precisely are the ‘manifold and multiform armorial trophies’? Are they shields, swords, helmets, suits of armour, or what? How many are there of each, and where exactly are they positioned? Well, this kind of ‘mid-mimesis’ (let’s call it) doesn’t precisely say, for its job is not to pan slowly round the room like a camcorder, but just to give us a series of vivid impressions of the nature and atmosphere of the room. Full mimesis is reached with the paragraph beginning ‘But the action produced’, where the pace of the telling is slowed further, and matched to the sequence of the officer’s impressions. So we get very precise stage directions which place us exactly in the officer’s position, so that we see with him, so to speak, and have the illusion that the events are happening before our eyes. The story then remains in full mimesis until the officer picks up the book and the embedded narrative begins, and that too goes through the same stages, from partial, to mid, to full mimesis.

两种叙事的焦点化也很有趣：框架叙事是第一人称同调故事，由具有鲜明个性和生活史的公开或“戏剧化”的叙述者告诉我们，我们可以从故事的细节中推断出这一点，即使我们不知道他的名字——他受过教育（他知道安妮·拉德克利夫 (Anne Radcliffe) 的 18 世纪哥特式小说，知道绘画技巧，例如“渐晕”'，并且似乎对感知行为的过程和阶段有浓厚的兴趣）而且他显然很富裕（例如，他有一个贴身男仆）。嵌入式叙事的叙述者更有问题：枕头上发现的“小册子”“旨在批评和描述”房间里“数量异常多”的画作表明他就是现在被称为艺术评论家的人或鉴赏家，但我们对他一无所知。我们推测，他是一个异故事叙述者，不是他讲述的故事的一部分，但在“没有人被允许进入炮塔”之后，他的信息来源很难猜测——要么他是一个无所不知的叙述者，他假设进入和建构他的主题的思想的特权，或者他与画家有更深的亲密关系。也许他是画家；当然，我们可以假设墙上“数量异常多的神采飞扬的现代画作”都是出自同一位艺术家之手，因为它们显然都是同一风格，而且也许每幅画都是在相似的环境下创作的，每幅画的成本都很高保姆的生活，在一个强制重复的“原始场景”中，艺术和生活在其中争夺至高无上的地位。有趣的是，这些最初是关于叙述者性质的技术推测似乎很快就引向了最深层次的内容。

The focalisation of the two narratives is also of interest: the frame narrative is first-person homodiegetic, told to us by an overt or ‘dramatised’ narrator who has a distinct personality and life history, which we can deduce from the details of the story, even though we do not know his name – he is educated (he knows the eighteenth-century Gothic novels of Anne Radcliffe, is aware of painterly techniques like ‘vignetting’, and seems to have a strong interest in the processes and stages of the act of perception) and he is obviously well-to-do (he has a valet, for instance). The narrator of the embedded narrative is more problematical: the ‘small volume’ found on the pillow which ‘purported to criticise and describe’ the ‘unusually great number’ of paintings in the room suggests that he is what would now be called an art critic or connoisseur, but we know nothing else about him. He is, we presume, a heterodiegetic narrator, not part of the tale he tells, but the source of his information after the period when ‘there were admitted none into the turret’ is difficult to guess – either he is an omniscient narrator who assumes the privilege of entering and constructing the mind of his subject, or else he has some deeper intimacy with the painter. Perhaps he is the painter; certainly, we can assume that the ‘unusually great number of spirited modern paintings’ on the walls are all painted by the same artist, since they are all evidently in the same style, and perhaps each of them was produced in similar circumstances, each costing the life of the sitter, in a compulsively repeated ‘primal scene’ in which art and life struggle together for supremacy. Interestingly, then, these at first technical speculations about the nature of the narrator seem to lead quickly to the deepest levels of content.

这将我们带到亚里士多德的潜在层面：错觉（驱动整个故事的罪恶或错误）当然是才华横溢的艺术家的道德盲目，他们将自己提升到神一般的地位，承担创造生活的角色，但只能以牺牲生命为代价才能做到这一点。他缺乏视线（对自己的了解）和前景视力，无法看到他的创造性痴迷的必然结果。奇怪的是，对于一个艺术家来说，他也缺乏同理心和想象力，因此无法复制真实的东西，只能复制一个幻影，一种完全没有人的本质的幽灵全息图。自我认知或无知的时刻来得太晚了，因为他从未有过“她快死了”的想法，只有迟来的“她死了”的知觉。Peripeteia，或命运的转变，可能与这两个角色有关，因为男性形象从“享有盛誉”的艺术家转变为吸血鬼杀手，而女性最初是某种能量的化身生命力本身，

This brings us to that underlying Aristotelian level: the hamartia (the sin or fault which motors the whole story) is of course the moral blindness of the talented artist, who elevates himself to god-like status, taking on the role of creating life, but being able to do so only at the expense of life. He lacks both insight (knowledge of himself) and fore sight, being unable to see the inevitable outcome of his creative obsessions. Curiously for an artist, he also lacks empathy and imagination, and so cannot reproduce the real thing, only a simulacrum, a kind of spooky hologram from which the essence of the person is quite absent. The moment of self-recognition, or anagnorisis, comes too late, since he never has the thought ‘she is dying’, only the belated perception ‘she is dead’. The peripeteia, or switch in fortune, is perhaps relevant to both characters, for the male figure changes from being an artist of ‘high renown’ and becomes a vampiric murderer, while the woman is at first a kind of embodiment of the energies of the life force itself, and then becomes the meekly yielding victim whose erotic appeal consists of listlessly allowing her life to be drained away (the fate of most of the women in Poe’s tales).

因此，通过这些主要是技术性的叙事学类别来处理这个故事似乎确实开辟了新的途径，这些途径确实表明了叙事中的意义是如何构建的，同时也为我们提供了关于这个特定故事的新想法的附带好处，它陈旧的主题领域是生活诉求与艺术诉求之间的冲突和对比。

So, approaching the story through these mainly technical narratological categories does seem to open up new avenues which do indeed suggest how meanings are constructed in narratives, at the same time as having the spin-off bonus of giving us new ideas about this particular tale and its well-worn thematic territory of the conflict and contrast between the claims of life and the claims of art.

选读

Selected reading

Bal, Mieke，《叙事学：叙事理论导论》（多伦多大学出版社，第 2 版，1997 年）。

最初用荷兰语写成，1985 年首次以英文出版，这本书很快成为标准文本：它具有叙事学最佳代表的精确、简洁和清晰——就像该领域的所有重要作品一样，这不是一本大量的书。可以愉快地通读，也可以用作简明的叙事学百科全书。

Bal, Mieke, Narratology: Introduction to the Theory of Narrative (University of Toronto Press, 2nd edn, 1997).

Originally written in Dutch, and first published in English in 1985, this book quickly became a standard text: it has the precision, concision, and clarity which typify narratology at its best – like all the important works in the field, this is not a massive tome. Can be read through with pleasure, or used as a concise encyclopaedia of narratology.

Cohan、Steven 和 Shires、Linda M.，讲故事：叙事小说的理论分析（Routledge，1988 年）。

涵盖整个当代文化（电影、广告等）的叙事。很多有用的材料，虽然写得相当简朴。

Cohan, Steven and Shires, Linda M., Telling Stories: A Theoretical Analysis of Narrative Fiction (Routledge, 1988).

Covers narrative across the whole range of contemporary culture (film, advertising, and so on). Plenty of useful material, though rather austerely written.

Genette, Gérard, Narrative Discourse (Basil Blackwell, 1972)。

热内特关于“顺序”、“持续时间”、“频率”、“情绪”和“声音”的五个章节是许多当代叙事学思想的源泉。如果将许多子标题打印在相当简约的目录列表中会有所帮助，但出色的索引弥补了不足，促进了该领域重要的“百科全书式”使用。

Genette, Gérard, Narrative Discourse (Basil Blackwell, 1972).

Genette’s five chapters on ‘Order’, ‘Duration’, ‘Frequency’, ‘Mood’, and ‘Voice’ are the source of much contemporary thinking in narratology. It would help if the many sub-headings were printed in the rather minimalist list of contents, but the excellent index makes up for the deficiency, facilitating the kind of ‘encyclopaedic’ use which is important in this field.

赫尔曼，大卫，编辑。The Cambridge Companion to Narrative（剑桥大学出版社，2007 年）。

关于故事、情节和旁白的有用章节；时间和空间; 特点; 对话; focusization 等，收录在旨在迎合“第一次接触叙事研究领域的读者”的合集中。

Herman, David, ed. The Cambridge Companion to Narrative (Cambridge University Press, 2007).

Useful chapters on story, plot and narration; time and space; character; dialogue; focalization, etc., in a collection which aims to cater for ‘readers coming to the field of narrative studies for the first time’.

Onega、Susana 和 Angel，José 编着，《叙事学》 （朗文出版社，1996 年）。

一个优秀的收藏。它强调叙事学和解构主义、女权主义、精神分析以及电影和媒体研究的相互影响。

Onega, Susana and Angel, José, eds, Narratology (Longman, 1996).

An excellent collection. It stresses the mutual influences of narratology and deconstruction, feminism, psychoanalysis, and film and media studies.

Prince, Gerald, A Dictionary of Narratology（内布拉斯加大学出版社，1987 年）。

包含最简短和最精辟的定义——这本小书在描述各种叙事学派别时表现得非常宽容。无论我想了解什么叙事学知识，这通常都是我的第一站。

Prince, Gerald, A Dictionary of Narratology (University of Nebraska Press, 1987).

Contains the briefest and most pithy definitions – this little book is strikingly catholic in its representation of the various narratological sects. Whatever I want to know in narratology, this is usually my first port of call.

Rimmon-Kenan, Shlomith,叙事小说(Routledge, 1983)。

看起来有点令人望而生畏，但这项开创性的工作尽管很简短，但却非常广泛。

Rimmon-Kenan, Shlomith, Narrative Fiction (Routledge, 1983).

Can seem a little daunting, but this pioneering work is extremely wide-ranging, in spite of its brevity.

13

生态批评

13

Ecocriticism

生态批评还是绿色研究？

Ecocriticism or green studies?

“简单地定义，生态批评是对文学与物理环境之间关系的研究”（Cheryll Glotfelty）。但我们应该称其为“生态批评”还是“绿色研究”？这两个术语都用于表示 1980 年代后期在美国和 1990 年代初期在英国开始的批判方法，并且由于它仍然是一个“新兴”运动，因此有必要简要介绍一下其迄今为止的制度历史. 在美国，公认的创始人是 Cheryll Glotfelty，他与 Harold Fromm 共同编辑了一本名为《生态批评读本：文学生态学中的地标》的重要散文集，这些散文集很有帮助且具有权威性（佐治亚大学出版社，1996 年）。1992 年，她还是 ASLE（发音为“Az-lee”，文学与环境研究协会）的联合创始人。ASLE 有自己的“内部期刊”，称为ISLE（文学与环境的跨学科研究)，始于 1993 年，因此美国的生态批评在 1990 年代初期已经是一个新兴的学术运动，开始建立由指定期刊和官方法人团体组成的专业基础设施。然而，与本书中讨论的大多数理论不同，它仍然明显处于学术边缘——这本书是众多可用的普通读者和文学理论导论中提到生态批评的第一本，而且该运动仍然没有广为人知的一组假设、学说或程序。由于美国的生态批评似乎在西方的大学中最为强烈——也就是说，远离最大的城市，远离美国主要的学术权力中心东海岸和西海岸——我们可能期望它体现这种“非中心主义”的理想。

‘Simply defined, ecocriticism is the study of the relationship between literature and the physical environment’ (Cheryll Glotfelty). But should we call it ‘ecocriticism’ or ‘green studies’? Both terms are used to denote a critical approach which began in the USA in the late 1980s, and in the UK in the early 1990s, and since it is still an ‘emergent’ movement, it is worth briefly setting out its institutional history to date. In the USA the acknowledged founder is Cheryll Glotfelty, co-editor with Harold Fromm of a key collection of helpful and definitive essays entitled The Ecocriticism Reader: Landmarks in Literary Ecology (University of Georgia Press, 1996). In 1992 she was also the co-founder of ASLE (pronounced ‘Az-lee’, the Association for the Study of Literature and Environment). ASLE has its own ‘house journal’, called ISLE (Interdisciplinary Studies in Literature and Environment), which started in 1993, so American ecocriticism was already a burgeoning academic movement by the early 1990s, beginning to establish its professional infrastructure of designated journals and an official corporate body. However, unlike most of the theories discussed in this book, it is still distinctly on the academic margins – the present book is the first of the many available general readers and introductions to literary theory to mention ecocriticism, and the movement still does not have a widely-known set of assumptions, doctrines, or procedures. Since ecocriticism in the USA seems to be strongest in the universities of the West – that is, away from the largest cities, and from the major academic power-centres of the East and West coasts – we might expect it to embody ‘decentrist’ ideals of this kind.

生态批评作为一个概念最早出现于 20 世纪 70 年代后期的 WLA（西部文学协会，一个关注美国西部文学的机构）会议上。在他对一系列简短立场文件（全部标题为“什么是生态批评？”）的介绍中，Michael P. Branch 将“生态批评”一词追溯到 William Rueckert 1978 年的论文“文学与生态学：生态批评的实验”。1著名的美国生态评论家 Karl Kroeber 声称在文学批评中首次使用相关术语“生态”，他的文章““格拉斯米尔的家”：生态圣洁”发表在PMLA 杂志上，89, 1974, 第 132–41 页。直到 1989 年 WLA 会议（在美国 Coeur d'Alene），这两个术语（“生态批评”和“生态”）显然都处于批评词汇中（Branch 说），当时 Cheryll Glotfelty（当时是康奈尔大学的研究生） ，随后是里诺内华达大学文学与环境副教授）不仅复活了“生态批评”一词，而且敦促采用它来指代以前被称为“自然写作研究”的分散批评领域.

Ecocriticism as a concept first arose in the late 1970s, at meetings of the WLA (the Western Literature Association, a body whose field of interest is the literature of the American West). In his introduction to a series of brief position papers (all entitled ‘What is ecocriticism?’) Michael P. Branch traces the word ‘ecocriticism’ back to William Rueckert’s 1978 essay ‘Literature and ecology: an experiment in ecocriticism’.1 A claim for first usage in literary criticism of the related term ‘ecological’ is made by prominent US eco-critic Karl Kroeber, whose article ‘“Home at Grasmere”: ecological holiness’, appeared in the journal PMLA, 89, 1974, pp. 132–41. Both terms (‘ecocriticism’ and ‘ecological’) apparently lay dormant in the critical vocabulary (says Branch) until the 1989 WLA conference (in Coeur d’Alene, USA), when Cheryll Glotfelty (at the time a graduate student at Cornell University, subsequently Associate Professor of Literature and the Environment at the University of Nevada, Reno) not only revived the term ‘ecocriticism’, but urged its adoption to refer to the diffuse critical field that had previously been known as ‘the study of nature writing’.

生态批评，正如它现在在美国存在的那样，从 19 世纪美国三位主要作家那里获得了文学意义，他们的作品颂扬自然、生命力和在美国表现出来的荒野，他们是拉尔夫·沃尔多·爱默生 (Ralph Waldo Emerson，1803-1882)，玛格丽特·富勒 (1810–1850) 和亨利·戴维·梭罗 (1817–1862)。这三人都是新英格兰作家、散文家和哲学家团体的“成员”，这些作家、散文家和哲学家统称为先验主义者，这是美国第一个从欧洲模式中实现“文化独立”的主要文学运动。爱默生的第一本短篇小说《自然》于 1836 年首次匿名出版（收录于拉尔夫·沃尔多·爱默生：论文选集，拉泽·齐夫编，企鹅出版社，1982 年）自然界的他，经常用极具戏剧性的直率话语表达：

Ecocriticism, as it now exists in the USA, takes its literary bearings from three major nineteenth-century American writers whose work celebrates nature, the life force, and the wilderness as manifested in America, these being Ralph Waldo Emerson (1803–1882), Margaret Fuller (1810–1850), and Henry David Thoreau (1817–1862). All three were ‘members’ of the group of New England writers, essayists and philosophers known collectively as the transcendentalists, the first major literary movement in America to achieve ‘cultural independence’ from European models. Emerson’s first, short book Nature, first published anonymously in 1836 (included in Ralph Waldo Emerson: Selected Essays, ed. Larzer Ziff, Penguin, 1982) is a reflective (rather than philosophical) essay on the impact upon him of the natural world, often voiced in words of powerfully dramatic directness:

穿过一片光秃秃的公地，在雪坑里，在暮色中，在乌云密布的天空下，我没有想到任何特别的好运，我享受了一种完美的兴奋。我高兴到恐惧的边缘。（第 1 章，第 38 页）
Crossing a bare common, in snow puddles, at twilight, under a clouded sky, without having in my thoughts any occurrence of special good fortune, I have enjoyed a perfect exhilaration. I am glad to the brink of fear. (chapter 1, p. 38)

富勒的第一本书是1843 年湖上的夏天（包括在便携式玛格丽特富勒，维京人/企鹅出版社，1994 年），这是一本强有力的日记，记录了她在作为第一位女学生一段时间后与美国风景的邂逅在哈佛。例如，在尼亚加拉，她写道：

Fuller’s first book was Summer on the Lakes, During 1843 (included in The Portable Margaret Fuller, Viking/Penguin, 1994), which is a powerfully written journal of her encounter with the American landscape at large, after a period as the first woman student at Harvard. At Niagara, for instance, she writes:

因为这里无法逃脱永恒创造的重压；所有其他形式和运动都来来去去，潮起潮落，风在最强大的时候以狂风暴雨的形式移动，但这里确实是一种持续不断的、不知疲倦的运动。无论醒着还是睡着，都无法逃脱，它仍然围绕着你，穿过你。正是通过这种方式，我最能感受到它的宏伟——即使不是无限，也有些永恒。（第 71 页）
For here there is no escape from the weight of a perpetual creation; all other forms and motions come and go, the tide rises and recedes, the wind, at its mightiest, moves in gales and gusts, but here is really an incessant, an indefatigable motion. Awake or asleep, there is no escape, still this rushing round you and through you. It is in this way I have most felt the grandeur – somewhat eternal, if not infinite. (p. 71)

梭罗的《瓦尔登湖》 （牛津大学出版社，世界经典，1999 年）记述了他从 1845 年起在瓦尔登湖岸边建造的一间小屋里逗留的两年，距离他的家乡马萨诸塞州康科德市几英里. 这也许是关于脱离现代生活并寻求通过“回归自然”来更新自我的经典描述——这当然是一本对读者的态度始终产生强烈影响的书。这三本书可以看作是美国“以生态为中心”写作的奠基之作。

Thoreau’s Walden (Oxford University Press, World’s Classics, 1999) is an account of his two-year stay, from 1845, in a hut he had built on the shore of Walden Pond, a couple of miles from his home town of Concord, Massachusetts. It is, perhaps, the classic account of dropping out of modern life and seeking to renew the self by a ‘return to nature’ – this is certainly a book which has always exerted a strong effect on the attitudes of its readers. These three books can be seen as the foundational works of American ‘ecocentred’ writing.

相比之下，英国版的生态批评或绿色研究从 1790 年代的英国浪漫主义而不是 1840 年代的美国超验主义中汲取灵感。英国方面的创始人物是评论家乔纳森贝特，他是浪漫生态学：华兹华斯和环境传统（Routledge，1991）的作者。英国生态批评家还指出，他们的许多担忧在雷蒙德·威廉姆斯 (Raymond Williams) 的著作《乡村与城市》 (Chatto & Windus, 1973) 中显而易见（在“生态批评”一词出现之前）。英国生态批评的基础设施不如美国发达（目前还没有本土期刊或供生态评论家加入的正式机构，尽管 ASLE 在英国设有分支机构），但提供本科学位课程的相关课程选择正变得越来越普遍，尤其是在新的大学和高等教育学院。当然，机构隶属关系会发生变化，但在撰写本文时，除了 Bate 本人（在华威大学任教）之外，大多数英国生态批评的活跃支持者都来自这些机构（例如曼彻斯特城市大学的 Laurence Coupe） , Richard Kerridge 和 Greg Garrard 都在 Bath Spa 大学，Terry Gifford 在前布雷顿霍尔学院，现在是利兹大学的一部分）。权威的英国散文集（在英国与美国的 Glotfelty 和 Fromm 具有同等地位）是 Laurence Coupe 的绿色研究读本：从浪漫主义到生态批评（Routledge，2000 年）。

By contrast, the UK version of ecocriticism, or green studies, takes its bearings from the British Romanticism of the 1790s rather than the American transcendentalism of the 1840s. The founding figure on the British side is the critic Jonathan Bate, author of Romantic Ecology: Wordsworth and the Environmental Tradition (Routledge, 1991). British ecocritics also make the point that many of their concerns are evident (before the term ‘ecocriticism’ existed) in Raymond Williams’s book The Country and the City (Chatto & Windus, 1973). The infrastructure of ecocriticism in the UK is less developed than in the USA (there are as yet no indigenous journals or formal bodies for ecocritics to join, though there is a UK branch of ASLE), but the provision of relevant course options on undergraduate degree programmes is becoming more widespread, especially in new universities and colleges of higher education. Of course, institutional affiliations change, but at the time of writing, apart from Bate himself (who teaches at the University of Warwick), most of the active British proponents of ecocriticism were based at these institutions (such as Laurence Coupe at Manchester Metropolitan University, Richard Kerridge and Greg Garrard both at Bath Spa University, and Terry Gifford at the former Bretton Hall College, now part of the University of Leeds). The definitive UK collection of essays (having equivalent status in the UK to that of Glotfelty and Fromm in the USA) is Laurence Coupe’s The Green Studies Reader: From Romanticism to Ecocriticism (Routledge, 2000).

两种截然不同的生态方法国家变体的存在表明一种类似于第 9 章中描述的情况，其中我们看到“英国”文化唯物主义和“美国”新历史主义在方法和目标上是如何明确联系在一起的，但在重点和“起源”上却有所不同。一般来说，美国首选的术语是“生态批评”，而“绿色研究”在英国经常使用，而且美国的写作可能有一种倾向是“庆祝”的语气（偶尔会退化为强硬的左翼批评家所贬低的）称为“抱树”），而英国变体往往更具“警告性”，也就是说，它试图警告我们来自政府、工业、商业和新殖民势力的环境威胁。例如，贝特最近的一本书《地球之歌》（Picador，2000 年）认为，殖民主义和森林砍伐经常并存。2个

The existence of two distinct national variants of the ecological approach suggests a situation similar to the one described in Chapter 9, in which we saw how ‘British’ cultural materialism and ‘American’ new historicism are clearly linked in their approaches and aims, but differ in emphasis and ‘ancestry’. Generally, the preferred American term is ‘ecocriticism’, whereas ‘green studies’ is frequently used in the UK, and there is perhaps a tendency for the American writing to be ‘celebratory’ in tone (occasionally degenerating into what harder-left critics disparagingly call ‘tree-hugging’), whereas the British variant tends to be more ‘minatory’, that is, it seeks to warn us of environmental threats emanating from governmental, industrial, commercial, and neo-colonial forces. For instance, Bate’s more recent book, The Song of the Earth (Picador, 2000), argues that colonialism and deforestation have frequently gone together.2

文化与自然

Culture and nature

那么，无论所讨论的是哪个民族变体，生态批评的特征是什么态度？本小节指出生态批评中关于文化与自然关系这一关键问题的一些辩论的范围。也许这里要说明的最基本的一点是，生态批评家拒绝这样一种观念（本书所考虑的大多数其他理论所共有的），即一切都是社会和/或语言建构的（这是五个反复出现的想法清单中的第一项）上文第 33-5 页给出的批判理论）。对于生态批评家来说，自然确实存在于我们之外，不需要被反讽为一个概念，将其封闭在已知的引号中，而是作为一个影响我们的实体存在，如果我们虐待它，我们可能会影响它，也许是致命的它。那么，自然不能还原为我们认为是我们文化实践的一部分的概念（例如，我们可能会设想一个神灵，并将其投射到宇宙中）。一般而言，理论倾向于将我们的外部世界视为社会和语言构建的，“总是已经”文本化为“话语”，但生态批评对这种长期存在的理论正统性提出质疑，有时相当不耐烦，正如凯特索珀经常被引用的评论（在她的开创性著作中什么是自然？ p. 151) “臭氧层破洞的不是语言。” 因此，生态批评否定了“建构性”的基本信念，而“建构性”是文学理论的一个重要方面。当然，对社会建构的普遍性的信念总是容易受到反对，因为如果它是真的，它必然是不可知的（因为“一切”都包括“一切都是社会和语言建构的”这一观念本身）。20世纪80年代，社会建设团伙似乎无处不在，将学术的人行道开挖、置换，而大部分的工作仍在原地，构成了人文学科的学术主干道。因此，无论是验证还是证伪一切都是社会或语言建构的观点的困难并没有削弱它对关于文学理论的日常辩论的控制。然而，生态批评介入理论的实质是挑战它。

What attitudes, then, are characteristic of ecocriticism, irrespective of which national variant is in question? This sub-section indicates the scope of some of the debates within ecocriticism concerning the crucial matter of the relationship between culture and nature. Perhaps the most fundamental point to make here is that ecocritics reject the notion (common to most of the other theories considered in this book) that everything is socially and/or linguistically constructed (which is the first item in the list of five recurrent ideas in critical theory given on pp. 33–5, above). For the ecocritic, nature really exists, out there beyond ourselves, not needing to be ironised as a concept by enclosure within knowing inverted commas, but actually present as an entity which affects us, and which we can affect, perhaps fatally, if we mistreat it. Nature, then, isn’t reducible to a concept which we conceive as part of our cultural practice (as we might conceive a deity, for instance, and project it out onto the universe). Theory in general tends to see our external world as socially and linguistically constructed, as ‘always already’ textualised into ‘discourse’, but ecocriticism calls this long-standing theoretical orthodoxy into question, sometimes rather impatiently, as in Kate Soper’s frequently-quoted remark (in her seminal book What is Nature? p. 151) that ‘It isn’t language which has a hole in its ozone layer.’ Ecocriticism, then, repudiates the foundational belief in ‘constructedness’ which is such an important aspect of literary theory. Of course, that belief in the universality of social constructedness was always vulnerable to the objection that if true it would necessarily be unknowable (since ‘everything’ would include the idea itself that ‘everything is socially and linguistically constructed’). In the 1980s, social-construction gangs seemed to be everywhere, digging up and replacing the academic sidewalks, and for the most part their work is still in place, constituting the main academic thoroughfare in the Humanities.
