这场争论在剑桥持续不断，似乎陷入了滑稽的模仿，就像汤姆夏普 1974 年的讽刺小说《蓝色波特豪斯》中的一集（讲述的是一所神话般的剑桥大学里反动派和改革派之间的斗争）。任命委员会的程序现在已经泄露，并宣布将由“大学古老的法庭Septem Viri ”调查此次泄密事件。'（七人）。然后学生们反抗并通过了对教职工委员会的不信任投票，要求对英语教职工的状况进行公开调查。这在参议院如期举行，在报纸报道中不可避免地被描述为“橡木镶板”。这本来应该是结构主义者、马克思主义者、人文主义者和其他人之间的高层次知识辩论，但当然不是——它是关于程序、行政和委员会的。当时的高等教育发展迅速，但撒切尔政府严格削减资金——建筑物湿腐烂，缺乏清洁工，学生抱怨与导师的接触时间不足，而导师越来越被迫接受他们的研究。最终，“事件”以失败告终：双方达成妥协，将 MacCabe 的职位再延长一年，但 1981 年 7 月，他离开剑桥，接受格拉斯哥富有进取精神的斯特拉斯克莱德大学的教授职位。总的来说，理论从所有这些宣传中受益：这里似乎是一位拥有前沿思想的聪明才俊，他的职业生涯正受到反动势力的威胁。我们可以说，理论现在有了自己的殉道者，并且对自身的连贯性和重要性有了更强烈的认识。是一个聪明的年轻人才，有着前沿的思想，他的职业生涯正受到反动势力的威胁。我们可以说，理论现在有了自己的殉道者，并且对自身的连贯性和重要性有了更强烈的认识。是一个聪明的年轻人才，有着前沿的思想，他的职业生涯正受到反动势力的威胁。我们可以说，理论现在有了自己的殉道者，并且对自身的连贯性和重要性有了更强烈的认识。

The dispute dragged on at Cambridge and seemed to descend into farcical parody, like an episode in Tom Sharpe’s 1974 satirical novel Porterhouse Blue (which is about the struggle between reactionaries and reformers at a mythical Cambridge college). The proceedings of the appointments committee had by now been leaked, and it was announced that the leak would be investigated ‘by the university’s ancient court the Septem Viri’ (the Seven Men). Then the students revolted and passed a vote of no confidence in the Faculty Board, calling for an open enquiry into the state of the English Faculty. This duly took place in the Senate House, inevitably described in the newspaper reports as ‘oak-panelled’. It should have been a high-level intellectual debate between structuralists, Marxists, humanists, and the rest, but of course it wasn’t – it was about procedures, and administration, and committees. Higher education in those days was expanding rapidly, but funding was being rigorously curtailed by the Thatcher government – there was wet rot in buildings and a lack of cleaners, and students complained about inadequate contact time with tutors who were increasingly being pressured to get on with their research. The ‘affair’, in the end, fizzled out: a compromise was reached whereby MacCabe’s post would be extended for a further year, but in July 1981 he left Cambridge to take up the offer of a professorship at the enterprising Strathclyde University in Glasgow. On the whole, theory benefited from all this publicity: here, it seemed, was a bright young talent with cutting-edge ideas whose career was being threatened by the forces of reaction. Theory, we might say, now had its martyr, and an increased sense of its own coherence and importance.

伊格尔顿的文学理论：

导论出版， 1983

The publication of Eagleton’s Literary Theory:

An Introduction, 1983

阅读：这本书本身，以及早期的评论，例如 John Bayley 在Times Literary Supplement中的评论（1983 年 6 月 10 日）。
Reading: the book itself, and early reviews such as John Bayley’s in the Times Literary Supplement (10 June 1983).

回顾 20 世纪 70 年代以来的文学理论传播似乎是不可避免和无情的，但实际上它取决于找到有效的理论教学方法，而不仅仅是研究方法它在教师和研究生水平。MacCabe 事件凸显了这样做的一些困难，表明需要进行详细的说明、举例和讨论。大多数文学理论的主要文本都是用法语写成的，有一些是用德语或俄语写的，而且还不是所有的都被翻译了。迫切需要“中介”作品，即可以用作本科和硕士课程教科书的介绍性书籍。没有这些书，文学理论注定只能是少数精英人士的兴趣所在。1977 年创立的名为“Methuen New Accents”的系列书籍首先满足了对基本中学阐述的需求，该系列书籍为学生提供了关于结构主义、解构主义、后结构主义等的个人介绍性书籍。文学理论：介绍，由 Blackwell 于 1983 年出版。这本书一炮而红，因为它以生动和挑衅的方式写成，并且抵制了制作厚重而庞大的大部头的诱惑——这样的书可能会给同行留下深刻印象，但不适合寻求探索的学生。初步启蒙。这些品质使它有别于它的大多数后继者，也有别于 80 年代后期开始出现的文学理论课本“读者”。包含一系列主要人物的关键文章和章节的“读者”如果有选择性并且试图满足用户的实际需求，可能会非常有用，但此类书籍很久以前就屈服于竞争性的超大尺寸，

The spread of literary theory since the 1970s seems in retrospect to have been inevitable and relentless, but in reality it was dependent upon finding effective ways of teaching theory, not just ways of studying it at faculty and postgraduate level. The MacCabe affair highlighted some of the difficulties of doing this and showed the need for detailed exposition, exemplification and discussion. Most of the primary texts of literary theory had been written in French, with a few in German or Russian, and by no means all of them had yet been translated. There was an acute need for ‘mediating’ works, that is, introductory books which could be used as course textbooks on undergraduate and MA courses. Without such books, literary theory would be doomed to remain an elitist minority interest. The need for basic secondary exposition was first supplied by the founding in 1977 of the series of books known as ‘Methuen New Accents’, which provided students with individual introductory books on structuralism, deconstruction, post-structuralism and the rest. An introductory overview of literary theory was also a necessity, and the first book to meet this need was Terry Eagleton’s Literary Theory: An Introduction, published by Blackwell in 1983. The book was an instant success because it was written in a lively and provocative manner, and resisted the temptation to produce a dense and elephantine tome – such a book might have impressed peers but would have been inappropriate for students seeking initial enlightenment. These qualities distinguished it from most of its successors, and from the course-book ‘readers’ in literary theory which began to appear from the late 1980s onwards. ‘Readers’ containing key articles and chapters by a range of major figures can be very useful if they are selective and if they try to meet the actual needs of their users, but such books succumbed long ago to competitive super-sizing, with publishing firms striving with each other in a ridiculous poker game to see who can produce the biggest theory reader (Publisher N to Publisher B: ‘I’ll see your thirteen hundred pages and raise you by another thirteen hundred’).

相比之下，伊格尔顿保持简单：他的介绍名为“什么是文学？” 第一章讲述了英语学兴起的历史；接下来的四章依次涉及现象学、结构主义、后结构主义和精神分析，结语的标题是“政治批评”。伊格尔顿毫不假装保持中立——他是一位马克思主义批评家，从坚定和明确的立场出发，而不是“主义”的啜饮者和品尝者，每一轮都喝了一会儿，然后转到下一轮。遗漏是惊人的——索引（这是 1983 年的）没有关于“女权主义”或“女权主义理论”的条目，例如，它似乎有些古怪（在一本名为《文学理论》的书中) 首先问“什么是文学？” 而不是“什么是文学理论？” 整个论点是有力但费力的：“什么是文学？”这个问题的答案。是文学“不存在于昆虫存在的意义上”。人们可能会不耐烦地反驳说，文学理论肯定存在，甚至可能在昆虫存在的意义上，因为伊格尔顿写了一本关于它的书。但文学理论的目的，对伊格尔顿来说，似乎是反文学的，这将它与文学批评区分开来，文学批评通常（人们会认为）站在文学一边。对他来说，理论的昆虫般的目的似乎是充当一种超级虫子，从内部攻击文学，目的是使其死亡（但如果文学不存在，它怎么会死？）。这就是伊格尔顿著名的寓言结局所提出的那种神学问题：

Eagleton, by contrast, kept it simple: his introduction is called ‘What is Literature?’ and the first chapter tells the history of the rise of English Studies; the next four chapters deal in turn with phenomenology, structuralism, post-structuralism, and psychoanalysis, and the Conclusion is entitled ‘Political Criticism’. Eagleton makes no pretence to neutrality – he is a Marxist critic writing from a committed and identified position, not a sipper and taster of ‘isms’ who swills each one round for a few moments and then passes on to the next one. The omissions are striking – the index (this is in 1983) has no entry on ‘feminism’ or ‘feminist theory’, for instance, and it seems somewhat eccentric (in a book called Literary Theory) to begin by asking ‘What is Literature?’ rather than ‘What is Literary Theory?’ The overall argument is vigorous but taxing: the answer to the question ‘What is Literature?’ is that literature ‘does not exist in the sense that insects do’. It might be retorted impatiently that literary theory must certainly exist, possibly even in the sense that insects do, since Eagleton has written a book about it. But literary theory’s purpose, for Eagleton, seems anti-literary, and that distinguishes it from literary criticism, which is usually (one would presume) on literature’s side. For him, theory’s insect-like purpose seems to be to act as a kind of super-bug, attacking literature from within, with the aim of bringing about its death (though if literature doesn’t exist, how can it die?). That is the kind of theological question which is posed by Eagleton’s famous allegorical ending:

我将以一个寓言结束。我们知道狮子比驯狮者强壮，驯狮者也是如此。问题是狮子不知道。文学之死或许有助于狮子的苏醒，这不无可能。
I shall end with an allegory. We know that the lion is stronger than the lion-tamer, and so does the lion-tamer. The problem is that the lion does not know it. It is not out of the question that the death of literature may help the lion to awaken.

正如约翰·贝利在他的《时代文学副刊》评论（1983 年 6 月 10 日）中所说，问题是“什么是狮子？” 想必，狮子就是无产阶级，驯狮者就是文学。所以理论的工作就是反对文学，剥夺文学镇压、安抚群众的力量。然而，伊格尔顿笔下的狮子似乎比他想象的要聪明，因为狮子知道驯狮者有鞭子，这就是使他比狮子强壮的原因。这个隐喻必须把文学想象成鞭子，把它看作是“意识形态国家机器”的一部分，它通过意识形态而不是武力来控制我们（见第8 章阿尔都塞的“ISA”概念）。伊格尔顿这本书的力量和影响在于它的整体活力、机智和思维敏捷性，以及它对大量思想体系的巧妙总结。例如，在他关于结构主义的章节中，他精辟地压缩了内容并提供了丰富的信息；在关于后结构主义的章节中，他提出了其他人在十多年后才开始讨论的问题；精神分析章节更为常规，他关于政治批评的最后一章毫不妥协地将他的马克思主义卡片正面朝上摆在桌面上，但以某种方式预见了二十年后他会全神贯注的伦理和道德问题——“这是什么意味着要成为一个“更好的人”，他说，“必须具体而实际”。那么，伊格顿的书，极大地促进了文学理论的“巩固”，并帮助将其牢固地确立在本科课程中，使导师相信有可能以系统的方式教授它。在这十个事件的历史中，它标志着理论兴起的顶点。

As John Bayley said in his Times Literary Supplement review (10 June 1983), the question is ‘What is the lion?’ Presumably, the lion is the proletariat, and the lion-tamer is literature. So the job of theory is to oppose literature and deprive it of its power to subdue and pacify the masses. Eagleton’s lion, however, seems wiser than he allows, for the lion knows that the lion-tamer has a whip, and that is what makes him stronger than the lion. The metaphor must envisage literature as the whip, seeing it as part of the ‘Ideological State Apparatus’, which controls us by ideology rather than force (see Chapter 8 for the Althusserian notion of the ‘ISA’). The power and impact of Eagleton’s book lay in its overall energy, wit, and mental agility, and in its deft summaries of large bodies of thought. He is brilliantly compressed and informative, for instance, in his chapter on structuralism; in the chapter on post-structuralism he raises the issues that others only got round to more than a decade later; the psychoanalysis chapter is more routine, and his final chapter on political criticism puts his Marxist cards uncompromisingly face-up on the table, but in a way that anticipates the ethical and moral issues which would pre-occupy him twenty years later – ‘What it means to be a “better person”’, he says, ‘must be concrete and practical’. Eagle-ton’s book, then, greatly contributed to the ‘consolidation’ of literary theory and helped to establish it firmly on the undergraduate curriculum, giving tutors confidence that it might be possible to teach it in a systematic way. In this ten-event history it marks the apex of the rise of theory.

J. Hillis Miller 的 MLA 总统演讲，1986 年

J. Hillis Miller’s MLA presidential address, 1986

阅读： “总统讲话，1986 年。理论的胜利、阅读的阻力和物质基础的问题。” PMLA（1987 年 5 月），102(3)：281-91；新历史学家 Louis Montrose 的回应，“宣扬文艺复兴：文化的诗学和政治”，转载于 Rivkin & Ryan，第 777-85 页。
Reading: ‘Presidential Address, 1986. The Triumph of Theory, the Resistance to Reading, and the Question of the Material Base.’ PMLA (May 1987), 102(3): 281–91; response by New Historicist Louis Montrose, ‘Professing the Renaissance: The Poetics and Politics of Culture’, reprinted in Rivkin & Ryan, pp. 777–85.

到20世纪80年代中期，文学理论即将衰落的征兆开始显现。一个关键时刻是 1986 年 J. Hillis Miller 的现代语言协会主席讲话。MLA 是美国大学英语教师的主要专业机构，其年度大会是该学科的重大活动。总统的主旨演讲是高潮，它采取一种“纪律状况”声明的形式，通常会指出未来的发展方向。希利斯米勒，作为《解构与批评》的“五大名著”之一，长期以来一直是解构主义的支持者，他的演讲表明他曾预计 80 年代初期的自信势头——当时解构主义似乎正在横扫美国著名的英语系——将会继续。然而，实际发生的事情似乎是一种新的相反力量正在检验理论。相反的力量是历史主义文学方法的兴起，它起源于早期现代主义研究领域，在美国由斯蒂芬格林布拉特的文艺复兴时期的自我塑造（1980）开始，在英国由乔纳森多利莫尔和艾伦辛菲尔德于 1985 年开始政治莎士比亚（见第 9 章）。正如希利斯米勒所意识到的那样，历史主义是解构主义的对立面，解构主义在 80 年代成为理论本身最突出的公开体现，取代了结构主义在 70 年代的地位。因此，米勒注意到（实际上）“理论的胜利”被令人遗憾的历史主义爆发打断了：

By the mid 1980s, symptoms of the coming decline of literary theory began to emerge. A key moment was the Modern Language Association’s presidential address by J. Hillis Miller in 1986. The MLA is the main professional body for university teachers of English in the USA, and its annual conventions are major events for the discipline. The keynote address from the president is the climax, and it takes the form of a kind of ‘state of the discipline’ pronouncement which will often point to future lines of development. Hillis Miller, as one of the ‘famous five’ authors of Deconstruction and Criticism, had long been a proponent of deconstruction, and his address shows that he had expected that the confident momentum of the early 1980s – when deconstruction seemed to be making a clean sweep of prestigious English departments in the USA – would continue. However, what was actually happening, it seemed, was that the dominance of theory was being checked by a new contrary force. The contrary force was the rise of historicist approaches to literature, emanating from the field of early modernist studies, and begun in the USA by Stephen Greenblatt’s Renaissance Self-Fashioning (1980) and in the UK by Jonathan Dollimore and Alan Sinfield’s Political Shakespeare in 1985 (see Chapter 9). Historicism, as Hillis Miller realised, is the polar opposite of deconstruction, which had become the most prominent public embodiment of theory itself in the 80s, taking over the status which structuralism had had in the 70s. So Miller noted that (in effect) the ‘Triumph of Theory’ was being interrupted by regrettable outbreaks of historicism:

过去几年的文学研究经历了一次突然的、几乎是普遍的从理论转向语言本身的转向，并相应地转向了历史、文化、社会、政治、制度、阶级和性别状况，社会背景，物质基础。（第 283 页）
Literary study in the past few years has undergone a sudden, almost universal turn away from theory in the sense of an orientation toward language as such and has made a corresponding turn toward history, culture, society, politics, institutions, class and gender conditions, the social context, the material base. (p. 283)

历史主义（与历史不同）是厌倦了理论的学术大众（大体上）所转向的，并且是更复杂的形式，需要大量的档案工作，跨学科研究中心的建立，以及追求跨机构合作。当他提出选择时，似乎很明显为什么许多人选择了希利斯米勒不赞成的一方，因为“历史、文化、社会、政治、制度、阶级和性别条件、社会背景、物质基础”听起来相当作为一个研究领域比（如米勒所说）“语言本身的方向”更有趣。本质上，解构文学理论认为学生应该研究“文学性”本身，而不是文学（即一般意义上的概念化过程，米德尔马奇）。在实践中，将这种“文学性本身”的概念转化为可行的本科课程一直是非常困难的，所有那些大象文学理论“读者”只是证明了这一点。同样，努力争取“对语言本身的定位”有点像在文学研究中试图看太阳——你不能看太久，它可能是有害的，你很快就会想看别处。研究历史、文化、性别状况等，要具体得多，并且翻译将学生想要遵循的兴趣范围纳入教学大纲并不是一项艰巨的任务。因此，潮流从解构主义转向历史主义并不是一个令人惊讶的趋势。

Historicism (as distinct from history) is what the theory-weary academic masses (in the main) moved on to, and to ever more elaborate forms of it, entailing extensive archival work, the setting up of interdisciplinary research centres, and the pursuit of cross-institutional collaborations. As he presents the choice, it might seem rather obvious why many were choosing the side that Hillis Miller disapproved of, for ‘history, culture, society, politics, institutions, class and gender conditions, the social context, the material base’ sound rather more interesting as a field of study than (as Miller phrased it) ‘an orientation toward language as such’. Essentially, deconstructive literary theory believed that students should study ‘literariness’ itself, rather than literature (that is, the process of the conceptualisation of meaning in general, rather than the specific meanings of, for example, Middlemarch). In practice, it has always been very difficult to translate this notion of ‘literariness itself’ into a viable undergraduate curriculum, and all those elephantine literary theory ‘readers’ merely demonstrate that this is so. Likewise, striving for ‘an orientation towards language as such’ is a bit like trying to look at the sun in literary studies – you can’t do it for long, it can be damaging, and you very quickly want to look elsewhere. Studying history, culture, gender conditions, and the rest, is much more concrete, and translating that range of interests into a syllabus which students would want to follow isn’t such a difficult task. So the turning of the tide away from deconstruction and towards historicism was not really a surprising trend.

但此时我们需要问的是，历史主义和历史之间的区别到底是什么？好吧，历史学家可能会通过勤奋的研究来恢复过去，让我们再次走在莎士比亚笔下伦敦的街道上，去剧院看哈姆雷特的表演。我们将知道街道的样子，闻到气味，听到声音，并知道我们手中究竟需要什么硬币才能进入剧院。（当然，这是斯蒂芬在乔伊斯的《尤利西斯》的“Scylla and Charybdis”部分中的知识幻想。）请注意，这些是外在的物质事物，代表了历史研究所揭示的内容。这种调查的最终结局可能是 Bankside Globe在伦敦，一座尽可能真实的伊丽莎白时代的剧院，我们现在可以去那里并获得近似的体验，像当地人一样站在露天，甚至可以听到伊丽莎白时代听到的英语声音，如果我们参加的表演是在'Old Pronunciation'中（当然，你必须能够忽略喷气式飞机飞入希思罗机场的持续噪音）。但历史主义者并不真正喜欢像 Bankside Globe 这样的企业，因为最终，这种外在的、物质的东西不是他们的目标。历史学家对内部事物感兴趣。他们对伊丽莎白时代在剧院里看到的东西不太感兴趣，而更关心在剧院里看到的感觉伊丽莎白时代在那里看到的。他们也对我们所说的“身份”感兴趣——包括“早期现代身份”、“性别身份”和“民族身份”——也就是说，不仅仅是外在的和物质的东西，而是更深层次的东西，它弥漫或超越了时代的面料。“谁在乎”，我能听到他们说，“伊丽莎白时代的人穿什么样的衬衫，或者他们的英语发音如何——我想了解成为伊丽莎白时代的。因此，历史主义者主要对“话语”、“情感结构”、“心态”和“身份”感兴趣，而且在我看来，他们通常比“真正的”历史学家更有信心，因为这些基本但无形的要素过去是可以恢复的。与历史学家不同，历史主义者想要直接进入那个“身份”层面，而不需要历史学家进行的所有无聊的考古工作。花大部分时间做。“历史学家总是唯物主义者，历史主义者总是唯心主义者”，正如莫里斯·扎普（大卫·洛奇小说中的文学理论家英雄）所说的那样。我认为，希利斯米勒在他的演讲中忽略了历史学家和历史主义者之间的区别，而将历史主义的对立力量视为代表了一种 Gradgrindian 对事实的兴趣，他自然无法理解这如何能够在兴趣上与对历史的迷恋相竞争“语言本身”。当我读到这第六个事件时，它是理论的巨大而迅速的成功开始引起某种自满情绪的时刻的征兆。它对英国和美国享有特权的机构的巨大影响导致它低估了其他方法的吸引力，

But what exactly, we need to ask at this point, is the difference between historicism and history? Well, a historian might seek through diligent research to recover the past, and enable us to walk again the streets of Shakespeare’s London, making for the playhouse to see a performance of Hamlet. We will know how the streets looked, smell the smells, hear the sounds, and know what coins exactly we need to have in our hands in order to get into the theatre. (This is Stephen’s intellectual fantasy in the ‘Scylla and Charybdis’ section of Joyce’s Ulysses, of course.) These, notice, are external, material things, representative of what historical research uncovers. The ultimate end of such enquiry might be the Bankside Globe in London, an Elizabethan theatre as authentic as we can make it, where we can now go and have an approximation of that experience, standing in the open air as the groundlings did, and even hearing the sounds of English as the Elizabethans heard them if the performance we attend is in ‘Old Pronunciation’ (of course, you have to be able to ignore the constant noise of jets flying into Heathrow). But historicists don’t really like enterprises like the Bankside Globe, because, in the end, such external, material things are not their goal. Historicists are interested in internal things. They are less interested in what the Elizabethans saw in the theatre, than in how it felt to see what Elizabethans saw there. They are interested, too, in what we call ‘identities’ – including ‘early modern identities’, ‘gender identities’ and ‘national identities’ – that is to say, not mere external and material things but something deeper which suffuses or transcends the material fabric of the era. ‘Who cares’, I can hear them say, ‘what kind of shirts the Elizabethans wore, or how they pronounced English – I want to understand how it felt to be Elizabethan’. So historicists are primarily interested in ‘discourses’, ‘structures of feeling’, ‘mind-sets’, and ‘identities’, and they seem to me much more confident than ‘real’ historians usually are that such fundamental and yet intangible elements of the past are recoverable. Unlike historians, historicists want to go straight to that ‘identity’ level, without all the boring archeological spadework that historians spend most of their time doing. ‘Historians are always materialists, historicists are always idealists’, as Maurice Zapp (the literary-theorist hero of David Lodge’s novels) would have said. Hillis Miller, I think, ignores the distinction between historians and historicists in his address, and sees the opposing force of historicism as representing just a kind of Gradgrindian interest in facts, and he naturally cannot understand how that could compete in interest with the fascination of ‘language as such’. As I read this sixth event, then, it is symptomatic of the moment when theory’s enormous and rapid success began to induce a certain complacency. Its huge impact at highly privileged institutions in the UK and the USA caused it both to under-estimate the appeal of other approaches, and over-estimate the likely intellectual shelf-life of its own ideas.

思克莱德大学“写作语言学”

会议，1986 年

The Strathclyde University ‘Linguistics of Writing’

conference, 1986

阅读： “会议之书”是写作语言学：语言与文学之间的争论，编辑。Nigel Fabb、Derek Attridge、Alan Durant 和 Colin MacCabe（曼彻斯特大学出版社，1987 年）。1987 年 11 月 22 日，大卫·洛奇 (David Lodge) 编写并制作了一部关于该事件的电视纪录片，名为“大话小世界”( Big Words Small Worlds)，并在第 4 频道播出。
Reading: The ‘book of the conference’ is The Linguistics of Writing: Arguments Between Language and Literature, ed. Nigel Fabb, Derek Attridge, Alan Durant and Colin MacCabe (Manchester University Press, 1987). A TV documentary film about the event, called Big Words Small Worlds, was written and presented by David Lodge and broadcast on Channel 4, on 22 November 1987.

1987 年夏天在格拉斯哥举行了一场引人注目的文学理论会议，许多最杰出的理论家都作为演讲者，文学理论可能再次变得有点自满的感觉似乎再次显现出来。回想起来，这次会议似乎既是理论达到其魅力和成功顶峰的时刻，同时也是某种必胜主义开始激起异议和抵抗的时代的开始，而这种异议和抵抗不仅仅来自顽固的传统主义者。我现在认为那件事很像英国工党臭名昭著的“谢菲尔德集会”，这是在 1992 年大选之前举行的政治大会，当时工党在民意调查中遥遥领先。很遗憾，在取得任何胜利之前，拉力赛在电视上被视为过早的胜利庆祝活动。民意调查的领先优势消失了，工党的结果是又五年在野。同样的凯旋之气斯特拉斯克莱德的庆祝活动很明显，奇怪的是，它还试图重振语言学的声望，因为这次会议是由斯特拉斯克莱德大学文学语言学项目组织的，并试图重复和重新创造传奇的“关于语言学的会议”的影响。 1958 年在印第安纳州举行的 Style'（这里讨论的第一个理论事件）。因此，回顾印第安纳会议，这次会议以“闭幕词”开场，以“开场词”结束，仿佛确信它正在启动一个全新的理论时代。然而，这些会议并不总是有区别的：在我看来，一些著名的语言学家似乎非常单一学科，从这个意义上说，他们与印第安纳州传福音的跨学科性倒退了一步。大卫·洛奇 (David Lodge) 在他关于巴赫金的演讲开始时，

The sense that literary theory was perhaps becoming a little complacent again seemed in evidence when a high-profile conference on literary theory took place in Glasgow in the summer of 1987, with many of the most prominent theorists as speakers. In retrospect, the conference seems both the point when theory reached the height of its glamour and success, and at the same time the beginning of the era when a certain triumphalism began to provoke dissent and resistance which wasn’t just coming from diehard traditionalists. I think of that event now as being rather like the British Labour Party’s infamous ‘Sheffield Rally’, which was a political convention mounted just before the General Election of 1992 when Labour was well ahead in the polls. Unfortunately, the Rally came across on TV as a premature victory celebration before any victory had been achieved. The poll lead evaporated and the result for the Labour Party was another five years in opposition. The same air of triumphal celebration was in evidence at Strathclyde, curiously mixed with an attempt to revive the prestige of linguistics, for the conference was organised by the Programme in Literary Linguistics at Strathclyde University, and sought to repeat and re-create the impact of the legendary ‘Conference on Style’ at Indiana in 1958 (the first theory event discussed here). So in reference back to the Indiana conference, this one opened with a ‘Closing Statement’, and closed with an ‘Opening Statement’, as if confident that it was setting in motion a whole new era of theory. Yet the sessions were not always distinguished: several of the famous linguists seemed very mono-disciplinary to me, and they were in that sense a step backwards from the evangelistic interdisciplinarity of Indiana. David Lodge, at the start of his lecture on Bakhtin, reminded us that one of the Indiana sessions had been a densely statistical and tabular paper on stylistic deviations in suicide notes, and as it went on, the Glasgow conference began to seem more and more like a lengthy suicide note for literary theory.

德里达发表了他的演讲“如何避免说话”，这是一篇关于消极神学的特别费力和无情的演讲，据我所知，演讲持续了将近两个小时，最后半小时不断被演讲厅的声音打断当观众精疲力尽地离开礼堂时，门打开和关闭。这个演讲不在会议的书中，我想是因为德里达已经在别处承诺过，但他也给出了一个问答环节，作为“一些问题和回应”包含在书中（第 252-64 页） . 这次会议的形式是，问题在前一天写好并交给主席，主席将问题转交给德里达，让他有时间考虑他的回答。在活动中，主席宣读了每个问题，然后德里达回答说，据我所知，这不是来自广泛的书面笔记，而是事先考虑过的好处，使其在感觉上类似于当今通过电子邮件进行的采访。我对这次会议的记忆首先是德里达的机智和魅力，其次是他宣布他从未说过或认为存在的形而上学是邪恶的——“我倾向于认为恰恰相反”，这让听众大吃一惊。 ，这很好'（p. 257）。人们花了几分钟时间来理解所讲内容的含义：如果在场的形而上学很好，为什么要花整个职业生涯来寻求解构它？这正是 Jonathan Culler 现在在场上问他的问题（会议偏离了书面问题）。答案本质上是神学的：对存在的渴望是自然的，但要实现它“将是死亡本身”（第 260 页），因此人们不得不解构它，继续表明我们误认为是完全存在的东西有些东西真的是延异的闪光。这导致了在他熟悉和习惯性陈述之后的几年里发生的事情，即“解构不是一种方法”，它“不存在于一套方法论规则中”（第 262 页）。当然，我没有从表面上接受这个说法，所以我相信试图在第 3 章中展示和量化解构实践。毕竟，德里达确实说它“有一些方法论的影响”（262），尽管没有解释这与作为一种方法究竟有何不同。总的来说，这是一场令人印象深刻的表演，但它确实预示着他职业生涯的剩余岁月，他总是乐于说出解构主义（或其他任何东西）不是什么，但似乎从来没有能力或不愿意解释解构主义是什么曾是。理论界越来越倾向于声称人们误解了他所说的话，或者过于照字面理解，或者以天真或简单化的方式理解，这种抱怨不断得到他的支持者的回应。当人们争辩说他在某件事上错了时，得到的回应总是他不是他说的那样，也不是他想表达的意思。

Derrida gave his lecture ‘How to Avoid Speaking’, a particularly taxing and relentless address on negative theology, which lasted, as I recall, for nearly two hours, the last half hour of which was constantly punctuated by the sound of the lecture-theatre doors opening and closing as members of the audience left the auditorium in exhaustion. This lecture is not in the book of the conference, I think because Derrida had already promised it elsewhere, but he also gave a question and answer session which is included in the book as ‘Some questions and responses’ (pp. 252–64). The format for this session was that questions had been written out the day before and handed to the chairperson, who passed them on to Derrida, giving him time to consider his response. At the event each question was read out by the chair and then Derrida responded, not from extensive written notes, so far as I could tell, but anyway with the benefit of prior consideration, making it similar in feel to a present-day interview conducted by e-mail. My memories of this session are firstly of Derrida’s wit and charm, and secondly, of the way he startled his audience by announcing that he had never said or thought that the metaphysics of presence was evil – ‘I’m inclined to think exactly the contrary, that it’s good’ (p. 257). It took some minutes for people to take in the implications of what had been said: if the metaphysics of presence is good, why spend a whole career seeking to deconstruct it? That was precisely what Jonathan Culler now asked him from the floor (the session drifted away from the written questions). The answer was essentially theological: the desire for presence is natural, but to accomplish it ‘would be death itself’ (p. 260), so one is compelled to deconstruct it, to keep on showing that what we mistake for the full presence of something is really the shimmer of différance. This leads to what became in the years which followed a familiar and habitual statement of his, that ‘Deconstruction is not a method’, it ‘doesn’t consist in a set of methodological rules’ (p. 262). Of course, I haven’t taken this statement at face value, so I do seek to demonstrate and quantify deconstructive practice in Chapter 3. After all, Derrida does say that it ‘has some methodological effects’ (262), though without explaining how exactly that is different from being a method. Overall, it was an impressive performance, but it did give a foretaste of the remaining years of his career, in which he was always happy to say what deconstruction (or anything else) was not, but never seemed able or willing to explain what it was. There was a growing tendency within the theory world to claim that people had misunderstood what he said, or had taken it too literally, or in a naïve or simplistic way, and this complaint was constantly echoed by his supporters. When people argued that he was wrong about something, the response was always that that wasn’t what he had said, or what he had meant.

随着会议的进行，挫败感越来越大。把这个活动拍成电视电影似乎是绝招（这不是最初计划的一部分），但灯光和麦克风是有干扰的，甚至在喝咖啡的时候，摄制组都带着他们的巨人聚集在大牌周围麦克风嗡嗡作响，如果他们在会议上提出问题，他们会拿着发布表冲向代表们签名。最后一天早上的“开场白”被在场的人打断了，他们想发表意见，尤其是关于会议程序暴露的高度分裂的权力结构。代表们投票决定关闭演播室的灯光，并让摄制组离开房间，这一切都以参差不齐的方式结束，响亮的“开场白”失去了影响力。

As the conference went on, frustrations built up. It had seemed a masterstroke to get a TV film made of the event (which hadn’t been part of the original plan), but lights and microphones are intrusive, and even at coffee time the camera crews clustered round the big names with their giant microphone booms, and rushed up to delegates with release forms to sign if they had asked a question at a session. The ‘Opening Statement’ on the final morning was interrupted from the floor by people who wanted their say, not least about the highly divisive power structures which the proceedings had laid all too bare. Delegates voted for the studio lights to be turned off and for the camera crew to leave the room, and it all ended rather raggedly, with the resounding ‘Opening Statement’ losing its impact.

出了什么问题？当然，有太多的大型全体会议（几乎都是美国和英国的男性发言人）和回复由同一组主导，几乎没有空间或时间进行公开和民主的交流。不管它的信息在社会上多么进步，文学理论的方法也必须在社会上进步。几乎是在不知不觉中，在几年的时间里，理论家们已经成为学术界的新机构和新精英，他们似乎太想当然了。就像工党的影子部长们乘坐一队伪部长级的黑色豪华轿车前来参加运气不佳的谢菲尔德集会一样，这些知名人士突然看起来似乎把理论的胜利看成是既成事实。

What had gone wrong? Certainly, there were too many big plenary sessions (nearly all by American and British male speakers) and the responses were dominated by the same group, leaving very little space or time for open and democratic exchange. No matter how socially progressive its message, literary theory has to be socially progressive in its methods too. Almost without realising it, and in the space of a few years, theorists had become the new establishment and the new elite of the academic world, and they seemed to be taking their position too much for granted. Like the Labour shadow-ministers arriving for the ill-starred Sheffield Rally in a cavalcade of pseudo-ministerial black limousines, the big names suddenly looked as if they were treating the triumph of theory a little too much like a fait accompli.

保罗·德曼 (Paul de Man) 战时著作的丑闻，1987–88

The scandal over Paul de Man’s wartime writings, 1987–88

阅读： “耶鲁学者为亲纳粹报纸撰稿”，纽约时报， 1987 年 12 月 1 日， p. 1 . Paul de Man：战时新闻，1939-43，编辑。Werner Hamacher、Neil Hertz 和 Tom Keenan，内布拉斯加大学出版社，1988 年。Jacques Derrida，“就像贝壳深处的大海之声：保罗·德曼的战争”， Critical Inquiry 14，1988 年春季，第 590-652 页. 有关对这篇文章的“批评性回应”，请参阅第 15 期，1989 年夏季，第 765–811 页。德里达对回应的回复是“可生物降解：七篇日记片段”，第 812-73 页。
Reading: ‘Yale Scholar Wrote for Pro-Nazi Newspaper’, New York Times, 1 December 1987, p. 1. Paul de Man: Wartime Journalism, 1939–43, ed. Werner Hamacher, Neil Hertz, and Tom Keenan, University of Nebraska Press, 1988. Jacques Derrida, ‘Like the Sound of the Sea Deep within a Shell: Paul de Man’s War’, Critical Inquiry 14, Spring 1988, pp. 590–652. For ‘Critical Responses’ to this piece, see issue 15, Summer 1989, pp. 765–811. Derrida’s reply to the responses is ‘Biodegradables: Seven Diary Fragments’, pp. 812–73.

我们已经讨论过“著名的五位”耶鲁大学解构主义者，他们是 1979 年《解构与批评》的联合作者，其中之一是出生于比利时的保罗·德曼 (Paul de Man)（1919-1983）。他的三部著作—— 《盲目与洞察》（1971 年）、《阅读的寓言》（1979 年）和《理论的抵抗》（1986 年）——具有很大的影响力，在他去世时，他作为文学严谨的知识分子体现而备受尊崇解构。但在 1987 年，《纽约时报》的一篇文章透露，作为 1940 年代初期在纳粹占领的比利时的一名年轻人，他为《晚报》撰写了近 200 篇明显反犹太主义的文章– 有关材料本身，请参阅Paul de Man：Wartime Journalism，1939-43。最初的发现是由 Ortwin de Graef 做出的，他是一名比利时学生，一直在研究德曼的早期生活和工作。尽管此案令人震惊，但损害解构主义和文学理论地位的主要不是德曼的个人罪行或其他原因，但其他理论家试图为他辩护的理由。在我看来，特别适得其反的是德里达在《批判性探究》杂志上发表的冗长文章，他最初为德曼辩护长达 75 页，而他对这些回应的回应又长达 60 页。

We have already discussed the ‘famous five’ Yale University deconstructionists who were joint authors of Deconstruction and Criticism in 1979, one of whom was Belgian-born Paul de Man (1919–1983). His trio of books – Blindness and Insight (1971), Allegories of Reading (1979) and The Resistance to Theory (1986) – have been highly influential, and he was much revered at the time of his death as the austere intellectual embodiment of literary deconstruction. But in 1987 an article in the New York Times revealed that as a young man in Nazi-occupied Belgium in the early 1940s he had written nearly two hundred articles of a markedly anti-semitic kind for the newspaper Le Soir – for the material itself see Paul de Man: Wartime Journalism, 1939–43. The original discoveries were made by Ortwin de Graef, who was a Belgian student who had been doing research on de Man’s early life and work. Though the case was shocking, it was not primarily the personal guilt or otherwise of de Man which damaged the standing of deconstruction and of literary theory in general, but the grounds on which other theorists attempted to defend him. Especially counterproductive, in my view, were Derrida’s lengthy articles in the journal Critical Inquiry, his original defence of de Man being seventy-five pages long, and his response to the responses a further sixty pages.

德里达开始思考，询问是否有可能回答问题，这样做可能意味着什么，这是否意味着承担责任，以及责任是什么。很明显，以这种方式进行的辩护将花费很长时间，而且真正需要的是德里达永远无法提供的东西——清晰、简洁、简洁以及坚定的信念和同情心。问题同样在于，辩护人的立场是不可能的：最好的“辩护”可能是将这些作品全部发表，以便将它们记录在案，简要地说出可以缓解的一切——德曼的青春，他可能至少在开始时，不知道欧洲犹太人的实际情况，以及可能存在的威胁或危险，所以他可能是出于恐惧而不是信念而行事。这可能并不多，但我认为这实际上是可以完成的所有工作。以前的朋友和同事没有必要也不应该反对他并谴责他，但他们也没有必要为他辩护。从理智上讲，理论家们可能会觉得，如果德曼不为自己辩护，那么解构主义和文学理论就会随着他的声誉而沉沦，但对他的辩护似乎是出于自利的职业动机，这将证明是极具破坏性的。作为朋友，德里达确实觉得有必要为德曼辩护，但他似乎为此使用了解构主义的所有微妙之处，以至于所有那些关于语言不可靠的信念，以及真理和真理概念的脆弱性自己，被发挥作用。结果是不可避免的——这些概念本身在道德上似乎是可疑的，因为质疑责任概念本身似乎会滑向否认我们对自己的言行负责。在 1940 年代写道，“旨在建立一个与欧洲隔绝的犹太人殖民地的犹太人问题解决方案不会对西方的文学生活造成可悲的后果”，这让公众支持（充其量）驱逐出境，而且它考虑到德曼后来的文学生涯，这一点尤其令人震惊学术上，他支持反犹太主义作为文学知识分子。那时，文学理论因德曼事件而受到严重损害，此后它再也没有完全恢复其声望、信心以及道德和政治正直感。

Derrida begins speculatively, asking whether it is possible to respond to questions, what it might mean to do so, whether that would imply taking responsibility, and what responsibility is. It is at once evident that a defence conducted in this way is going to take a very long time, and also that what is really required is what Derrida was never able to supply – clarity, concision, brevity, and strength of conviction and compassion. The problem, too, is that the defender’s position is an impossible one: the best ‘defence’ might be to publish these writings entire so that they are on the record, saying briefly whatever can be said in mitigation – de Man’s youth, his possible ignorance, at least at the start, of what was actually happening to Jews in Europe, and that there may have been threats or dangers, so that he might have been acting out of fear rather than conviction. This might not amount to much, but I think it is actually all that could have been done. It would be neither necessary nor right for former friends and colleagues to turn against him and denounce him, but nor need they feel obliged to defend him. Intellectually, theorists might feel that if de Man remained undefended then deconstruction and literary theory would sink with his reputation, but defences of him which seemed to be motivated by that self-interested professional motive would prove highly damaging. As a friend, Derrida did feel the need to defend de Man, but he seemed to be using all the subtleties of deconstruction in order to do so, so that all those convictions about the unreliability of language, and the fragility of notions of truth and the self, were brought into play. The result was inevitable – such concepts begin to seem themselves morally suspect, for questioning the very concept of responsibility seems to glide towards denying that we are responsible for what we do and say. To write in the 1940s that ‘A solution to the Jewish problem that aimed at the creation of a Jewish colony isolated from Europe would entail no deplorable consequences for the literary life of the West’ gives public support for (at best) deportations, and it is especially shocking, in view of de Man’s subsequent career as a literary academic, that he endorses anti-semitism as a literary intellectual. Literary theory, then, was seriously compromised by the de Man affair, and thereafter it never quite recovered its prestige, its confidence and its sense of moral and political rectitude.

让·鲍德里亚和“海湾战争从未发生”，1991

Jean Baudrillard and ‘The Gulf War never happened’, 1991

阅读： Jean Baudrillard，海湾战争没有发生， Power Publications，悉尼，1995 年。Christopher Norris，非批判性理论：后现代主义、知识分子和海湾战争（Lawrence 和 Wishart，1992 年）。
Reading: Jean Baudrillard, The Gulf War Did Not Take Place, Power Publications, Sydney, 1995. Christopher Norris, Uncritical Theory: Postmodernism, Intellectuals, and the Gulf War (Lawrence and Wishart, 1992).

作为 1991 年初首次发表的三篇论文的结果，让·鲍德里亚（Jean Baudrillard，1929-2007 年）在大众的想象中被称为臭名昭著的法国后现代主义哲学家，他声称相信（第一次）海湾战争从未发生过。这三篇文章（分别）写于战争开始前、进行中和结束后，最初于 1991 年 1 月、2 月和 3 月发表在法国《解放报》上，随后三篇文章一起再版法语为La Guerre du Golfe n'as pas eu lieu，英语翻译为海湾战争没有发生。鲍德里亚被西方在海湾地区的外交政策强加于人，他使用有力而极端的言辞来表达自己的观点。语气粗暴无礼，就像十八世纪乔纳森·斯威夫特抨击政治腐败和社会自欺欺人时的言辞。对于鲍德里亚来说，发生的事情不是一场战争——他说，在涉及的 50 万西方士兵中，如果他们留在家中，死于交通事故的人数将多于伤亡人数（第 69 页），估计有 100,000 人伤亡（第 69 页）。 2）都在一侧。这代表了“完全不对称的操作”（第 19 页），但值得注意的是“事件的诱饵，战争的诱饵实现了淫秽的催情功能”（第 75 页）). 性意象逐渐增多：“战争像一场长长的脱衣舞一样展开”（第 77 页），被称为“外科手术战争”，并以“智能武器”的机鼻摄像机转播的镜头为代表目标。战争变成的媒体事件没有显示实际人员伤亡，而是以“外科手术式打击”的“干净”技术图像为代表。但战争的脱衣舞以电视画面达到高潮战争结束时撤退的伊拉克军队在巴士拉路上遭到可怕而无情的轰炸，具有讽刺意味的是，也许这一事件最持久的形象是 Ken Jarecke 广泛发表的照片，照片中一名被烧毁的伊拉克士兵被烧毁轰炸后的车辆。

As a result of three essays first published early in 1991, Jean Baudrillard (1929–2007) became known, in the popular imagination, as the notorious French postmodernist philosopher who professed to believe that the (first) Gulf War never happened. The three essays were written (respectively) just before the war started, while it was in progress, and just after it ended, and were originally published in the French newspaper Libération in January, February, and March 1991, all three then being republished together in French as La Guerre du Golfe n’as pas eu lieu, and in English translation as The Gulf War Did Not Take Place. Baudrillard was implacably imposed to Western foreign policy in the Gulf, and he uses a powerful and extreme rhetoric to make his points. The tone is savage and offensive, like the rhetoric of Jonathan Swift in the eighteenth century when he is attacking political corruption and social self-deception. For Baudrillard, what happened was not a war – of the half million Western soldiers involved, he says, more would have died in traffic accidents had they stayed at home than became casualties (p. 69), and the estimated 100,000 casualties (p. 2) were all on one side. This represents an ‘entirely asymmetrical operation’ (p. 19), but what is notable is ‘the obscene aphrodisiac function fulfilled by the decoy of the event, by the decoy of war’ (p. 75). The sexual imagery builds up: ‘the war has unfolded like a long striptease’ (p. 77), billed as a ‘surgical war’, and typified by the footage relayed from the nose-cameras of ‘smart weapons’ homing in on their targets. The media event which the war became showed no actual human casualties, and was typified by ‘clean’ technological images of ‘surgical strikes’. But the striptease of the war culminated with television images of the horrific and merciless bombing of the retreating Iraqi army on the Basra Road at the end of the war, and the irony is that perhaps the most lasting image of the event is Ken Jarecke’s widely-published photograph of an incinerated Iraqi soldier in a burned out vehicle after the bombardment.

从文学理论的角度来看，鲍德里亚的海湾战争随笔的最大讽刺之处在于，它们成为了他们所诊断的条件的受害者。就像图像或“拟像”一样（见第 4 章) 战争，在鲍德里亚的指责中，被错误地理解为战争本身，所以人们认为鲍德里亚写的东西的流行观点被他实际写的东西所取代。因此，他成为反理论家的替罪羊和高道德立场谴责后现代主义的目标，现在，在 1990 年代，后现代主义被视为一般文学理论的代表（遵循语言学在 1990 年代的顺序） 1960年代，70年代的结构主义，80年代的解构主义）。在他所说的漫画或“模拟版本”中，这位超级聪明的后现代主义者对现实的概念争论不休，对毫无疑问发生的痛苦和死亡漠不关心（我们被愤怒地告知），即使鲍德里亚认为海湾战争没有。如果我们从怀疑海湾战争的真实性开始，

From the point-of-view of literary theory, the great irony of Baudrillard’s Gulf War essays is that they became victims of the very condition they diagnosed. Just as the image, or ‘simulacrum’ (see Chapter 4) of the war, in Baudrillard’s accusation, was wrongly taken to be the war itself, so the popular view of what Baudrillard was thought to have written was substituted for what he actually wrote. Hence, he became the whipping-boy of anti-theorists and the target for high-moral-ground condemnations of postmodernism, which was now, in the 1990s, being seen as representative of literary theory in general (following the sequence of linguistics in the 1960s, structuralism in the 70s, and deconstruction in the 80s). In the caricature or ‘simulacrum version’ of what he had said, the hyper-clever postmodernist quibbled about notions of reality and was indifferent to the suffering and death that (we were indignantly informed) had undoubtedly taken place, even if Baudrillard thought the Gulf War hadn’t. If we start by doubting the reality of the Gulf War, it was now suggested, won’t we end by doubting the reality of Holocaust?

德曼事件对理论的真正损害是由他的捍卫者造成的，而鲍德里亚事件的损害部分是由他的攻击者造成的。曾就战时著作为德曼辩护的克里斯托弗·诺里斯对鲍德里亚有不同的看法，因为他现在果断地反对一般的“修辞形式主义”，尤其是后现代主义，认为理论的许多方面都是对理性客观性原则的放弃和真理有利于相对主义、共识和实用主义。结果是他愤怒而尖刻的书《不加批判的理论：后现代主义、知识分子和海湾战争》诞生了，因为在他看来，海湾战争的争论将所有这些问题推向了紧要关头。诺里斯（Norris）在事件发生时写下了激烈的事件，回应了《卫报》1991 年 1 月编辑的第一篇海湾战争文章。他把鲍德里亚的话理解为他们所说的字面意思（海湾战争不会发生），他说，这个命题已经轰炸的开始以经验为依据驳斥了这一点。正如他所说（他是对的），“也许观察鲍德里亚的预测完全错误会错过重点”（第 14 页）。鲍德里亚然后与现在成为诺里斯目标的理论家——理查德·罗蒂、斯坦利·菲什、福柯和其他人——混为一谈——所有这些“反认知主义者”都认为在任何给定情况下“真理”只能是价值观的问题某些现有“解释性”社区的成员之间恰好盛行的信念和信念（第 16 页）。将“现实”视为“一种纯粹的话语现象”（即，由代码、惯例、语言等构成）是同一事物的一部分，就像“普遍存在的误读”一样德里达的作品使他认为——以唯我论的方式——很简单，“文本之外没有任何东西”'（第 16 页，我的斜体）。令人费解的是，所谓对德里达的误读与诺里斯对鲍德里亚的误读似乎如出一辙。换句话说，诺里斯读到鲍德里亚的意思是，除了媒体对海湾战争的误传之外，几乎没有任何其他内容。但为什么要双重标准呢？为什么鲍德里亚只能按字面意思来解读，而德里达只能以比喻的方式来解读，以至于前者总是字面意思，而后者从来没有做？“后记（鲍德里亚的第二篇海湾战争文章）”做出了一些让步，但仍然以攻击鲍德里亚的“彻底的认知和认识论怀疑论”（第 196 页）作为结尾。

Whereas the real damage to theory in the de Man affair was caused by his defenders, the damage in the case of the Baudrillard episode was partly caused by his attackers. Christopher Norris, who had defended de Man over the wartime writings, felt differently about Baudrillard, for he had now turned decisively against ‘rhetorical formalism’ in general, and postmodernism in particular, seeing many aspects of theory as an abandonment of principles of rational objectivity and truth in favour of relativism, consensus and pragmatism. The result was his angry and scathing book Uncritical Theory: Postmodernism, Intellectuals and the Gulf War, for in his view the Gulf War controversy brought all these issues to a head. Norris wrote in the heat of events as they were happening, responding to the Guardian’s January 1991 edited version of the first Gulf War essay. He took Baudrillard’s words to mean literally what they said (that the Gulf War will not happen), a proposition, he says, already refuted on empirical grounds by the commencement of the bombing. As he says (and he’s right), ‘perhaps it would be missing the point to observe that Baudrillard’s predictions were flat wrong’ (p. 14). Baudrillard is then lumped in with the theorists who had now become Norris’s targets – Richard Rorty, Stanley Fish, Foucault and the rest – all those ‘anticognitivists’ who argue that ‘“truth” in any given situation can only be a matter of the values and beliefs that happen to prevail among members of some existing “interpretive” community’ (p.16). Seeing ‘reality’ as ‘a purely discursive phenomenon’ (that is, constructed by codes, conventions, language, etc.) is part of the same thing, as is ‘a prevalent misreading of Derrida’s work which takes him to be arguing – in solipsist fashion – that there is, quite simply “nothing outside the text”’ (p. 16, my italics). Puzzlingly, the alleged misreading of Derrida seems exactly the same as Norris’s misreading of Baudrillard. Norris, in other words, reads Baudrillard as saying that there is literally nothing outside the media misrepresentation of the Gulf War. But why the double standard? Why is Baudrillard to be read only literally, and Derrida only figuratively, so that the former always literally means what he says and the latter never does? The ‘Postscript (Baudrillard’s second Gulf War article)’ makes some concessions, but still ends by attacking Baudrillard’s ‘thoroughgoing cognitive and epistemological scepticism’ (p. 196).

尽管他的攻击很猛烈，但诺里斯和鲍德里亚肯定在本质上是一致的——他们都对西方在海湾地区无原则的残酷政策表示遗憾。鲍德里亚展示了事件是如何在发生时被重新制作的，以及“智能”武器和外科手术式打击的替代现实被提供给公众。实际上，正如鲍德里亚的观点，战争中使用的绝大多数武器都不是“智能”武器，它们的影响至今仍在体验。理论干预海湾战争的总体效果是它变得更加声名狼藉，因为它被视为（在我看来是非常错误的）承认真理和价值的绝对原则受到侵蚀，并支持巧妙地模糊世界和世界之间的界限、概念与知觉、现实与幻觉、想象与事件。

Fierce though his attack is, it is surely the case that Norris and Baudrillard are in essentially in agreement – both deplore the unprincipled cruelty of Western policy in the Gulf. Baudrillard shows how the event was re-made as it was happening, and a replacement reality of ‘smart’ weapons and surgical strikes was fed to the public. In reality, which was Baudrillard’s point, the vast majority of the weapons used in the war were anything but ‘smart’, and their effects are still being experienced today. The overall effect of theory’s intervention in the Gulf War is that it became further discredited because it was seen (quite wrongly in my view) as subscribing to the erosion of absolute principles of truth and value and supporting tricksy blurrings of the edges between word and world, concept and percept, reality and illusion, imagination and event. The theory ‘community’ had wrongly defended de Man and wrongly attacked Baudrillard, and a third ‘own goal’ was on the way.

索卡尔事件，1996

The Sokal affair, 1996

阅读：知识骗局：后现代哲学家对科学的滥用（Alan Sokal 和 Jean Bricmont，Profile Books，第 2 版，2003 年，1997 年首次以法语出版，1998 年以英语首次出版）。
Reading:Intellectual Impostures: Postmodern Philosophers’ Abuse of Science (Alan Sokal and Jean Bricmont, Profile Books, 2nd edn, 2003, first published in French in 1997 and in English in 1998).

1996 年，纽约大学物理学教授艾伦·索卡尔 (Alan Sokal) 写了一篇恶作剧文章，题为“超越边界：迈向量子引力的变革诠释学”，这篇文章主要由他认为是一堆后现代主义陈词滥调组成。他把它寄给了杜克大学的后现代主义文化研究期刊《社会文本》，正式接受并发表了这篇文章。在它出现的那天，他在另一本杂志上发表了一篇文章，揭露了这个骗局，并争辩说，接受原作暴露了后现代主义理论的空虚性，并且暗示所有文化理论，鉴于现在享有的卓越地位后现代主义。这个骗局成为一个著名且备受争议的事件，但与此直接相关的一个重要因素是文章中引用了德里达，后来又加入了公众对此的争论。

In 1996 Alan Sokal, a physics professor at New York University, wrote a hoax article, entitled ‘Transgressing the Boundaries: Towards a Transformative Hermeneutics of Quantum Gravity’, which was largely made up of what he considered to be a skein of postmodernist clichés. He sent it to Duke University’s postmodernist cultural studies journal Social Text, which duly accepted and published the piece. On the day it appeared he published an article in another journal revealing the hoax and arguing that the acceptance of the original piece exposed the vacuity of postmodernist theory, and, by implication, of all cultural theory, given the pre-eminent status now enjoyed by postmodernism. The hoax became a celebrated and much debated event, but a significant element of its immediate relevance here is that Derrida is quoted in the article and later joined in the public controversy about it.

原文转载于 Sokal 和 Bricmont 的著作Intellectual Impostures: Postmodern Philosophers' Abuse of Science，1998 年以英文出版。这本书和这篇文章并不是对后现代理论的全面攻击（尽管他们被广泛认为是那样），而是揭露法国著名理论家，尤其是拉康，对物理学和数学思想的滥用， Kristeva、Irigaray、Baudrillard、Deleuze 和 Guattari 等人。从广义上讲，法国理论家借用的科学和数学思想似乎证实了“建构主义”或“相对主义”的现实概念（例如，海森堡的“不确定性原理”、哥德尔关于不完备性的论文、爱因斯坦的相对论等在）。索卡尔说，这意味着大量后现代“行话”似乎没有非常简洁或“严谨”的含义，因此，该领域重要期刊的编辑无法认识到，已批准的术语和表述被混合和相乘，以产生一篇没有整体连贯性或逻辑的文章。如果当骗局被揭露时，编辑们只是简单地承认他们犯了一个错误并且需要加强他们的审稿程序，那么整个业务可能很快就结束了。但他们没有，随后迅速升级——有关索卡尔关于争议的综合参考书目，请参阅http://physics.nyu.edu/sokal//#impostures。

The original article is reproduced in Sokal and Bricmont’s book Intellectual Impostures: Postmodern Philosophers’ Abuse of Science, published in English in 1998. The book and the article are not a wholesale attack on postmodern theory (though they were widely taken to be that) but an exposure of the misuse of ideas derived from physics and mathematics by prominent French theorists, notably Lacan, Kristeva, Irigaray, Baudrillard, Deleuze and Guattari, and others. Broadly, the scientific and mathematical ideas borrowed by the French theorists are those which seem to validate ‘constructivist’ or ‘relativist’ notions of reality (for instance, Heisenberg’s ‘Uncertainty Principle’, Godel’s thesis regarding incompleteness, Einstein’s Theory of Relativity, and so on). The implication, says Sokal, is that a good deal of postmodern ‘jargon’ seems to have no very concise or ‘rigorous’ meaning, and that consequently the editors of an important journal in the field were unable to recognise that the approved terms and formulations were being mixed and multiplied to produce an article which had no overall coherence or logic. If, when the hoax was revealed, the editors had simply acknowledged that they had made a mistake and needed to tighten up their refereeing procedures, then the whole business might have blown over very quickly. But they didn’t, and a rapid escalation followed – for Sokal’s comprehensive bibliography of the controversy see http://physics.nyu.edu/sokal//#impostures.

因为控告者是美国人，几乎所有被控是法国人，这场骗局被视为对法国知识分子地位的攻击，Julia Kristeva（书中批评最严厉的思想家之一）在法国报纸Le Nouvel Observateur（ 1997 年 9 月 25 日，第 122 页），认为在一段时期的亲法之后，钟摆又向另一个方向摆回，现在在美国目睹的是“ une véritable francophobie ”（“真正的法语恐惧症”）。德里达不是在原始文章或书中受到持续批评的思想家之一，但在文章中他是第一个被引用的理论家，引用被描述为“文章的第一个主要的胡言乱语引用”（智力骗局， p。244）。引用，相当奇怪，来自德里达在 1966 年对让·伊波利特的问题的即兴回答（如上所述），德里达在评论索卡尔事件时提到了这一点（最初发表在世界报，并在他的书《造纸机》中转载（斯坦福大学出版社，2005 年，第 70-2 页）。与他对德曼案的干预相比，德里达的评论很简短：通常被引用的只是“可怜的索卡尔”这句话，指的是一位物理学家的困境，他以骗局而不是物理学而闻名。但德里达也从民族主义的角度看待这件事——在美国，作为“外国教授”给予自己的“荣誉”被认为是过分的，所以他现在和其他法国作家一起被攻击为一个错误（使用一种从科学和数学中提取的松散方式隐喻）当然不能仅限于法国人。他说，他想进一步评论“美国背景和政治背景”，但他没有空间这样做。

Because the accuser was American and nearly all the accused French, the hoax was seen as an attack on the standing of French intellectuals, and Julia Kristeva (one of the thinkers most harshly criticised in the book) responded in the French newspaper Le Nouvel Observateur (25 September 1997, p. 122) with the view that after a period of Francophilia, the pendulum had swung back in the other direction, and what was now being witnessed in the USA was ‘une véritable francophobie’ (‘genuine francophobia’). Derrida is not one of the thinkers subjected to sustained criticism in either the original article or the book, but in the article he is the first theorist to be quoted, and the quotation is described as ‘the article’s first major gibberish quote’ (Intellectual Impostures, p. 244). The quotation, rather oddly, is from Derrida’s off-the-cuff response to questions from Jean Hyppolite, back in 1966 (as discussed above), and Derrida refers to this when he comments on the Sokal affair (originally in the newspaper Le Monde, and reprinted in his book Paper Machine (Stanford University Press, 2005, pp. 70–2). In contrast to his intervention in the de Man case, Derrida’s comments are brief: what is usually quoted is just the remark ‘poor Sokal’, referring to the plight of a physicist who is better known for his hoax than his physics. But Derrida too sees the affair in nationalistic terms – the ‘credit’ being given in the USA to himself as a ‘foreign professor’ was perceived to be excessive, so he is now attacked alongside other French writers for a fault (that of using in a loose way metaphors drawn from science and mathematics) which surely cannot be confined to the French. He would like to comment further on ‘the American context and the political context’, he says, but he has not the space to do so.

总的来说，索卡尔事件似乎确实带有一些被克里斯蒂娃和德里达察觉到的民族主义色彩。在 1958 年和 1966 年邀请文学理论进入该国并接待了大约 40 年之后，美国的知识界机构现在似乎正在向它发出前进的命令。信息似乎是理论的“时刻”已经持续了足够长的时间，现在是理论家们收拾行李回家的时候了。鉴于后现代主义已经开始代表一般理论，如前所述，后现代理论因索卡尔的恶作剧而蒙受羞辱（这就是事件的普遍看法）现在被视为标志着“理论”的全面失败。毫无疑问，美国的强大力量正在努力恢复和重新美国化人文课程，并且随着 1990 年代的继续，这些力量将加快步伐。美国大学里正在发生一场普遍的反革命，反对一系列目标——政治正确、相对主义、后现代主义、多元文化主义等——而这些趋势在 9/11 事件后的气候中得到强化。随着我们接近新千年第一个十年的尾声，对进一步恐怖袭击的普遍担忧使国际集会变得更加困难，此外，我们对全球变暖和碳足迹的担忧也日益加剧。在某些方面，聚会也不是那么必要（在电子邮件、视频会议、电话会议、黑莓、“社交网络”等时代）。因此，知识分子的生活变得更加孤立，在性质上更加民族化而非国际化，而文学理论也未能幸免于这些趋势。或许我们可以期待在未来几十年里，在世界不同地区占据主导地位的文学理论版本之间会出现更大的分歧，而不是少数全球品牌在该领域的全面统治。毫无疑问，这是一个令人兴奋的新局面，而且似乎已经到来，下一章将对此进行说明。同样，聚会的必要性也降低了（在电子邮件、视频会议、电话会议、黑莓手机、“社交网络”等时代）。因此，知识分子的生活变得更加孤立，在性质上更加民族化而非国际化，而文学理论也未能幸免于这些趋势。或许我们可以期待在未来几十年里，在世界不同地区占据主导地位的文学理论版本之间会出现更大的分歧，而不是少数全球品牌在该领域的全面统治。毫无疑问，这是一个令人兴奋的新局面，而且似乎已经到来，下一章将对此进行说明。同样，聚会的必要性也降低了（在电子邮件、视频会议、电话会议、黑莓手机、“社交网络”等时代）。因此，知识分子的生活变得更加孤立，在性质上更加民族化而非国际化，而文学理论也未能幸免于这些趋势。或许我们可以期待在未来几十年里，在世界不同地区占据主导地位的文学理论版本之间会出现更大的分歧，而不是少数全球品牌在该领域的全面统治。毫无疑问，这是一个令人兴奋的新局面，而且似乎已经到来，下一章将对此进行说明。知识分子的生活变得更加孤立，在性质上更加民族化而不是国际化，文学理论也未能幸免于这些趋势。或许我们可以期待在未来几十年里，在世界不同地区占据主导地位的文学理论版本之间会出现更大的分歧，而不是少数全球品牌在该领域的全面统治。毫无疑问，这是一个令人兴奋的新局面，而且似乎已经到来，下一章将对此进行说明。知识分子的生活变得更加孤立，在性质上更加民族化而不是国际化，文学理论也未能幸免于这些趋势。或许我们可以期待在未来几十年里，在世界不同地区占据主导地位的文学理论版本之间会出现更大的分歧，而不是少数全球品牌在该领域的全面统治。毫无疑问，这是一个令人兴奋的新局面，而且似乎已经到来，下一章将对此进行说明。

Overall, the Sokal affair does seem to have some of the nationalistic overtones perceived by Kristeva and Derrida. Having invited literary theory into the country in 1958 and 1966, and having played host to it for some forty years, the intellectual establishment of the USA now seemed to be giving it its marching orders. The message seemed to be that the ‘moment’ of theory had gone on long enough, and it was now time for the theorists to pack their bags and go home. Given that postmodernism had come to stand for theory in general, as suggested earlier, the humiliation of postmodern theory by Sokal’s hoax (which is how the event was generally perceived) was now seen as marking a comprehensive defeat of ‘theory’. It was undoubtedly the case that powerful forces in the USA were working to reclaim and re-Americanise the Humanities syllabus, and these would gather pace as the 1990s went on. A general counter-revolution was taking place in American universities against a cluster of targets – political correctness, relativism, postmodernism, multi-culturalism, among others – and these tendencies were hardened in the post-9/11 climate. As we approach the end of the first decade of the new millennium, pervasive anxieties about further terror attacks have made international gatherings more difficult, and to this has been added our growing concerns about global warming and carbon footprints. In some ways, too, the gatherings are less necessary (in the age of e-mail, video-conferencing, conference calling, Blackberries, ‘social networking’, and so on). Consequently, intellectual life has become more insular, more national than international in character, and literary theory has not been immune to these trends. Perhaps we can expect greater divergence in the coming decades between the versions of literary theory which hold sway in different parts of the world, rather than total dominance of the field by a narrow range of global brands. That, surely, is an exciting new situation, and one which already seems to be coming about, as the next chapter will illustrate.

15

“理论”之后的理论

15

Theory after ‘Theory’

理论遗产

Legacies of theory

“理论之后还有生命吗？” 想知道 2003 年英国的一次重要会议。会议的书名为《生活》。后。理论（Michael Payne 和 John Schad 编辑，Continuum，2003 年），其中包含对主要参与者——雅克·德里达、弗兰克·克莫德、托里尔·莫伊和克里斯托弗·诺里斯的采访。有趣的是，会议的标题本身就是一个问题——它被宣传为“理论之后还有生命吗？” – 而书名可能被视为一种信仰，认为理论之后确实存在生命。在 1995 年第一版《理论开始》的序言中，我引用了托马斯·多彻蒂 (Thomas Docherty) 1990 年出版的《理论之后》( After Theory ) 一书，提到了一种普遍的感觉，即文学理论的真正业务已经结束。特里·伊格尔顿 (Terry Eagleton) 为他自己 2003 年的书重新使用了“理论之后”这个标题，这意味着理论仍然结束了，可以这么说，伊格尔顿的书本身就是“后”瓦伦丁·坎宁安(Valentine Cunningham) 的《理论之后的阅读》 (Blackwell, 2001)，它没有提到这一点. 总的来说，坎宁安很庆幸理论已经走到了尽头，他认为自己正在开始修复理论所破坏的批评的各个方面，并将它们恢复到文学研究中的适当位置，就像有人开始整理洪水或飓风过后。还有其他“恢复性”书籍，其中一些具有更本地化的简介，例如大卫斯科特卡斯坦的莎士比亚理论之后（劳特利奇，1999 年）。在这本书中，“理论之后”被理解为，不是指理论消亡之后的时期，而是指理论不再是新闻的时期。人们可能会声称，理论不再具有新闻价值，因为它的许多关键思想已被普遍接受，因此它的影响和魅力已经“常规化”（使用社会学家马克斯·韦伯的术语）。因此，它不再需要坚持自己的独特性，而是进入了普遍的思想潮流。这种“非主见”的气势，的确可以看作是“说”之后理论的一般特征的典型，即“说教”阶段结束后的理论，正是因为它的许多思想已经成为我们现在生活的知识氛围的共同货币。

‘Is there life after theory?’ a major UK conference wanted to know in 2003. The book of the conference was called Life. After. Theory (ed. Michael Payne and John Schad, Continuum, 2003) and it contains interviews with the major participants – Jacques Derrida, Frank Kermode, Toril Moi, and Christopher Norris. Interestingly, the title of the conference itself was a question – it had been advertised as ‘Is there life after theory?’ – whereas the title of the book might be taken as a profession of faith in the view that there is indeed life after theory. In the introduction to the first edition of Beginning Theory in 1995 I mentioned the common feeling even then that the real business of literary theory was already over, citing Thomas Docherty’s 1990 book After Theory. Terry Eagleton reused the title After Theory for his own book of 2003, implying that theory was still over, so to speak, and Eagleton’s book was itself ‘post’ Valentine Cunningham’s Reading After Theory (Blackwell, 2001), which it doesn’t mention. Cunningham was thankful, on the whole, that theory had run its course, and he saw himself as beginning the process of repairing aspects of criticism which theory had damaged, and restoring them to their proper places within literary studies, rather like someone starting to tidy up after a flood or a hurricane. There have been other ‘restorative’ books, some with a more localised brief, such as David Scott Kastan’s Shakespeare After Theory (Routledge, 1999). In this book ‘after theory’ is understood to mean, not the period after the passing away of theory, but the period during which theory has ceased to be news. Theory is no longer news-worthy, it might be claimed, because there has been a general acceptance of many of its key ideas, so that its impact and charisma have been ‘routinised’ (to use the terms of the sociologist Max Weber). So it has ceased to have to assert its uniqueness, and has passed into the general stream of ideas. This air of ‘non-assertiveness’, indeed, may be taken as typical of the general character of theory after ‘Theory’, that is, theory in the period when the ‘preaching’ phase is over, precisely because so many of its ideas have become the common currency of the intellectual climate we now live in.

那么，这些想法中有哪些在四分之一个世纪前遭到强烈抵制，但现在看来却司空见惯并被视为理所当然？一个基本的清单将包括以下内容：首先，我们认为身份既是一种固定的东西，也是一种变化的东西。因此，成为英国人、男同性恋者、女性或宗教信仰者并不是拥有某种固定的实体或始终如一的观点的问题——相反，这些身份总是容易漂移，以响应各种潮流对不同的人有不同的操作。我们可以这样总结这一点：我们的“存在”概念，“根据理论”，是它始终包含重要的“生成”元素。第二，我们对理论之后的文学文本的概念同样不稳定，无论我们是否在考虑“经典化”文本，因为每个文本都受到对其“是什么”的不断变化的看法，因此它可能对不同的群体有不同的“身份” , 并且可能存在于几个不同编辑和不同呈现的版本中。同样，“文本”总是受到不同的（并且可能是连续的）挪用——想想我们在最近的理论生命中看到的所有莎士比亚，比如文化唯物主义者的“性异议”和“后殖民”莎士比亚80 年代的莎士比亚，以及 1990 年代的“天主教”和“共和党”莎士比亚，仅举几例。第三，我们意识到语言本身的不稳定性，以及它滑过描述和严格定义之网的能力。这不仅仅是我们警惕的、后弗洛伊德式的感觉，即“失误”和失误是语言本身结构的一部分，因为我们也敏锐地意识到语言的隐喻和比喻的“梦想生活”，有时会破坏最平淡无奇的语言和工具的话语。最后，还有我们对无处不在的感觉理论本身，我们意识到不可能选择退出立场的业务，因为每一个立场都是一个观点，所以所有我们的断言是即兴的、偶然的和临时的，就像对知识和文化银行开出的投机支票一样，因此我们永远无法确定账户中有多少存款来支持它们。我想说的是，这四种思维模式——即不稳定的身份、不稳定的文本、不稳定的语言结构和不确定的真值库——是我们许多人留下的“理论后”。我们并没有将这四种信念作为一组信念——几乎根据定义，我们对四种不同类型的不稳定性的信念本身是不稳定的，但它们一直存在，它们构成了气候，而不仅仅是天气，我们的思维和感性。

What are some of those ideas, then, which were fiercely resisted a quarter of a century ago but now seem commonplace and taken for granted? A rudimentary list would include such things as: firstly, our feeling that identity is as much a shifting as a fixed thing. Thus, to be British, or gay, or female, or religious is not a matter of possessing some fixed entity or outlook which has always been the same – rather, these are identities which are constantly prone to drifting, in response to various currents which operate differently on different people. We might sum this up by saying that our notion of ‘being’, ‘after theory’, is that it always has significant elements of ‘becoming’ within it. Secondly, our notion of the literary text after theory is likewise unstable, whether we are thinking of ‘canonized’ texts or not, for each text is subject to shifting perceptions of what it ‘is’, so it may have different ‘identities’ for different groups, and may exist in several differently edited and differently presented versions. Likewise, ‘the’ text is always subject to different (and possibly serial) appropriations – think of all the Shakespeares we have seen even in the recent lifetime of theory, such as the ‘sexual dissidence’ and ‘postcolonial’ Shakespeares of the cultural materialists of the 1980s, and the ‘Catholic’ and ‘Republican’ Shakespeares of the 1990s, to name but a few. Thirdly, we are aware of the instabilities of language itself, and its capacity for slithering beyond the net of delineation and tight definition. This isn’t just our wary, post-Freudian sense that ‘slips’ and slippage are part of the fabric of language itself, for we are also acutely aware of language’s ‘dream life’ of metaphor and figuration which can sometimes disrupt the most prosaic and instrumental of utterances. And finally, there is our sense of the pervasiveness of theory itself, our realization that it isn’t possible to opt out of the business of position-taking, because every stance is a viewpoint, so that all our assertions are improvisatory, contingent, and provisional, like speculative cheques drawn against the intellectual and cultural bank, so that we can never know for sure what deposits are in the account to back them up. Those four mind-sets, I would say – that is, unstable identities, unstable texts, unstable linguistic structures, and uncertain truth-banks – are what many of us have been left with ‘after theory’. We don’t sign up to these four as a set of beliefs – almost by definition, our convictions about the four different kinds of instability are themselves unstable, but they are there all the time and they constitute the climate, rather than just the weather, of our thinking and sensibility.

应该提到理论本身的知识面貌中的四个进一步的普遍转变或“解决”。一个普遍的转变是，面对大量和推测性的知识主张，理论变得不像迄今为止那样愿意暂停怀疑，而是比过去更致力于在经验层面上处理其材料。因此，研究结果现在更有可能得到证明，或者至少比以前更细致地论证，而不是仅仅被权威地断言。事实上，古老的高卢人对“纯粹”经验主义的蔑视现在看来与法国美食的假设一样过时了。法国时装天生就优于其他所有时装。现在，即使是文学理论家，人们也期待清晰，并且在 1970 年代和 80 年代自由地颁发给法语理论家的诗歌许可证不再有效（或者至少在国外无效）。那么，当前理论的“死后生命”的特点是对旧的知识分子“巨型区域”进行某种战略性的“缩小”：因此，结构主义已经被叙事学黯然失色，叙事学最初是它自己的专业子集之一，而马克思唯物主义理论的主题“意识形态”和“政治”的抽象概念，已经被对特定时期文化逻辑的细致关注所取代——尤其是早期现代主义、浪漫主义和维多利亚主义。

Four further general shifts or ‘settlements’ in the intellectual landscape of theory itself ought to be mentioned. One general shift has been that theory has become less willing than hitherto to suspend disbelief in the face of vast and speculative intellectual claims, and more committed than it used to be to engaging with its material at an empirical level. Hence, findings are now more likely to be demonstrated, or at least more meticulously argued than before, rather than just being magisterially asserted. Indeed, the old Gallic disdain for ‘mere’ empiricism now seems as dated as the assumption that French cuisine and French fashions are inherently superior to all others. Clarity is now expected, even of literary theorists, and the poetic licences liberally issued to Francophone theorists in the 1970s and 80s are no longer valid (or, at least, are not valid abroad). The current ‘afterlives’ of theory, then, are characterised by a certain strategic ‘downsizing’ of the old intellectual ‘mega-zones’: thus, structuralism has been eclipsed by narratology, originally one of its own specialist sub-sets, and the abstractions of ‘Ideology’ and ‘Politics’, which were the subject of Marxist-materialist theory, have been replaced by minute attention to the cultural logistics of specific periods – especially Early Modernism, Romanticism and Victorianism.

其次，有证据表明，人们背离了以英国文化唯物主义和美国新历史主义为代表的占主导地位的唯物主义，甚至转向“精神”方面，无论是被视为阅读、写作和生活各个方面的隐喻。文本性（参见 Julian Wolfreys, Victorian Hauntings: Specialty, Gothic, the Uncanny and Literature, Palgrave, 2001)，或者作为比物质现实更真实（在更深刻、更基本的意义上）的世界的转喻表征。事实上，宗教转向在当前千禧年的文学研究中似乎很明显，远比几十年更明显，也许最近对莎士比亚宗教的广泛关注表明了这种“转向”（见 EAJ Honigmann，Shakespeare : The Lost Years, 1988, and Richard Wilson, Secret Shakespeare, 2004, both Manchester University Press).

Secondly, there is evidence of a turning away from the dominant materialism epitomized by British Cultural Materialism and American New Historicism, and even a drift towards aspects of ‘the spiritual’, whether conceived of as metaphorical renderings of various aspects of reading, writing, and textuality (see Julian Wolfreys, Victorian Hauntings: Speciality, Gothic, the Uncanny and Literature, Palgrave, 2001), or as metonymic representations of a world more real (in the sense of deeper, more fundamental) than material reality. Indeed, the religious turn seems much in evidence in literary studies in the present millennial era, far more so than for several decades, and perhaps the recent widespread pre-occupation with Shakespeare’s religion is indicative of this ‘turn’ (see E. A. J. Honigmann, Shakespeare: The Lost Years, 1988, and Richard Wilson, Secret Shakespeare, 2004, both Manchester University Press).

第三，我所说的“语言崇高”已经发生了明显的转变，这是语言的“建构主义”概念，它将语言视为构建或形成我们的世界，因此实际上一切都是语言，或者语言就是一切，取决于你想如何看待它。理论家和哲学家克里斯托弗·诺里斯（Christopher Norris，生于 1947 年）长期以来一直是对抗和瓦解全面语言建构主义威望的主要力量。诺里斯怀疑（甚至更多）语言在说我们而不是相反的观点，他说，这个概念（大概是考虑到海德格尔和德曼）太容易让我们否认对自己的声明负责。诺里斯还猛烈抨击哲学中的“反实在论者”（那些否认“独立于思想”的现实存在并倾向于将一切视为“思想决定”的人），甚至是讨论最多的“第三条道路”他倾向于将“现实主义”和“反现实主义”两极视为实际上只是后者的另一种形式。同样，他对鲍德里亚、菲什、罗蒂和利奥塔等理论家提出的“无尽的、有趣的、多义的解释”提出了异议，在他看来，这些解释是“以牺牲系统论证为代价的”，认为这种事情是典型的后现代主义相对主义（见他的书后现代主义有什么问题？约翰霍普金斯大学出版社，1990 年，《量子理论与逃离现实主义》，劳特利奇，2000 年，以及《真相很重要：现实主义、反现实主义和反应依赖》，爱丁堡大学出版社，2005 年）。

Thirdly, there has been a marked shift away from what I call the ‘linguistic sublime’, which is that ‘constructivist’ notion of language which sees it as constructing or forming our world, so that effectively everything is language, or language is everything, depending on how you want to look at it. The theorist and philosopher Christopher Norris (b. 1947) has long been a major force in confronting and dismantling the prestige of full-on linguistic constructivism. Norris is suspicious (and more) of the view that language speaks us rather than vice versa, a notion which, he says, (presumably with Heidegger and de Man in mind) too easily allows us to deny responsibility for our own pronouncements. Norris has also vehemently attacked the ‘anti-realists’ in philosophy (those who deny the existence of ‘mind-independent’ reality and tend to see everything as ‘mind-determined’), and even the much discussed ‘third way’ between the ‘realist’ and ‘anti-realist’ poles he has tended to see as really just another form of the latter. Likewise, he has taken issue with the ‘endless, playful, polysemic interpretations’ offered, in his view, ‘at the expense of systematic argument’ in such theorists as Baudrillard, Fish, Rorty, and Lyotard, seeing that kind of thing as typical of postmodernist relativism (see his books What’s Wrong with Postmodernism?’ Johns Hopkins University Press, 1990, Quantum Theory and the Flight from Realism, Routledge, 2000, and Truth Matters: Realism, Anti-Realism and Response-Dependence, Edinburgh University Press, 2005).

最后，针对 9/11 等极端事件以及阿以冲突、伊拉克、阿富汗、宗教原教旨主义蔓延等明显棘手问题所产生的全球悲观主义，出现了一种新的文化批评。 ，以及环境恶化的无情进展。一种感觉特里·伊格尔顿 (Terry Eagleton) 最近的大部分作品背后隐藏着一种日益绝望的世界局势，在这种阴影下，文化批评本身似乎是一种愚蠢的奢侈（参见《甜蜜的暴力》，布莱克威尔，2003 年，《理论之后》，艾伦·莱恩， 2003 年和神圣恐怖，牛津大学出版社，2005 年）。伊格尔顿提供了一种越来越关注暴力、恐怖和邪恶的文化批评，一种可以称为“危机批评”的写作形式（生态批评可能被视为其中的一个分支）。这部作品充满了一种无处不在和迫在眉睫的灾难感，文学和文化批评中更常见的担忧似乎与准备摧毁我们的力量暗中串通一气。伊格尔顿对道德、宗教和伦理问题的日益关注，以及他对马克思主义的转变，也可以看作是前面提到的“宗教转向”的征兆。

Finally, a new kind of cultural critique has arisen in response to extreme events such as 9/11, and the global pessimism which is the product of apparently intractable problems such as the Arab-Israeli conflict, Iraq, Afghanistan, the spread of religious fundamentalism, and the relentless progress of environmental deterioration. A sense of a world situation which is increasingly desperate, and in the shadow of which cultural critique itself comes to seem a foolish luxury, lies behind much of the recent work of Terry Eagleton (see Sweet Violence, Blackwell, 2003, After Theory, Allen Lane, 2003, and Holy Terror, OUP, 2005). Eagleton provides a cultural critique increasingly pre-occupied with violence, terror, and evil, a form of writing which might be called ‘Crisis Critique’ (of which eco-criticism could plausibly be seen as a sub-branch). This work is much burdened by a sense of catastrophe as both pervasive and impending, and the more usual concerns of literary and cultural criticism are made to seem darkly complicit with the forces poised to destroy us. Eagleton’s increasing preoccupation with moral, religious, and ethical issues, and his shift away from Marxism, can also be seen as symptomatic of the ‘religious turn’ mentioned earlier.

因此，近年来的理论倾向于变得更加经验主义，不再那么纯粹唯物主义，不再那么容易受到“语言崇高”版本的影响，并且更加充满了对日益迫在眉睫的全球危机的意识。但它并没有关门歇业。事实上，它一直在继续交易，甚至开发了几条新线路。所以我们现在可以问，自从 1995 年开始流行说理论已经结束以来，理论是以何种精确的方式被添加和发展的？不打算面面俱到，我将着眼于四个发展领域，初学者可能会注意到这些领域。

So theory in recent years has tended to become more empiricist, less exclusively materialist, less susceptible to versions of the ‘linguistic sublime’, and more suffused with an awareness of ever-impending global crisis. But it hasn’t shut up the shop and gone out of business. In fact, it has continued trading, and it has even developed several new lines. So we can now ask, in what precise ways has theory been added to and developed since, say, 1995, when it started to become common to say that theory was over? Without trying to be comprehensive, I will look at four areas of development which beginning-theorists might usefully be aware of.

存在主义

Presentism

当下主义是一种文学研究方法，它“以文本在当下的意义为导向，与以过去的意义为导向的‘历史主义’方法相反”（休·格雷迪）。它最初关注的是近代早期的文学，尤其是莎士比亚，但最近出现在浪漫主义领域，被称为“批判当下主义”。其中，现时主义的实践者有特伦斯霍克斯、休格雷迪和伊万弗尼。

Presentism is an approach to literature which is ‘oriented towards the text’s meaning in the present, as opposed to “historicist” approaches oriented to meanings in the past’ (Hugh Grady). It was initially concerned with the literature of the early modern period, especially Shakespeare, but has more recently emerged in the field of Romanticism, under the designation ‘critical presentism’. Among others, the practioners of presentism are Terence Hawkes, Hugh Grady, and Ewan Fernie.

最近的批判当下主义趋势可以看作是对以历史为中心的文学研究方法（如新历史主义和文化唯物主义，见第 9 章）的一种反动，这些研究方法已经自 1980 年代以来一直占据主导地位。对历史的强调建立在米歇尔·福柯的著作之上，福柯在《知识考古学》 （1972 年）第一章中规定，在对话语场的分析中，“我们必须把握陈述发生的确切特殊性'（我的斜体）。因此，仅仅分析“声明”（一种“声明”是文学文本）是不够的，我们必须设法将其“放置”在其费力重建的历史特殊性中：因此我们必须“确定它的条件”存在，至少确定它的界限，建立它与可能与之相关的其他陈述的相关性，并表明它排除了哪些其他形式的陈述。这就是福柯提倡的探究方法，对文学研究的影响可能是毁灭性的。事实上，如果你愿意的话，福柯自己的“声明”是一个历史学家宪章，如果我们像许多人一样签署这些修辞声明，我们将致力于永无止境的历史考古学。历史主义也建立在雷蒙威廉姆斯的强调之上（在Marxism and Literature, Oxford University Press, 1977）关于理解“整个生活的社会过程，实际上是由特定的和主导的意义组织起来的”（又是我的斜体）。在此类声明中使用“特定”、“精确”和“整体”等词的威吓性使用促使许多人转向详尽的历史主义研究，以至于文学学者开始专注于历史方法。到 20 世纪 90 年代后期，人们似乎理所当然地认为，只有业余文学读者才会否认通过历史可以最好地理解文学。

The recent trend of critical presentism can be seen as a reaction against the history-centred approaches to literature (such as new historicism and cultural materialism, see Chapter 9) which have been dominant since the 1980s. That emphasis on history built upon the work of Michel Foucault, who had stipulated, in the first chapter of The Archaeology of Knowledge (1972), that in the analysis of the discursive field ‘we must grasp the statement in the exact specificity of its occurrence’ (my italics). So it is not enough merely to analyse ‘the statement’ (and one kind of ‘statement’ is the literary text) rather, we must seek to ‘place’ it within its laboriously rebuilt historical specificity: so we must ‘determine its conditions of existence, fix at least its limits, establish its correlations with other statements that may be connected with it, and show what other forms of statement it excludes’. That was the method of enquiry which Foucault advocated, and the implications for literary study are potentially devastating. Indeed, Foucault’s own ‘statement’ is, if you like, a Historicist Charter, and if we sign up to these rhetorical pronouncements – as so many did – we will be committed to a lifetime of never-ending historical archeology. Historicism also built upon Raymond Williams’s emphasis (in Marxism and Literature, Oxford University Press, 1977) on understanding ‘the whole lived social process, as practically organized by specific and dominant meanings’ (my italics again). The intimidatory use of words like ‘specific’, ‘exact’, and ‘the whole’ in such proclamations drove many towards exhaustive historicist study, so that literary scholars became preoccupied by historical method. By the late 1990s it seemed to be taken for granted that only an amateur reader of literature would deny that literature can best be understood through history.

这就是现在主义所反对的情况。“现在主义”这个词可以追溯到二十世纪初。它最初表示一种天真的倾向，只根据现在来解读过去，将今天视为过去一直努力追求的顶点和顶点。对于这种天真的意义上的“现在主义者”来说，只有当它的关注点被视为与我们自己的关注点直接相关时，过去才会引起人们的兴趣，因此我们会审视历史以寻找与我们自己“密切相关”的东西并丢弃其余部分。显然，“现在主义”在历史学家中是一个严重的错误，但文学学者呢？可以说，一个文学学者不是一个现在主义者根本不是一个真正的文学学者，因为如果文学不能解决我们今天所关心的问题，那么阅读文学就没有意义。因此，自 2000 年左右以来，我们看到了一群自称文人“现在主义者”，部分是为了表明他们认为自己的立场与历史主义者的立场相反。特伦斯·霍克斯 (Terence Hawkes) 是现代主义的主要实践者，他的劳特利奇 (Routledge) 系列“莎士比亚的口音”一直是其主要出版渠道之一。霍克斯也是 20 世纪 70 年代文学理论传播的重要人物，当时他是 Methuen 的“新口音”系列的总编辑，该系列在普及和调解理论运动主要人物的写作方面发挥了重要作用。他的新系列延续了最初的“新口音”的使命，其宗旨是“要么“应用”理论，要么拓宽和改编它以与具体的教学问题联系起来”（总编辑的系列声明）。霍克斯自己的系列书中阐述了当下主义的一些定义性立场，Shakespeare in the Present (2002)，一开始就指出“根本不可能”（第 2 页）“真正捕捉或重复过去”。所以我们从过去已经过去的立场出发，这样我们就永远无法重建或重新获得它的“身份”（在我看来，这似乎是大多数历史主义研究文学的基本目标）。因此，历史学家或文学学者不可能“接触未被他们自己的关注所塑造的过去”（第 3 页）)，因为（霍克斯在此引用了意大利批评家和哲学家贝内代托·克罗齐 (Benedetto Croce, 1866–1952) 的观点）“所有的历史都是当代史”。因此，“现在主义”文学学者将积极寻找“过去的现在”，正如我们所说的那样，明确的目标是与生活者交谈或谈判。相比之下，历史学家和历史学家寻求“与死者交谈”（第 4 页），这通常被认为是历史学家的主要目标和满足之一。事实上，你可能还记得，新历史主义先驱史蒂芬·格林布拉特 (Stephen Greenblatt) 在他颇具影响力的著作《莎士比亚谈判》( Shakespearian Negotiations , 1988) 的开头写道：“我开始时渴望与死者交谈……的确，我只能听到自己的声音，但我的声音自己的声音是死者的声音”（p. 1 ). 因此，现在论者和历史论者之间的一个基本区别是，前者的目标主要是与生者对话，而后者则与死者对话，尽管两者都会意识到他们实际上经常是在与自己谈判（正如格林布拉特的开场白似乎承认的那样）。

That is the situation which presentism reacts against. ‘Presentism’ is a term which goes back to the early twentieth century; it originally denoted the naïve tendency to read the past exclusively in terms of the present, taking the present day as the summit and culmination towards which the past has been striving. For a ‘presentist’ in this naïve sense, the past is only of interest when its concerns are seen as directly relevant to our own, so that we scan history for what is ‘germane’ to ourselves and discard the rest. Clearly, ‘presentism’ would be a grievous fault in a historian, but what of the literary scholar? It could be argued that a literary scholar who isn’t a presentist isn’t really a literary scholar at all, since there could be no point in reading literature if it did not address our concerns today. Hence, since around the year 2000, we have seen the development of a group of literary scholars who call themselves ‘presentists’, partly to indicate that they see their position as opposed to that of the historicists. Terence Hawkes is the leading practitioner of presentism, and his Routledge series ‘Accents on Shakespeare’ has been one of its major publishing outlets. Hawkes was also a major figure in the promulgation of literary theory back in the 1970s, when he was the General Editor of Methuen’s ‘New Accents’ series which did the essential work of popularizing and mediating the writing of the major figures of the theory movement. His new series continues the mission of the original ‘New Accents’, and the brief is to ‘either “apply” theory, or broaden and adapt it in order to connect with concrete teaching concerns’ (General Editor’s series statement). Some of the defining positions of presentism are set out in Hawkes’s own book in the series, Shakespeare in the Present (2002), beginning with the point that it is ‘fundamentally impossible’ (p. 2) ‘genuinely to capture, or repeat, the past’. So we start from the position that the past is past, so that we can never reconstruct or recapture its ‘identity’ (as seems to me the essential aim of most historicist approaches to literature). Hence, it is impossible for historians or literary scholars to ‘make contact with a past unshaped by their own concerns’ (p. 3), for (Hawkes here quotes the view of the Italian critic and philosopher Benedetto Croce, 1866–1952) ‘all history is contemporary history’. So the ‘presentist’ literary scholar will actively seek out ‘the present in the past’, as we might call it, with the explicit aim of speaking with, or negotiating with, the living. By contrast, historians and historicists seek to ‘speak with the dead’ (p. 4), which is often said to be one of the main aims and satisfactions of the historian. Indeed, you may remember that the pioneer new historicist Stephen Greenblatt began his influential book Shakespearian Negotiations (1988) with the words ‘I began with the desire to speak with the dead … It was true that I could only hear my own voice, but my own voice was the voice of the dead’ (p. 1). So a basic distinction between presentists and historicists would be that the former aim to speak primarily to the living and the latter to the dead, though both will realise that they are often in fact negotiating with themselves (as Greenblatt’s opening statement seems to acknowledge).

历史主义的目标本质上是在文学的时间和地点的“嵌入性”中研究文学（福柯的“其确切的特殊性”occurrence' again），乍一看，这似乎是研究文学的一种合乎逻辑且显而易见的方法。存在主义仅仅询问（比如）莎士比亚戏剧的“时间和地点”究竟是什么，因为正如伊万·弗尼所说，“莎士比亚尤其是主要的当代剧作家和作家，因为他目前正在接受教育、阅读和表演任何其他作家都无法比拟的全球规模……与文艺复兴时期相比，他更深入地融入了我们的现代世界”（在他的文章“莎士比亚与当下主义的前景”中，第 175 页）。也可以说，历史主义是建立在逻辑矛盾之上的，因为如果身份真的是历史建构的，那么我们就永远无法走出我们自己历史建构的身份来识别任何其他时代的身份。霍克斯还提到了莎士比亚研究中当下主义强调的两个特定领域，首先是英国政治权力下放的最新发展——1990 年代后期在苏格兰、威尔士和北爱尔兰建立了独立的议会或议会，以及随之而来的对什么的重新定义。是指“联合王国”。霍克斯对英国“联盟”内部的紧张和模棱两可的感觉，尤其是自 1990 年代的权力下放运动以来，为他阅读莎士比亚的作品提供了信息第 4 章中的辛白林。它的标题是 ' Aberdaugleddyf'，这是米尔福德港的威尔士名称（字面意思是“两条溪流的入口”），米尔福德港是威尔士的一个“英国”港口，长期以来对保卫“王国”（一个适当模糊的术语）具有重要的战略意义)，并在剧中扮演重要角色。在英国历史上，威尔士都铎王朝和苏格兰斯图亚特王朝轮流继承“不列颠”王位，但爱尔兰、苏格兰和威尔士的国家地位却有些模棱两可（它们是不是独立的国家？）。该项目旨在将英国性、威尔士性、苏格兰性和爱尔兰性融合成一个单一的“英国性”，但不是采用联邦模式。霍克斯在阅读莎士比亚的戏剧时了解到，威尔士文化和英国文化的两大流派从未融合为一，而当今的权力下放过程正日益导致它们分道扬镳。

The historicist aim is essentially to study literature in the ‘embed-dedness’ of its time and place (Foucault’s ‘the exact specificity of its occurrence’ again), and this seems at first a logical and obvious way to approach literature. Presentism merely asks what the ‘time and place’ of (say) a Shakespeare play actually is, for as Ewan Fernie says, ‘Shakespeare, in particular, is primarily a contemporary dramatist and writer, because he is currently taught, read and performed on a global scale unmatched by any other author … he is more embedded in our modern world than he ever was in the Renaissance’ (in his article ‘Shakespeare and the prospect of presentism’, p.175). It could be argued, too, that historicism is founded on a logical contradiction, for if identity really is historically constructed, then we can never step out of our own historically constructed identities to identify that of any other epoch. Hawkes also mentions two particular areas of presentist emphasis in Shakespeare Studies, firstly the recent development of devolution in British politics – the establishment of separate parliaments or assemblies in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland in the late 1990s, and the consequent re-definition of what is meant by the ‘United Kingdom’. Hawkes’s sense of the tensions and ambiguities within the British ‘Union’, especially since the devolution movement of the 1990s, informs his reading of Shakespeare’s Cymbeline in Chapter 4. It is entitled ‘Aberdaugleddyf’, which is the Welsh name (literally ‘the mouth of two streams’) for the port of Milford Haven, an ‘English’ port in Wales, long of great strategic importance to the defence of ‘the realm’ (a suitably vague term), and featuring strongly in the play. In British history the Welsh Tudors and the Scottish Stuarts accede in turn to the ‘British’ throne, but with the national status of Ireland, Scotland, and Wales left somewhat ambiguous (are they nations in their own right, or not?). The project was to fuse Englishness, Welshness, Scottishness and Irishness into a single ‘Britishness’, but not by adopting a federal model. Hawkes reads Shakespeare’s play in the knowledge that the two streams of Welshness and Englishness were never fused into one, and that present-day processes of devolution are increasingly causing them to diverge.

莎士比亚研究中当下主义强调的第二个领域涉及一系列既定优先事项或偏好的战略逆转，包括“明显不变的概念等级，如主要/次要，过去/现在”（第 4 页）。例如，莎士比亚对马克思和弗洛伊德的影响将被视为正如马克思主义和弗洛伊德对莎士比亚的解读一样有趣和重要，莎士比亚戏剧的“表演”将被视为与其“参考”一样重要——也就是说，它所做的和它所说的一样重要。稍后会给出对当下主义稍微更全面的定义：霍克斯说，它是一种批评，“其根源在于此时此地，并且与此时此地的联系被充分和积极地寻求，有意地突出，并作为首要原则加以利用……当下主义批评的参与文本的发生恰恰是根据现代世界的那些维度发生的，这些维度与过去的事件最响亮地相呼应——也许作为其开始的结束”（第 21-2 页）。因此，当下主义将自己视为“在某种程度上扭转了新历史主义的策略”（第 22 页），从“物质当下”开始，并允许其“设定其质疑议程”。

The second area of presentist emphasis in Shakespeare studies concerns a series of strategic reversals of established priorities or preferences, including ‘apparently immutable conceptual hierarchies such as primary/secondary, past/present’ (p. 4). For instance, the influence of Shakespeare on Marx and Freud will be seen as being just as interesting and important as Marxist and Freudian readings of Shakespeare, and the ‘performance’ of a Shakespeare play will be taken to be as important as its ‘reference’ – that is, what it does is as important as what it says.
