A slightly fuller definition of presentism is given a little later: it is, says Hawkes, a criticism ‘whose roots in and connections with the here and now are fully and actively sought, deliberately foregrounded, exploited as a first principle … A presentist criticism’s engagement with the text takes place precisely in terms of those dimensions of the modern world that most ringingly chime – perhaps as ends to its beginnings – with the events of the past’ (pp. 21–2). So presentism sees itself as ‘reversing, to some degree, the stratagems of new historicism’ (p. 22), beginning with ‘the material present’ and allowing that ‘to set its interrogative agenda’.

实践中的存在主义

Presentism in practice

当下主义所代表的理论立场的要点可能包含在“所有的目的，当它们到达时，塑造它们之前的开始”的陈述中（第 62 页）。尽管前提如此不同，但根据霍克斯的莎士比亚在当下的证据，现在主义的方法似乎与新历史主义的方法非常相似。这些文章往往以生动的“文化快照”开头，有点像新的历史“轶事”（见第 9 章），但“快照”取自当下，或近在眼前。因此，霍克斯在哈姆雷特的文章“老比尔”中看到了哈姆雷特作为一部关于警务、调查和“搜集”的戏剧，因为剧中的许多角色都在不断地受到监视和监视（“老比尔”是英国俚语，意思是警察）。开头的“快照”涉及这样一个事实，即 1945 年在柏林，美国占领军强加了一份批准和未批准的戏剧清单，其中《哈姆雷特》因其处理“腐败和正义”而在前一份清单上，而《朱利叶斯·凯撒》和科里奥兰纳斯之所以选择后者，是因为据称他们“美化了独裁统治”。因此，在第二次世界大战结束后的特定情况下，该剧本身成为监视过程中的一个元素。霍克斯接着探讨了舞台的使用和戏剧中的表演，然后编织了犹太演员毛里兹·莱昂·赖斯的真实故事，他在 1930 年代的纳粹德国建造了他在现实生活中“扮演”了一个全新的非犹太人身份，最终在 1940 年代移居美国和好莱坞时达到顶峰，讽刺的是，他最终在宣传片中扮演了纳粹的角色。这些元素在文章中被编织成我想称之为“关键情节”的东西，正是“情节”的元素，以及它更熟悉的创造性而非批判性写作的建议，我将其视为一个特征元素现代主义写作。有_“现在主义”文章中的特写文本工作，但它是高度“主题化”的，从文本中提取监视、表演等关键主题的无数方面。简而言之，这些是该剧呈现主义“情节”或“表演”的关键要素——生动的初始“快照”、关键主题不断出现的高度策划的话语结构、强烈的“主题”参与文本，以及当今压倒一切的关注的驱动力，这通常是政治性质的。

The nub of the theoretical position represented by presentism is perhaps contained in the statement ‘All ends, when they arrive, shape the beginnings that precede them’ (p. 62). Though its premises are so different, the methods of presentism, on the evidence of Hawkes’s Shakespeare in the Present, can seem quite closely analogous to those of new historicism. The essays tend to begin with a vivid ‘cultural snapshot’, rather like the new historical ‘anecdote’ (see Chapter 9), but the ‘snapshot’ is taken from the present, or the near-present. Thus, Hawkes’s Hamlet essay, ‘The Old Bill’, sees Hamlet as a play about policing, investigating, ‘gleaning’, for many of the characters in the play are constantly both under surveillance and on the watch (‘the Old Bill’ is British slang for the Police). The ‘snapshot’ at the start concerns the fact that in Berlin in 1945 the American occupation forces imposed a list of approved and non-approved drama, with Hamlet on the former list because of its treatment of ‘corruption and justice’, while Julius Caesar and Coriolanus were on the latter because they allegedly ‘glorified dictatorship’. Thus the play itself becomes an element in the process of surveillance in the specific circumstances of the immediate aftermath of World War Two. Hawkes then goes into the use of stages and acting within the play, and then weaves in the true-life story of the Jewish actor Mauriz Leon Reiss, who in 1930s Nazi Germany constructed a whole new non-Jewish identity for himself which he ‘acted’ in real life, culminating in his move to the USA and Hollywood in the 1940s, where, by a cruel irony, he ended up playing the part of Nazis in propaganda films. These elements are woven in the essay into what I would want to call a ‘critical plot’, and it is that element of ‘plotting’, with its more familiar suggestion of creative rather than critical writing, which I would see as a characteristic element of presentist writing. There is close-up textual work in the ‘presentist’ essay, but it is highly ‘themed’, drawing out from the text innumerable aspects of the key themes of surveillance, acting, and so on. Those, in short, are the key elements of the presentist ‘plot’ or ‘performance’ of the play – the vivid initial ‘snapshots’, the highly plotted discursive structure in which key motifs keep reappearing, the intensely ‘themed’ engagements with the text, and the driving force of a present-day overriding concern which is usually political in nature.

归根结底，历史主义和现在主义之间的较量是关于语境选择的争论——我们可以在过去的语境中阅读《哈姆雷特》（就像斯蒂芬·格林布拉特在《炼狱中的哈姆雷特》中所做的那样，从宗教信仰和现代早期的冲突），或者在现在的背景下（或者，至少，像霍克斯所做的那样，在最近的过去）。伊万·弗尼 (Ewan Fernie) 在上面列出的哈姆雷特(Hamlet ) 文章中，在当今恐怖主义威胁的背景下阅读该剧大部分随机暴力时，也做出了“当下主义”解读。但正如 Fernie 所见，这可以被视为一种协议，因为历史主义者和现在主义者似乎都在说“除了文本之外的任何东西”（第 176 页）)，因为他们都将上下文的选择视为他们阅读策略中的决定性行为——就好像哈姆雷特说的是“上下文是关键”而不是“剧本是关键”。我们将在考虑新唯美主义时回到这个问题。

In the last analysis, the contest between historicism and presentism is an argument about choice of contexts – we can read Hamlet either in the context of the past (as Stephen Greenblatt does in Hamlet in Purgatory, seeing the play in terms of the religious beliefs and conflicts of the early modern period), or in the context of the present (or, at least, of the more recent past, as Hawkes does). Ewan Fernie too, in the Hamlet essay listed above, makes a ‘presentist’ reading when he reads the randomized violence of much of the play in the context of the present-day threat of terrorism. But as Fernie sees, this could be seen as a kind of agreement, for both historicists and presentists seem to be saying ‘anything but the text’ (p. 176), since both see the choice of context as the decisive act in their strategy of reading – it’s as if Hamlet had said ‘The context’s the thing’ rather than ‘The play’s the thing’. We will come back to this issue in considering new aestheticism.

读什么现代主义

What to read on presentism

伊万·弗尼 (Ewan Fernie)，“最后一幕：哈姆雷特的存在主义、灵性和政治”，第 186–211 页，《精神莎士比亚》，编辑。伊万·弗尼 (Ewan Fernie)，劳特利奇 (Routledge) 的“莎士比亚口音”系列，2005 年。

Ewan Fernie, ‘The last act: presentism, spirituality and the politics of Hamlet’, pp. 186–211 in Spiritual Shakespeares, ed. Ewan Fernie, Routledge ‘Accents on Shakespeare’ series, 2005.

伊万·弗尼 (Ewan Fernie)，“莎士比亚与当下主义的前景”，载于《莎士比亚调查》，卷。58，剑桥大学出版社，2005。

Ewan Fernie, ‘Shakespeare and the prospect of presentism’, in Shakespeare Survey, vol. 58, Cambridge University Press, 2005.

Hugh Grady 和 Terence Hawkes，eds，Presentist Shakespeares， Routledge“莎士比亚口音”系列，2006 年。

Hugh Grady and Terence Hawkes, eds, Presentist Shakespeares, Routledge ‘Accents on Shakespeare’ series, 2006.

特伦斯霍克斯，莎士比亚在当下，劳特利奇“莎士比亚的口音”系列，2002 年。

Terence Hawkes, Shakespeare in the Present, Routledge ‘Accents on Shakespeare’ series, 2002.

罗宾·海德拉姆·威尔斯 (Robin Headlam Wells)，“早期现代研究中的历史主义和‘现存主义’”，《剑桥季刊》第 37-60 页，卷。29，第 1 期，2000 年。

Robin Headlam Wells, ‘Historicism and “Presentism” in Early Modern Studies’, pp. 37–60 in The Cambridge Quarterly, Vol. 29, No. 1, 2000.

有关存在主义的互联网讨论，请访问：http ://www.shaksper.net/archives/2007/0091.html 。

For an internet discussion of presentism visit: http://www.shaksper.net/archives/2007/0091.html.

关于横向诗学的注释

A note on transversal poetics

我将在此对一种在许多方面等同于英国现在主义的美国发展，即起源于 20 世纪 90 年代后期的美国的“横向诗学”，做一个简短的评论。这是一种处理文本（尤其是早期现代时期的文本）的方法，旨在“横向地”评论和解释，大致意思是“越界地”，在早期现代文本与当代文化、政治和社会的各个方面之间建立牢固的联系。它试图对这些文本中被压抑或被忽视的方面进行“逃亡探索”，目的是通过“横向权力”的转化能量来缓和“国家权力”。横向诗学与当代戏剧中激进的表演实践以及心理学和社会心理学密切相关，除了与新历史主义、文化唯物主义和解构主义有联系。煽动者是目前加州大学欧文分校的布莱恩雷诺兹，以及堪萨斯州立大学的唐纳德赫德里克和美国西北大学的威廉韦斯特。雷诺兹 1997 年的文章“魔鬼之家，“或更糟”：早期现代英格兰的横向权力和反戏剧话语”（戏剧杂志，卷。49, No. 2, pp. 143–67) 将“横向主义”的概念引入早期现代研究，并与新的历史主义态度相一致，它看到了伊丽莎白时代的一个无所不能的国家，它用它的墙来控制舆论和实践-到墙上的“国家机器”。但剧院本身被视为极少数破坏性或“横向”力量之一——注意，不是个别戏剧及其“信息”，而是作为“媒介”的剧院本身。对于雷诺兹来说，剧院代表着“横向领域”（第 148 页），也就是说，它是一个挑战权力的场所，一个“体验差异性”的空间。在雷诺兹的图式中，剧院与“酒神狂欢、犯罪、魔鬼、不可言说的、不可想象的、“或更糟的””（第 150 页）相关联，换句话说，与任何越轨的和超越社会范围的事物相关联。

I will add a briefer comment here about an American development which is equivalent in many ways to British presentism, namely the ‘transversal poetics’ which originated in the late 1990s in the USA. This is an approach to texts (especially those of the early modern period) that seeks to comment and interpret ‘transversally’, roughly meaning ‘transgressively’, making strong connections between early modern texts and aspects of contemporary culture, politics, and society. It seeks to produce ‘fugitive explorations’ of repressed or neglected aspects of these texts, with the aim of tempering ‘state power’ by means of the transforming energies of ‘transversal power’. Transversal poetics is closely linked to radical performance practices in contemporary theatre, as well as to psychology and social psychology, in addition to having connections with new historicism, cultural materialism, and deconstruction. The instigating figure is Bryan Reynolds, currently of the University of California, Irvine, along with Donald Hedrick, at Kansas State University, and William West, at Northwestern University, USA. Reynolds’s 1997 article ‘The Devil’s House, “or worse”: Transversal Power and Antitheatrical Discourse in Early Modern England’ (Theatre Journal, Vol. 49, No. 2, pp. 143–67) introduced the concept of ‘transversalism’ into Early Modern Studies, and in line with new historicist attitudes, it sees an all-powerful state in Elizabethan times which controls opinion and practice with its wall-to-wall ‘state machinery’. But the theatre itself is seen as one of very few disruptive or ‘transversal’ forces – not the individual drama and its ‘message’, notice, but the theatre itself as a ‘medium’. Theatre, for Reynolds, represents ‘transversal territory’ (p. 148), that is, it is a location which challenges power, a space of ‘experiential alterity’. In Reynolds’s schema, the theatre is associated with ‘bacchanalia, criminality, the Devil, the unspeakable, the unthinkable, “or worse”’ (p. 150), in other words, with whatever is transgressive and beyond the social pale.

他的书《莎士比亚及其同时代人戏剧中的横向企业：逃亡探索》 （Palgrave，2006 年）的开篇标题为“横向诗学和逃亡探索：剧院空间、暂停意识、虚拟语气和麦克白”，很明显他喜欢这些头重脚轻、令人费解的标题。雷诺兹在那里说，横向诗学是一种批判性方法，旨在“培养能动性、创造力，并产生更认真、更有社会意义的学术和教学法”（第 1 页）。它进行“逃亡探索”，即“挑战减少和包含意义的权威，包括阅读和文本本身”（第 7 页）。

The opening chapter of his book Transversal Enterprises in the Drama of Shakespeare and his Contemporaries: Fugitive Explorations (Palgrave, 2006) is entitled ‘Transversal Poetics and Fugitive Explorations: Theatrespace, Paused Consciousness, Subjunctivity, and Macbeth’, and it will be evident that he has a liking for these top-heavy and confusing titles. Reynolds says there that transversal poetics is a critical approach designed ‘to foster agency, creativity, and the production of more conscientious and socially purposeful scholarship and pedagogy’ (p. 1). It makes ‘fugitive explorations’, that is, readings which ‘defy the authorities that reduce and contain meanings, both of the readings and of the text itself’ (p. 7).

横向主义自信地将自己推销为早期现代研究中即将到来的事物——它在语气和并列方面大而大胆。相比之下，雷诺兹说，解构主义阅读“仅仅暴露了文本和它们在其中发挥作用的符号系统的不稳定性”，这实际上相当于旧的指控，即解构主义缺乏政治承诺，取而代之的是一种准审美、准哲学的乐趣在揭露和思考文本的不稳定性时，可以说，仍然被“延异”的文本微光迷住了。横向海盗很容易受到这种固定的影响，并且超越文本，例如展示麦克白中女巫的方法类似于“在剧本之外传播具有诱惑力或误导性的概念”。他指出“当代广告活动或[当代]宗教机构……[或]诸如“引导证人”和“信仰治疗”等当前争论不休的认知干预措施'（第9页）。因此，女巫们对麦克白说，女人所生的男人不能伤害他，在 Birnam Wood 开始移动之前，他不必害怕，但这两种说法都非常狡猾，就像现代广告商的承诺一样，“Daz washes更白'，这并没有说明它比（卷心菜？）洗得更白。这是一个有启发性的并置，它很好地说明了横向方法在实践中的潜在敏锐度。他也是对的，解构主义者无法做到这种“横向”探索（从麦克白到广告、法庭诉讼、信仰治疗等的轨迹）因为文本不稳定性是所有文本性普遍堕落状态的观点使得他们不可能在任何实际文本。最终，横向诗学希望读者“将所讨论的文学文本与与他们生活相关的问题联系起来”（第 10 页）)，这从来都不是解构主义的优先事项。横向并置本身可能需要更详细、更持久和更突出，并且可能会有效地遏制衍生出越来越复杂、相互交织的术语的趋势，但应该注意到横向诗学的出现，并关注未来的发展.

Transversalism has confidently marketed itself as the coming thing in early modern studies – it is big and brash in its tone and its juxtapositions. By contrast, Reynolds says, deconstructive readings ‘merely expose the instability of texts and semiotic systems in which they function’, which amounts, really, to the old charge that deconstruction lacks political commitment and instead takes a quasi-aesthetic, quasi-philosophical pleasure in exposing and contemplating textual instabilities, remaining, as it were, mesmerized by the textual shimmer of ‘différance’. The transversal pirates are susceptible to no such fixation, and go through and beyond the text, for instance showing how the methods of the witches in Macbeth are similar to those of ‘the circulation of seductive or misleading concepts outside of the play text’. He points to ‘contemporary advertising campaigns or [contemporary] religious institutions … [or] such currently hotly-debated cognitive interventions as “leading the witness” and “faith healing”’ (p. 9). Thus, the witches say to Macbeth that no man born of woman can harm him, and that he need fear nothing till Birnam Wood begins to move, but both statements turn out to be highly tricksy, just like the modern advertiser’s promise that ‘Daz washes whiter’, which does not say what it washes whiter than (cabbage?). This is an enlightening juxtaposition, and it gives a good idea of the potential sharpness of transversal methodology in practice. He is right, too, that deconstructionists could not make such ‘transversal’ explorations (the trajectory from Macbeth out to advertisements, court proceedings, faith healing, and so on) because the view that textual instability is the universal fallen state of all textuality makes it impossible for them to get a useful comparative purchase on any actual texts. Ultimately, transversal poetics wants readers to ‘relate the literary text in question to issues pertinent to their lives’ (p. 10), which has never been a priority for deconstruction. The transversal juxtapositions themselves perhaps need to be more detailed, sustained and prominent, and the tendency towards the spinning out of ever more elaborate, intertwining terminology might usefully be curbed, but the arrival of transversal poetics on the scene should be noted and future developments watched.

新唯美主义

New aestheticism

新唯美主义是文学批评和理论中的新兴运动，起源于 1990 年代关于美学地位的哲学辩论，并在千禧年左右开始成为一种独特的文学实践。它强调文学文本的“特殊性”和“特殊性”，寻求与其对话而不是掌握它，并将文本视为在自身内部和与读者之间进行的持续辩论的一部分，而不是将其视为代表一个固定的立场，或作为预先确定的社会保守观点的表达。新唯美主义的实践者包括伦敦伯克贝克学院英语名誉教授伊莎贝尔·阿姆斯特朗；John Joughin，目前就职于中央兰开夏大学；和目前在爱丁堡大学工作的 Simon Malpas。

New aestheticism is an emergent movement in literary criticism and theory which arose from philosophical debates about the status of aesthetics in the 1990s and started to become a distinct literary practice around the time of the millennium. It emphasises the ‘specificity’ and ‘particularity’ of the literary text, seeking dialogue with it rather than mastery over it, and seeing the text as part of an on-going debate, within itself and with its readers, rather than viewing it as representative of a fixed position, or as the pre-determined expression of socially conservative views. Among the practitioners of new aestheticism are Isobel Armstrong, Emeritus Professor of English at Birkbeck College, London; John Joughin, currently of University of Central Lancashire; and Simon Malpas, currently of Edinburgh University.

新唯美主义与文学理论的主要变体背道而驰，因为它们从 1970 年代开始崭露头角，因为几乎所有这些变体都越来越受到挑战，越来越否认文学的自主性。因此，马克思主义批评家将文学视为社会力量的表现，精神分析批评家将其视为心理驱动力和本能冲突的发声，而后结构主义批评家则将文学的每一个行为都视为语言本身不稳定性的表现。理论上的共识是，无论作家认为他们在做什么或在说什么，他们总是在做或说别的事情——事实上，文学永远不可能说话，只能说通过社会、心理或语言力量的各种组合，批评家/理论家总是比作家更了解这些力量是什么。于是，文学失去了它的自主性、它的陌生感、它的特殊性，并且总是受到批评家和理论家的制止和警告，即使它看起来表现得非常好——支持弱者，支持自决和平等，或者呼吁宽容和理解他人的主张。例如，简·奥斯丁可能认为她在她的小说中做了所有这些事情，但批判理论思想警察总是知道得更多。他们可以看出她实际上是在排斥法国大革命，纵容英国海军普遍存在的暴行，洗白贵族与奴隶制之间联系的知识，曼斯菲尔德公园！这种对作家本能的不信任是法国哲学家保罗·利科 (Paul Ricoeur, 1913–2005) 所称的“怀疑诠释学”（在弗洛伊德与哲学中）的一部分，他将其定义为“一种解释方法，它假设字面或表面——文本的层次意义是为了掩盖文本所服务的政治利益。解释的目的是剥去遮掩，揭穿那些利益。

New aestheticism runs contrary to the major varieties of literary theory, as they came to prominence from the 1970s onwards, for nearly all of these increasingly challenged and increasingly denied the autonomy of literature. Thus, the Marxist critic saw literature as the expression of social forces, the psychoanalytic critic saw it as the voicing of psychic drives and instinctual conflicts, and the post-structuralist saw every act of literature as a demonstration of the instabilities of language itself. The theoretical consensus was that whatever writers thought they were doing or saying, they were always doing or saying something else – in fact, literature couldn’t ever speak, it could only be spoken by various combinations of social, psychic, or linguistic forces, and the critic/theorist always knew better than the writer what these forces were. Literature, then, lost its autonomy, its strangeness, its specificity, and was always being stopped and cautioned by critics and theorists, even when it seemed to be behaving perfectly well – championing the underdog, standing up for self-determination and equality, or calling for tolerance and understanding of the claims of others. Jane Austen, for instance, might have thought she was doing all those things in her novels, but the critical-theoretical thought-police always knew better. They could see that she was really occluding the French Revolution, condoning the brutality prevalent in the British Navy, laundering knowledge of the links between the gentry and slavery, or recommending sexual repression – and all that in a single novel – Mansfield Park! This instinctive distrust of writers is part of what the French philosopher Paul Ricoeur (1913–2005) called the ‘hermeneutics of suspicion’ (in Freud and Philosophy), which he defined as ‘a method of interpretation which assumes that the literal or surface-level meaning of a text is an effort to conceal the political interests which are served by the text. The purpose of interpretation is to strip off the concealment, unmasking those interests’.

那时，理论家和批评家在大约四分之一个世纪里一直是文学的剥削者和揭露者，自 1980 年代初自由人文主义者失败以来，他们基本上没有受到挑战。每个文本的独特品质都被很好地忽视了，无论其具体品质如何，文学作品都会被认定犯有广泛的一般罪行，每种理论方法都专门研究这些罪行——女性主义批评家的性别歧视和男性中心主义，后殖民主义者的东方主义，解构主义者的标志中心主义，等等。经过几十年的无情冲击，文学最终必须重新确立自己的地位是不可避免的。文学文本的反驳（如果允许它说话）很简单，它会是这样的：所有的文学文本都是不同的，它们不应该被定型为都具有社会保守倾向。后殖民主义者非常正确地说，所有阿拉伯人或“亚洲人”或穆斯林都是不同的、特殊的和不应该表现在集体的负面刻板印象中，就像将它们混为一谈的有害“东方主义”思想一样。但是，这种对轻率同质化的抵制并没有体现在我们看待文学作品的方式上。文学理论应该支持除其自身专业文学领域以外的每个领域的差异、差异性、能动性和特殊性，并且应该将文学视为一个整体，将其视为一种社会倒退的知识形态，这是一种严重的反常。那么，自 2000 年以来出现的新唯美主义可以被视为文学在经历了 30 年的怀疑解释学审讯之后不可避免的反击中的一个因素。

Theorists and critics, then, for around a quarter of a century, had been the strippers-off and un-maskers of literature, and they had gone largely unchallenged since the defeat of the liberal humanists back in the early 1980s. The unique qualities of each text were pretty well disregarded, for whatever its specific qualities, a literary work would be found guilty of the broad generic crimes which each of the theoretical approaches specialized in investigating – sexism and phallocentricism in the case of the feminist critics, orientalism for the postcolonialists, logocentricism for the deconstructionists, and so on. After a few decades of this relentless onslaught, it was inevitable that literature must eventually re-assert itself. The counterargument of the literary text (if it were allowed to speak) would be simple, and it would go something like this: all literary texts are different, and they shouldn’t be typecast as all sharing socially conservative tendencies. The postcolonialist quite rightly says that all Arabs or ‘Asiatics’ or Muslims are different and particular and shouldn’t be represented in collective negative stereotypes, as happens in the pernicious ‘orientalist’ thinking that lumps them all together. But this resistance to thoughtless homogenization is not carried through to the way we regard works of literature. It is a gross anomaly that literary theory should champion difference, alterity, agency, and particularity in every sphere except its own professional sphere of literature, and should view literature as a whole, as a socially regressive intellectual formation. New aestheticism, then, emerging since 2000, can be seen as one element in the inevitable fight-back of literature after its thirty-year interrogation by the hermeneutics of suspicion.

但是，作为新唯美主义的一个关键因素，重新确立文学文本的力量，是否仅仅是回到很久以前被理论取代的旧的“细读”？我不这么认为，因为它的基本原理可以追溯到 IA Richards 1929 年的实践批评和 William Empson 1930 年的七种类型的歧义（文本细读的创始文本），而是康德和黑格尔的哲学，它重新-在德里达和其他人重读后重读。70 年代和 80 年代的理论家们似乎总是把他们自己的“重读”想象成永久的和决定性的，而实际上它们只是一个正在进行的循环中的瞬间，所以他们的重读就像任何一次一样开放除了被自己重新阅读之外。换句话说，新唯美主义并不寻求扭转1929 年的实践批评成为批评实践的逆转（凯瑟琳贝尔西 1980 年颇具影响力的书的书名），但正在进行一系列干预，试图改变理论本身的轨迹。此外，“新”唯美主义代表了 19 世纪后期“审美运动”所表达的对审美的兴趣和态度的复兴，正如诗人阿尔杰农·查尔斯·斯温伯恩 (Algernon Charles Swinburne, 1837–1909) 的作品所见、诗人和画家但丁·加布里埃尔·罗塞蒂（Dante Gabriel Rossetti，1828-1882 年）、爱尔兰作家奥斯卡·王尔德（Oscar Wilde，1854-1900 年）和散文家兼评论家沃尔特·佩特（Walter Pater，1839-1894 年），他们的态度通常用“为艺术而艺术”的口号来概括'，它宣称艺术和文学的自主性，以及它不受道德正确性或社会效用考虑的自由。形式——非常有趣，而且在我看来，这是对历史主义和对文学文本的解释学怀疑传统的一种受欢迎的反应。*

But is this re-assertion of power of the literary text, which is a key element in new aestheticism, simply a return to the old ‘close reading’ which theory long ago displaced? I don’t think so, for it goes back for its rationale, not to I. A. Richards’s Practical Criticism of 1929 and William Empson’s Seven Types of Ambiguity of 1930 (the founding texts of close reading), but to the philosophy of Kant and Hegel, which it re-re-reads after they had been re-read by Derrida and others. The theorists of the 1970s and 80s always seemed to imagine their own ‘re-readings’ to be permanent and decisive, whereas they are in fact merely moments in an on-going cycle, so that their re-readings are just as open as any other to being themselves re-read. In other words, new aestheticism is not seeking to reverse the reversal whereby Practical Criticism of 1929 became Critical Practice (the title of Catherine Belsey’s influential book of 1980), but is making a series of interventions which seek to alter the very trajectory of theory itself. In addition, the ‘new’ aestheticism represents a revival of the interests and attitudes towards the aesthetic which were expressed in the late nineteenth century by the ‘aesthetic movement’, as seen in the work of the poet Algernon Charles Swinburne (1837–1909), the poet and painter Dante Gabriel Rossetti (1828–1882), the Irish writer Oscar Wilde (1854–1900), and the essayist and critic Walter Pater (1839–1894), attitudes often summed up in the slogan ‘Art for Art’s sake’, which asserted the autonomy of art and literature, and its freedom from considerations of moral correctness or social utility. The desire to re-instate the literary text at the centre of literary studies – but in a newly ‘totalised’ form – is of great interest, and, as I see it, a welcome reaction against both historicism and the tradition of the hermeneutical suspicion of the literary text.*

那么，新唯美主义可以从不同的角度来考虑——一种方式是将其视为对 19 世纪后期唯美主义兴趣的复兴；另一种认为是重新开启了源于康德和黑格尔哲学的美学争论；第三是将它（通过读者与文本之间正在进行的“对话”的概念）视为一种新的伦理批评；最后，第四是将其视为一种“新形式主义”，强调文本的形式特征以及这些特征对读者的影响。新唯美主义常常以一种恼怒的不耐烦感来面对占主导地位的批评和理论共识，断言文学研究中一些长期被排斥和辱骂的方面的重要性。仿佛突然厌倦了一直处于不利地位，它突然提出了一个无法提出的问题——“审美出了什么问题？” “康德怎么了？” “有多近？” 所有这些问题都是 Isobel Armstrong 书中的部分或章节标题，接下来将对此进行讨论。

New aestheticism, then, can be considered in various ways – one way is to see it as a revival of interest in the aestheticism of the late nineteenth century; another regards it as re-opening debates about aesthetics which stem from the philosophy of Kant and Hegel; a third is to see it (through the notion of the on-going ‘dialogue’ between the reader and the text) as a new kind of ethical criticism; and a fourth, finally, is to see it as a ‘new formalism’ which foregrounds the formal features of the text and the effects of those features on readers. New aestheticism often confronts the dominant critical and theoretical consensus with a sense of exasperated impatience, asserting the importance of some long-excluded and reviled aspect of literary study. As if suddently fed up with being constantly on the back foot, it snaps out the un-askable question – ‘What’s wrong with the aesthetic?’ ‘What’s wrong with Kant?’ ‘How close is close?’ All these questions are section or chapter headings from Isobel Armstrong’s book, which is discussed next.

实践中的新唯美主义

New aestheticism in practice

标志着新唯美主义开端的著作是伊泽贝尔·阿姆斯特朗的《激进美学》（牛津出版社，2000 年）。导言讨论了所有最近的文学理论流派对美学概念的拒绝，阿姆斯特朗写道，“发展另一种诗学意味着通过重建其理论基础和改变论证的术语来挑战反美学的政治” （第 2 页）。她说，这意味着恢复“基础哲学家康德和黑格尔”（第 1 页），最可行的美学概念源自他们。阿姆斯特朗将特里·伊格尔顿 (Terry Eagleton) 的著作《审美的意识形态》 (1990) 确定为对“反审美政治”的具有广泛影响力的陈述，以及她自己的著作激进的美学，十年后出现，可以看作是对它的直接挑战。她也将伊格尔顿的书视为怀疑诠释学的一个高峰——我们可以将新唯美主义描述为从对怀疑的诠释学的怀疑开始的文学研究方法。阿姆斯特朗的第一章强烈反对伊格尔顿。对他来说，例如，十四行诗的所有文本特定效果“总是已经”被考虑在内。这将包括以下内容：押韵模式；八位位组和六位组之间思想的“转变”；将长长的思绪压缩成几个图像和一个十四行的框架；使用将两种不同的含义巧妙地融合到一个矛盾的表述中的单词和短语；“沉重”话题的方式（爱情，死亡，宗教，等等）因语言的灵巧而“轻松”；以及十四行诗形式本身特有的“戏剧性”，这需要作家自己进入概念或隐喻的死胡同，然后在最后几行中用巧妙的短语逃脱。所有这些都给读者带来审美和智力上的愉悦，同时也是十四行诗形式的燃料和引擎。但“多疑”的理论家将它们视为“纯粹”的手段，其主要作用是意识形态——对他们来说，十四行诗中展示的语言技巧是与阶级相关的和精英主义的；这是一种多余的奢侈品，用复杂的花丝图案装饰思想。产生这些效果所需的技能和技巧只能由那些有足够特权的人获得，他们有大量的空闲时间投入到学习中，因此每次展示这些技能时，阶级界限得到加强。此外，当明显的矛盾或对立在十四行诗中“上演”，然后在结尾的几行中用语言上的花招调和，文学形式本身传达了一个隐含的信息或意识形态，即所有的冲突都是这样的。文学形式说，冲突只是表面上的，暗示社会差异总是可以通过坐下来商定一点进化修补来解决，而且没有任何矛盾是根本性的，需要对包含的系统进行彻底革命它。类似上述几点将构成对文学形式的“解释学怀疑”观点。这个问题的新唯美主义版本究竟会有何不同？

The book which marks the beginning of the new aestheticism is Isobel Armstrong’s The Radical Aesthetic (Oxford, 2000). The introduction discusses the rejection of notions of the aesthetic by all recent schools of literary theory, and Armstrong writes that ‘Evolving another poetics means challenging the politics of the anti-aesthetic by re-making its theoretical base and changing the terms of the argument’ (p. 2). This, she says, means re-instating the ‘foundational philosophers Kant and Hegel’ (p. 1), from whom the most viable notions of the aesthetic derive. Armstrong identifies Terry Eagleton’s book The Ideology of the Aesthetic (1990) as a widely influential statement of the ‘politics of the anti-aesthetic’, and her own book The Radical Aesthetic, appearing ten years later, can be seen as a direct challenge to it. She sees Eagleton’s book, too, as a kind of highpoint of the hermeneutics of suspicion – we might characterise the new aestheticism as the approach to literature which begins with suspicion of the hermeneutics of suspicion. Armstrong’s first chapter argues closely against Eagleton. For him, all the text-specific effects of a sonnet, for instance, would ‘always already’ have been accounted for. This would include such things as: the rhyme pattern; the ‘turning’ of the thought between the octet and the sestet; the compressing of a long sweep of thought into a couple of images and a fourteen-line frame; the use of words and phrases which finesse two different senses into one paradoxical formulation; the way ‘heavy’ topics (love, death, religion, and so on) are ‘lightened’ by verbal dexterity; and the characteristic ‘drama’ of the sonnet form itself, which requires writers to work themselves into a conceptual or metaphorical cul-de-sac, and then escape with a deft phrase in the final lines. All these things give aesthetic and intellectual pleasure to the reader, and are both the fuel and the engine of the sonnet form. But ‘suspicious’ theorists see them as ‘mere’ devices whose primary effect is ideological – for them, the verbal skill on display in the sonnet is class-linked and elitist; it is a redundant luxury, decorating thought in intricate, filigree patterns. The skills and techniques required to produce these effects can only be acquired by those privileged enough to have vast amounts of free time to devote to their acquisition, so that each time these skills are displayed, there is a reinforcement of class boundaries. Further, when apparent contradictions or opposites are ‘staged’ in the sonnet and then reconciled with a verbal sleight of hand in the concluding lines, the literary form itself conveys the implicit message or ideology that all conflicts are like this. Conflicts, says the literary form, are apparent only, implying that social differences can always be solved by sitting down together and agreeing on a little evolutionary tinkering, and that no contradiction is ever so fundamental as to require the complete revolution of the system that contains it. Something like the above points would constitute a ‘hermeneutically suspicious’ view of literary form. How exactly would a new aestheticist version of the matter be different?

Isobel Armstrong在激进美学的第三章末尾对新实践进行了出色的演示，标题为“文本骚扰：文本细读的意识形态，或接近程度如何？” 这一章是关于华兹华斯的“丁登修道院”，这首诗长期以来一直是批评和理论的战场，如果有的话，也是“斗争的场所”。她对标题中的问题（“多近才算近？”）的回答是“不够近”：传统的细读实际上通过对“掌握”的性/文本幻想保持了读者与诗歌之间的距离，因为评论家（通常是男性）对文本进行通常的剖析色情——“揭露”它的物理原理，“揭开”它的烟火技术，“品味”它的语言的物理味道——所有这些短语都来自一个不幸的引文，放在她章节的开头，来自评论家和理论家 Stanley Fish，谁在描述他在文本分析过程中的感受。阿姆斯特朗说，这种“掌握”的方法是对文本“影响”的逃避，这意味着它对读者产生的情感影响，是历代男性评论家非常害怕和不断驱除的东西——例如，IA Richards 谴责诸如“股票反应”和“先前的教义依附”之类的东西——这听起来确实很混乱；Wimsatt 和 Beardsley 谴责了“情感谬误”，而 William Emspon 写了同一首诗作为一种工具，用于仔细区分和定义他在诗歌中的几种不同类型的语言歧义，对华兹华斯“某事”的应受谴责的模糊性感到非常激动在“一种更深刻地融合的感觉”这一行中。阿姆斯特朗的观点是，当我们描述感受和感觉时，一定程度的模糊是不可避免的，甚至可能是表达任何事情的唯一方式。

Isobel Armstrong gives an excellent demonstration of the newer practice towards the end of the third chapter of The Radical Aesthetic,which is entitled ‘Textual Harassment: The Ideology of Close Reading, or How Close is Close?’ The chapter is about Wordsworth’s ‘Tintern Abbey’, a poem which has long been a critical and theoretical battleground, a ‘site of struggle’ if ever there was one. Her answer to the question in her title (‘How close is close?’) is ‘not close enough’: conventional close reading has actually maintained a distance between the reader and the poem by entertaining sexual/textual fantasies of ‘mastery’, as the (usually male) critic performs the usual dissective erotics on the text – ‘laying bare’ its physics, ‘uncovering’ its pyrotechnics, ‘savouring’ the physical taste of its language – all these phrases come from an unfortunate quotation, placed at the start of her chapter, from critic and theorist Stanley Fish, who is describing how he feels in the act of textual analysis. This ‘mastery’ approach, says Armstrong, is an evasion of the ‘affect’ of the text, by which is meant the emotional effect it has on the reader, something much feared and constantly exorcised by male critics down the ages - I. A. Richards, for instance, condemns such things as ‘stock responses’ and ‘prior doctrinal adhesions’ – which sound very messy indeed; Wimsatt and Beardsley condemned the ‘affective fallacy’, and William Emspon, writing about this same poem as a vehicle for carefully separating and defining his several different varieties of verbal ambiguity in poetry, gets very worked up about the reprehensible vagueness of Wordsworth’s ‘something’ in the line ‘a sense of something far more deeply interfused’. Armstrong’s point is that when we are describing feelings and sensations, a certain degree of vagueness is inescapable, and may even be the only way of saying anything at all.

阿姆斯特朗对这种困境的回应是“更接近而不是接近”——例如，她用了七页中的两页来讲述华兹华斯关于“的”这个词的诗歌。那么，新美学技术的一个方面就是“超特写”，即关注“形式词”，如“of”，而更传统的近文本审查往往集中在“内容词”上– 即名词和形容词、动词和副词。其次，阿姆斯特朗使用了“分叉”和“擦除”这两个概念，哲学家埃马纽埃尔·列维纳斯（1906-1995）从法国作家和民族志学家米歇尔·莱里斯（1901-1990）那里得到：在“分叉”中，选择一条道路而不是另一条道路使两者都发挥作用，而“擦除”意味着“重写”，就像重写本一样，擦除是通过重写来完成的，也就是说，通过在旧单词上写一个新单词。这两个词（“分叉”和“擦除”）都表明诗歌包含一个悬而未决的元素，它们在内部争论，并邀请我们加入争论；也许他们有话要问我们，而不是话要说我们——很可能，华兹华斯本人并不十分清楚“某物”是什么，而且由于他不是哲学家，他不必在下笔之前做出决定。正如阿姆斯特朗所展示的那样，“廷特恩修道院”中有大量的分叉和擦除：例如，华兹华斯写到“树篱行”，并立即自我更正并将其重写为“几乎没有树篱行，小行/嬉戏的树林狂野'。同样，从树上升起的烟雾给人“某种不确定的感觉，就像看起来/无家可归的树林中的流浪居民”。这里的“as might seem”可能会让读者不耐烦地问，“它看起来是不是这样？” 同样，矛盾的短语“流浪者”似乎使相关人员（他们可能在场或不在场，因为华兹华斯没有见过他们）同时显得既定居又游牧。同样相关的是，这首诗在更大范围内不断地重复和重写自己——诗中“现在”中描述的访问重复了五年前的一次，而华兹华斯这首诗正在写回声并挑战另一个（未提及）非常相似的类型之一，“午夜的霜冻”，由他的朋友竞争对手柯勒律治创作。因此，阿姆斯特朗说，这首诗在很多层面上都充满了焦虑，而它紧张的语气和结构也反映了这一点。读者不应该试图“掌握”它，逃避它令人焦虑的“影响”，而应该进入它所呈现的情感的混乱之中，更接近，换句话说，不仅仅是文字，而是感受的诗。同样，接近情感的元素是新审美实践的主要组成部分。因此，阿姆斯特朗的阅读提请注意文本的“千变万化”品质，强调它所呈现的与其说是批判性关注的静态目标，不如说是思想和情感的动态漩涡，两者几乎无法区分，而且可能无法描述作为一种独特的影响强度。可以说，这段文字呼吁它需要“与某人建立关系”（p. 102）。读者“可能会在文本的‘正文’中找到他们害怕、讨厌和渴望的东西”；一个“自恋”的时刻认同可能是一种基本的反应……因为它摆脱了我们文化中占主导地位的阅读的主/从模式。阿姆斯特朗说，我们需要面对“亲密的恐惧”，而不是退回到熟练解剖文本尸体的安全领域。事实上，正如“理论之后的理论”所知道的那样，文本不是尸体，也根本没有死，即使理论正在唤醒它，它仍然在起舞。

Armstrong’s response to the dilemma is to go ‘closer than close’ – for instance, she spends two of her seven pages on Wordsworth’s poem writing about the word ‘of’. One aspect of the new aesthetic technique, then, is the ‘ultra close-up’, the attention to a ‘form word’ like ‘of’, when more traditional versions of close-textual scrutiny tend to be centred on ‘content words’ – that is, nouns and adjectives, verbs and adverbs. Secondly, Armstrong uses the twin concepts of ‘bifurcation’ and ‘erasure’, taken, via the philosopher Emmanuel Levinas (1906–1995), from the French writer and ethnographer Michel Leiris (1901–1990): in ‘bifurcation’, the choice of one path rather than another brings both into play, while ‘erasure’ connotes ‘over-writing’, as in the palimpsest, where the erasing is done by re-writing, that is, by writing a new word over an old one. Both words (‘bifurcation’ and ‘erasure’) suggest that poems contain an unsettled element, that they are arguing within themselves, and inviting us to join in the argument; perhaps they have something to ask us, rather than something to tell us – quite possibly, Wordsworth himself doesn’t quite know what the ‘something’ is, and as he isn’t a philosopher, he doesn’t have to decide before he puts pen to paper. As Armstrong shows, there is plenty of both bifurcation and erasure in ‘Tintern Abbey’: Wordsworth writes of ‘hedge-rows’, for instance, and immediately self-corrects and re-writes it as ‘hardly hedge-rows, little lines/Of sportive woods run wild’. Likewise, the smoke seen rising above the trees gives ‘some uncertain notice, as might seem,/Of vagrant dwellers in the houseless woods’. Here ‘as might seem’ might make the reader ask impatiently, ‘Well does it seem that way or not?’ Similarly, the oxymoronic phrase ‘vagrant dwellers’ seems to make the people concerned (who may or may not be there, as Wordsworth has not seen them) appear both settled and nomadic at the same time. Also relevant is the fact that the poem constantly repeats and re-writes itself on a larger scale – the visit described in the ‘now’ of the poem repeats one of five years earlier, and the poem Wordsworth is engaged in writing echoes and challenges another (unmentioned) one of a very similar type, ‘Frost at Midnight’, written by his friend-rival Coleridge. So the poem, says Armstrong, is fraught with anxieties on many levels, and its nervousness of tone and structure reflects that. The reader shouldn’t be attempting to ‘master’ it, evading its anxious-making ‘affect’, but should enter the turmoil of the emotions it presents, getting closer, in other words, not just to the words, but to the feelings of the poem. That too, that element of closeness to the affect, is a major component of new aesthetic practice. So Armstrong’s reading draws attention to the ‘protean’ qualities of the text, emphasising that it presents, not so much a static target for critical attention, as a dynamic vortex of thoughts and emotions, the two hardly distinguishable from each other, and possibly describable as a unique intensity of affect. The text, so to speak, calls out its need to ‘enter into a relationship with someone’ (p. 102). Readers are ‘likely to find in the “body” of the text what they fear, hate and desire’; a ‘“narcissistic” moment of identification may be an essential response … because it escapes from the master/slave model of reading which is the dominant model in our culture’. We need to face the ‘terrors of closeness’, Armstrong says, rather than retreating to the safe territory of masterly dissection of the textual corpse. Indeed, as ‘theory after Theory’ knows, the text isn’t a corpse and isn’t dead at all, it was up and dancing even as Theory was conducting its wake.

该领域的另一本重要著作《新唯美主义》（曼彻斯特，2003 年，由约翰·乔因和西蒙·马尔帕斯编辑）的介绍与阿姆斯特朗的强调一致，即某些来自遥远时代的文学文本的幸存并不是因为它们具有“永恒”的意义。 ' 的重要性，但在于他们有能力“维持通常有争议或政治上反对的解释”（第 8 页）). 这表明，如果文学文本要在其产生的时代中存活下来，那么它们需要具备的关键品质是，它们应该为读者留出空间，让他们“加入”，与他们反驳，并“进入一个与他们的关系”，借用阿姆斯特朗使用的术语。相比之下，一部纯粹虔诚、宣传或“正确”的文学作品不允许有这样的空间：它告诉我们它认为我们应该思考什么，接受或放弃。所以幸存下来的工作的标志是它具有仍在进行中的质量，可以说，仍在从事解决问题的业务。这就是新美学家回应并寻求参与的工作的一个方面，即保持问题开放且从不完全得出结论的质量。新唯美主义者，换句话说，试图在工作中保持对话，而不是寻求封顶、关闭或结束，就像其他批评方法在将其作为主要目标时似乎所做的那样，以展示东方主义、男性中心主义或自动-解构性的工作。从某种意义上说，这种“保持对话”的方法确实“赋予”文学作品本身“特权”，但其他方法则赋予批评家或理论家特权，而新唯美主义者所设想的与作品无休止的对话似乎在本质上具有“民主”特征，因为这是一场永远无法圆满结束的对话。因此，人们普遍认为，批判性探究的目标永远不可能是得出决定性的科学真理（这与认知主义的前提大不相同，见下文）——它永远不可能最终确立，例如，康拉德的《黑暗之心》是或不是种族主义作家写的“种族主义”书（这篇文章是罗伯特·伊格斯通在《乔因和马尔帕斯》一书中的章节的主题），或者哈姆雷特是或不是“疯子”，因为在这两个文本中都没有那种“是”（无论是积极的还是消极的）。而是只能讨论《黑暗之心》中的种族主义问题和《哈姆雷特》中的疯癫问题。无论如何，很难想象解决这些问题中的任何一个可能带来的任何好处，而另一方面，当然可以想象讨论会带来很多好处他们。强调我们与文学文本的开放式读者对话是我所能解释的最接近于解释新唯美主义最终是什么的。

The introduction to another key book in this area, The New Aestheticism (Manchester, 2003, edited by John Joughin and Simon Malpas), agrees with Armstrong’s emphasis in suggesting that the survival of certain literary texts from remote eras is not due their having ‘timeless’ significance, but lies in their capacity to ‘sustain interpretations which are often either contestable or politically opposed’ (p. 8). This suggests that the crucial quality which literary texts need to possess if they are to outlive the era of their own production is that they should leave space for readers to ‘join in’, to talk back with and to them, and ‘enter into a relationship with them’, to pick up the term used by Armstrong. By contrast, a literary work which is merely pious, or propagandistic, or ‘right on’ doesn’t allow this space: it tells us what it thinks we ought to think, in a take it or leave it way. So the mark of the work that survives is that it has the quality of still being in progress, so to speak, of still being engaged in the business of working things out. That is the aspect of the work that the new aestheticist responds to and seeks engagement with, that quality of keeping questions open and never quite concluding. The new aestheticist, in other words, seeks to keep the conversation with the work going on, rather than looking for capping, or closure, or end-stopping, as other critical approaches seem to do when they take it as their main aim to show how orientalist, or phallocentric, or auto-deconstructive the work is. It is true in one sense that this ‘keeping talking’ approach ‘privileges’ the literary work itself, but then other approaches privilege the critic or theorist, and the unending dialogue with the work envisaged by the new aestheticist seems fundamentally ‘democratic’ in character, for it is a conversation which can never be finally rounded off and concluded. So there is an acceptance that the aim of the critical enquiry can never be to reach conclusive scientific truth (in this it is quite different from the premises of cognitivism, see later) – it can never be finally established, for instance, that Conrad’s Heart of Darkness is or is not a ‘racist’ book written by a racist author (this text is the subject of Robert Eaglestone’s chapter in Joughin and Malpas), or that Hamlet is or is not ‘mad’, for there isn’t that kind of ‘isness’ (of either the positive or negative sort) in either text. Rather, it is only possible to discuss the issue of racism in Heart of Darkness and the issue of madness in Hamlet. In any case, it would be extremely difficult to imagine any possible benefit arising from settling either of these questions, while on the other hand, it is certainly possible to imagine plenty of benefits coming from discussing them. That emphasis on our open-ended readerly dialogue with the literary text is as close as I can get to explaining what the new aestheticism is ultimately about.

读什么新唯美主义

What to read on new aestheticism

Isobel Armstrong，激进美学，牛津，2000 年。

Isobel Armstrong, The Radical Aesthetic, Oxford, 2000.

John Joughin 和 Simon Malpas 合着，新唯美主义，曼彻斯特，2003 年。

John Joughin and Simon Malpas, eds, The New Aestheticism, Manchester, 2003.

Nicholas Shrimpton，文学指南针中的“旧唯美主义与新唯美主义” ，卷。2，第 1 期，2005 年 1 月。

Nicholas Shrimpton, ‘The Old Aestheticism and the New’ in Literature Compass, Vol. 2, Issue 1, January 2005.

关于历史形式主义的注记

A note on historical formalism

这里应该顺便提一下最近的运动——或者更确切地说，一种趋势——它被称为历史形式主义，这种趋势似乎与现在主义和新唯美主义有一些相似之处。历史形式主义（至少名义上）出现在美国莎士比亚协会 2003 年会议上的一个研讨会上。斯蒂芬·科恩 (Stephen Cohen) 编辑的散文集《莎士比亚与历史形式主义》的导言中描述了这种趋势(Ashgate, 2007)，这在论文本身中得到了证明，其中有八篇，第一部分有四篇，副标题为“历史化形式”，第二部分有四篇，副标题为“重新形成历史” . 科恩在引言的开头令人印象深刻地说，过去一个世纪的英语研究制度史可以概括为一系列“学科两个强大的对立面，形式和历史之间的振荡”。新历史主义在 20 世纪 80 年代初期使我们果断地转向了后者，而历史形式主义暗示着它是对形式的纠正性反摆。但是，历史形式主义（顾名思义）并不是对新历史主义的果断拒绝，而恰恰是一种纠正。我们或许可以从字面上把它看作是一种课程修正，也就是说，作为对我们课程的一种修正，一种试图弥补新历史主义的一些盲点的错误，例如，尽管它经常有很多话要说关于“个别文本与历史情境之间的关系”，它对文学体裁的“历史根源和功能”“从未表现出太多兴趣”。那么，粗略地说，历史形式主义试图对文学研究进行一次修正，这将使我们远离仅仅询问文本的含义（当然是在其所有历史特殊性中），而稍微转向询问如何这意味着，这（在历史形式主义者看来）将要求我们更多地关注其流派的影响（它是十四行诗序列，或五幕戏剧喜剧，或其他）。引言中包含许多精心措辞的意图陈述，具有一定的修辞计算气息，似乎旨在为未来奠定标记，例如：

A passing mention should be made here of the recent movement – or, better, tendency – which is known as historical formalism, a tendency that seems to have some affinities with presentism and new aestheticism. Historical formalism emerged (in name, at least) at a seminar with that title at the 2003 meeting of the Shakespeare Association of America. The tendency is described in the introduction to Stephen Cohen’s edited collection of essays Shakespeare and Historical Formalism (Ashgate, 2007), and it is demonstrated in the essays themselves, of which there are eight, four in Part 1, which is sub-titled ‘Historizing Form’, and four in the Part 2, subtitled ‘Re-Forming History’. Cohen memorably says at the start of the introduction that the institutional history of English Studies, over the past century, can be summed up as a series of ‘oscillations between the discipline’s two mighty opposites, form and history’. new historicism, in the early 1980s, swung us decisively towards the latter, and historical formalism, it is implied, is a corrective counter-swing back towards form. However, historical formalism (as its very name implies) is not a decisive rejection of new historicism, but, precisely, a corrective. We might perhaps see it literally as a course correction, that is, as a correction to our courses, and one which seeks to compensate for some of the blind-spots of new historicism, such as the fact that while it often has much to say about ‘the relationship between individual text and historical situation’, it has ‘never shown much interest’ in ‘the historical roots and function’ of literary genres. Roughly speaking, then, historical formalism seeks to make a course correction for literary studies which will point us a little bit away from just asking what the text means (in all its historical specificity, of course) and a little bit towards asking how it means, which (in the view of the historical formalists) is going to require us to give more attention to the effects of its genre (its being a sonnet sequence, or a five-act dramatic comedy, or whatever). The introduction contains many carefully-phrased statements of intent, which have a certain air of rhetorical calculation, and seem designed to lay down markers for the future, like this one:

如果历史批评要在早期现代文学和文学理论中寻求肯定和启发，那不应基于他们所谓的拒绝文学与其他话语之间的差异，而应基于他们对文学形式及其意识形态功能的特殊性的敏感——一种有助于恢复我们自己的批判实践的敏感性。（第 13 页）
If historical criticism is to seek affirmation and inspiration in early modern literature and literary theory, it should be based not on their purported refusal of the differences between literature and other discourses, but on their sensitivity to the particularity of literary forms and their ideological functions – a sensitivity that can help to revive our own critical practice. (p. 13)

这是一个过于谨慎的陈述，不可能成为鼓舞人心的战斗口号，但请注意“特殊性”这个词的典型出现，（在千禧年头十年的文学研究中）经常表示对墙到墙的抵抗墙历史主义。另一方面，这里所断言的不是特定文学文本的主张（麦克白的那些坚韧不拔的词、短语、图像和句子阻碍了对该剧的任何简单消化），而是特定文学文本的主张文学形式，当然，这是一种完全不同的特殊性。因此，虽然历史形式主义对学科的掌舵人进行了一种受欢迎的纠正，但它似乎只是推迟或取代了历史主义，而不是对被认为适合文学研究的纯粹数量的历史主义进行任何认真的干预。换句话说，历史形式主义不是（至少从它的早期表现来看）这是对新历史主义的根本挑战，因为我认为现在主义和新唯美主义是这样。但时间会证明一切，而且随着我们进入理论“来世”的旅程继续进行，即使是一个小的路线修正的影响也可能比掌舵者预期的更彻底。

This is too carefully-hedged a statement to be an inspirational rallying cry, but note the characteristic occurrence of the word ‘particularity’, which (in the literary studies of the first decade of the millennium) so often denotes resistance to wall-to-wall historicism. On the other hand, it isn’t the claims of the specific literary text which are being asserted here (those gritty words, phrases, images, and sentences of Macbeth which inhibit any easy digestion of the play), but the claims of the specific literary form, which, surely, is a rather different kind of particularity. So while historical formalism applies a welcome corrective touch to the disciplinary helm, it seems merely to defer or displace the historicism, rather than making any serious inroads into the sheer amount of it thought to be appropriate for literary studies. In other words, historical formalism is not (judging from its early manifestations, at least) so fundamental a challenge to new historicism as I take presentism and new aestheticism to be. But time will tell, and it could be that as our journey into the ‘afterlife’ of theory continues, the effects of even a small course correction will prove more radical than perhaps those at the helm intended.

认知诗学

Cognitive poetics

认知诗学是一种结合语言学和心理学的文学阅读方法，旨在更好地理解基本的认知过程。它的一些重要实践者是： Reuven Stur，特拉维夫大学希伯来文学名誉教授；Peter Stockwell，目前就职于诺丁汉大学；Alan Richardson，目前就读于美国波士顿学院；Joseph Tabbi，目前在伊利诺伊大学芝加哥分校工作；Ellen Spolsky，目前在以色列巴伊兰大学工作。

Cognitive poetics is a method of reading literature which combines linguistics and psychology, with the aim of better understanding basic cognitive processes. Some of its important practitioners are: Reuven Stur, Professor Emeritus of Hebrew Literature at Tel Aviv University; Peter Stockwell, currently of Nottingham University; Alan Richardson, currently of Boston College, USA; Joseph Tabbi, currently of the University of Illinois at Chicago, and Ellen Spolsky, currently at Bar-Ilan University, Israel.

拉丁语动词cognoscere的意思是开始了解，英文术语“cognition”由此而来，意思是（《简明牛津英语词典》说)“通过思想、经验和感官获取知识的心理活动或过程”；形容词是“认知”，意思是“与认知有关”。“认知科学”研究思维的组织方式、思维本身的过程，以及作为内外世界界面的思维。这个领域的一场“革命”从 20 世纪 50 年代开始发生，与前一章中提到的跨学科潮流密切相关，人类学、心理学和语言学学科开始相互对话。这在一定程度上也是计算机技术发展的产物，它开始为心理处理机制提供可能的模型。另一个重要因素是美国语言学家诺姆乔姆斯基（Noam Chomsky，生于 1928 年）对与心理学家 BF Skinner（1904-90 年）相关的“行为主义”思维方法提出的挑战。乔姆斯基对斯金纳著作的著名评论Verbal Behavior (in Language, 35, No. 1, 1959, pp. 26–58) 挑战了语言习得可以根据对外部提示和刺激的累积反应来解释的观点。乔姆斯基持相反的观点，认为语言习得是一种创造性的内化过程，人类头脑是独一无二的。人们很自然地认为研究语言将有助于解释思维的运作方式，因为语言的使用似乎是人类认知过程中最复杂和最具特色的部分。例如，隐喻和转喻之类的基本语言比喻似乎与理解和理解的基本方法相对应，因为前者将两个或多个概念融合成一个新的整体，而后者则让事物的一部分代表事物的整体。但是，认知主义者说，如果我们谈论心理过程并将它们与隐喻和其他修辞手段联系起来，那么我们就进入了文学批评的领域，因此融合文学批评、心灵哲学的综合形式的批评的想法，甚至进化生物学和神经科学，开始变得不那么离奇了。

The Latin verb cognoscere means to get to know, and from it comes the English term ‘cognition’, which means (says the Concise OED) ‘the mental action or process of acquiring knowledge through thought, experience, and the senses’; the adjective is ‘cognitive’, meaning ‘relating to cognition’. The ‘cognitive sciences’ study the way the mind is organised, the processes of thought itself, and the mind as the interface between inner and outer worlds. A ‘revolution’ in this field took place from the 1950s onwards, closely connected to the cross-disciplinary currents looked at in the previous chapter, whereby the disciplines of anthropology, psychology, and linguistics began to talk to each other. It was also partly the product of the growth in computer technology, which began to offer possible models for the mechanisms of mental processing. Another significant factor was the challenge offered by the American linguist Noam Chomsky (born 1928) to the ‘Behaviourist’ approaches to mind associated with the psychologist B. F. Skinner (1904–90). Chomsky’s famous review of Skinner’s book Verbal Behavior (in Language, 35, No. 1, 1959, pp. 26–58) challenged the view that language acquisition can be accounted for in terms of cumulative responses to external cues and stimuli. Chomsky took the opposite view, seeing language acquisition as a creative, internalising process for which the human mind is uniquely equipped. It is natural to suppose that studying language will help to explain how the mind works, since language use seems the most intricate and characteristic of human cognition processes. For instance, basic language tropes like metaphor and metonymy seem to correspond to fundamental methods of apprehension and understanding, since the first fuses two or more concepts into a single new whole, while the latter lets part of something stand for the whole something. But, say the cognitivists, if we are talking about mental processes and relating them to metaphor and other rhetorical devices, then we have entered the territory of literary criticism, so the idea of a combined form of critique which blends literary criticism, philosophy of mind, and even evolutionary biology and neuroscience, begins to seem less bizarre.

在 1990 年代初期，以色列评论家 Reuven Tsur（走向认知诗学理论，第 2 版，苏塞克斯学术出版社，2008 年）和 Ellen Spolsky（自然界的差距：文学诠释和模块化思维，纽约州立大学出版社，1993 年）。当时，文学理论部分被后结构主义所主导，它认为语言不过是“不稳定性”和“相对性”，部分是历史主义，其底线是“一切都是社会和历史的”建'。任何“自然”的概念都受到极度怀疑——这个词本身就是禁忌，正如我们在第 13 章中看到的那样，这是生态批评不得不挑战的知识分子禁忌。在某种程度上，乔姆斯基的语言理论让“自然”重新发挥作用：正如乔姆斯基在斯金纳评论中所说，语言习得不能完全用“刺激、强化、剥夺等概念”来解释。也就是说，“社会”因素（如鼓励、奖励和认可、示范和指导）不能完全解释孩子语言习得的原因，学习语言的能力必须以某种方式“内建”或与生俱来。诚然，拉康认为无意识的结构类似于语言（见第 5 章)，他关于语言结构的想法不是很精确，因为它们不是基于任何系统的实证研究。事实上，忽视经验主义（我们指的是详细的实践调查，而不是概念性的理论化）是 80 年代占主导地位的理论范式的另一个重大弱点，现在它遇到了不可避免的挑战。

During the early 1990s the basis for this combination of fields was being laid, in the work of Israeli critics Reuven Tsur (Toward a Theory of Cognitive Poetics, 2nd edition, Sussex Academic Press, 2008) and Ellen Spolsky (Gaps in Nature: Literary Interpretation and the Modular Mind, SUNY Press, 1993). At that time, literary theory was dominated partly by post-structuralism, which brooked no counter to its view of language as nothing but ‘instabilities’ and ‘relativities’, and partly by the historicism whose bottom line is that ‘everything is socially and historically constructed’. Any notion of ‘nature’ was regarded with extreme suspicion – the very word was taboo, and as we saw in chapter 13, this was the intellectual taboo that ecocriticism had to challenge. In a way, Chomsky’s theories of language bring ‘nature’ back into play: language acquisition can’t be entirely accounted for ‘in terms of such notions as stimulus, reinforcement, deprivation’, as Chomsky says in the Skinner review. That is, ‘social’ factors (such as encouragement, rewards and approval, demonstrations and coaching) cannot entirely account for the child’s acquisition of language, and the capacity to learn language must in some way be ‘wired in’ or innate. And while Lacan had, it is true, argued that the unconscious is structured like a language (see Chapter 5), his ideas about how a language is structured were not very precise, since they were not based on any systematic empirical investigation. Indeed, the disregard of empiricism (by which we mean detailed practical investigation, rather than conceptual theorising) was another of the great weaknesses of the dominant theoretical paradigm of the 1980s which now met its inevitable challenge.

那么，这些因素在 1990 年代聚集在一起，导致了“认知诗学”的发展。它出现的一个关键时刻是 1998 年美国现代语言协会年会，当时 Francis Steen 和 Lisa Zunshine 设立了一个关于“文学和认知革命”的论坛，以及一个关于“文学的认知方法”的讨论组”是在同一事件开始的——见“文学与认知革命：导论”，《今日诗学》认知主义特刊的第一篇，它本身就是认知诗学领域建立的一个重要里程碑，并使这个主题的一个很好的起点。

These are the factors, then, which came together in the 1990s and resulted in the growth of ‘cognitive poetics’. A key moment in its emergence was the 1998 annual convention of the Modern Language Association in the USA when a forum was set up by Francis Steen and Lisa Zunshine on ‘Literature and the Cognitive Revolution’, and a discussion group on ‘Cognitive Approaches to Literature’ was started at the same event – see ‘Literature and the Cognitive Revolution: an Introduction’, the first item in the Poetics Today special issue on Cognitivism, which is itself an important landmark in the establishment of the field of cognitive poetics, and makes an excellent starting point on this topic.

艾伦·理查森 (Alan Richardson) 在那期特刊中的文章（“心痛和头部受伤：在劝说中读心术”）让我们了解了认知主义批评家的典型兴趣。这篇文章解读了安妮·艾略特 (Anne Eliot) 在《劝说》中与当时认知科学的关系：在简·奥斯汀时代，人们广泛接受的心灵观点是“社会建构主义”，也就是说，它认为心灵是由“情况和事件”。说明这种共识的一个经典文学例子是玛丽雪莱的弗兰肯斯坦，其中怪物的性格是由它所受到的对待形成的。一般来说，心灵被视为被动印记，一块白板根据英国“经验主义”哲学家约翰·洛克（1632-1704 年）和大卫·哈特利（1705-57 年）的观点，受环境印记的影响经验的印记，因此，关键因素是教育和社会条件。这些力量使我们成为现在的我们，或者更确切地说，我们成为了现在的我们。出自玛丽·沃斯通克拉夫特的《女人的冤屈》一直到西蒙娜·德·波伏娃 (Simone de Beauvoir) 及以后（“人不是天生的女人，而是成为女人”），这种观点对女权主义至关重要，对现代社会正义观念也很重要，在现代社会正义观念中，我们认为仅仅惩罚罪犯（监狱等）不会根除犯罪，因为我们还需要根除滋生犯罪行为模式的社会条件（“一个人不是天生的罪犯，一个人成为罪犯”，德波伏娃可能也说过） . 同样，我们可能会相信（以下古希腊哲学家赫拉克利特和德国浪漫主义诗人诺瓦利斯）认为“性格决定命运”，这听起来确实像是宿命论的一种形式，但如果我们也同意乔治·艾略特的“环境造就性格”，那就不那么像了。这些关于性格的陈述中的第一个基本上意味着“一切都是给定的”，而第二个意味着“一切都是被创造的”。第三种观点是“一切都是部分给予和部分制造”，这似乎最接近简·奥斯汀在《劝说》中提出的观点，体现在她的角色安妮·艾略特 (Anne Eliot) 身上，她 27 岁，按照小说中女主人公的标准，已经是中年人了，当时小说中女主人公的标准是 18 岁左右。“体现”这个词是特意选择的，因为在理查森的阅读中，这部小说坚持表明思想和性格是嵌入和体现在大脑和身体中的。理查森说，安妮·艾略特与“假女主人公”路易莎·默斯格罗夫搭档，后者“不合时宜地扑向弗雷德里克的怀抱”（第 145 页）) 导致她“一头栽倒在被称为莱姆里吉斯科布海堤的铺路石上”。对头部的打击改变了她一生的性格，就像安妮的性格因她生活中的失望而改变一样（安妮十四岁时母亲去世，五年后她与弗雷德里克的恋情破裂）。理查森 (148) 说，一个人的心碎了，另一个人的脑袋坏了。秋天改变了路易莎的“神经”和她的“命运”，奥斯丁说，因为心灵是“具体化的”，而不是像灵魂一样独立地自由漂浮。同样，她对安妮·艾略特反应的描述表明，她的身心、认知和肉体密切相关：理查森说，当安妮想到温特沃斯上尉“不受束缚、自由自在”时，“她的心不由自主地跳动起来，并带来了色彩”进入她的脸颊'（p. 151）。那么，在理查森的阅读中，小说的主题表现出对“认知主义”的关注。在《劝说》中，奥斯汀与她那个时代的思想对话，在某种程度上与玛丽·沃斯通克拉夫特、亨利·戈德温和玛丽·雪莱等同时代人所见的极端社会建构主义保持距离。小说的认知主义阅读将这些问题带到了前台，集中于小说如何以主体性建构的这些概念为中心。

Alan Richardson’s essay in that special issue (‘Of heartache and head injury: reading minds in Persuasion’) gives a sense of the characteristic interests of cognitivist critics. The essay reads the character of Anne Eliot in Persuasion in relation to the cognitive science of the day: the broadly accepted view of the mind in Jane Austen’s day was ‘socially constructivist’, which is to say that it saw the mind as formed by ‘circumstances and events’. A classic literary example illustrating this consensus would be Mary Shelley’s Frankenstein, where the monster’s character is formed by the treatment it receives. Generally the mind was seen as passively imprinted, a tabula rasa shaped by the imprint of circumstance, following the views of British ‘empiricist’ philosophers John Locke (1632–1704) and David Hartley (1705–57) both of whom saw the mind as a kind of ‘empty’ potentiality which is shaped by the impress of experience, so that the crucial factors are education and social conditioning. Those forces make us what we ‘are’, or rather what we become. From Mary Wollstonecraft’s The Wrongs of Woman through to Simone de Beauvoir and beyond (‘One is not born a woman, one becomes a woman’), this view has been essential to feminism, and it is essential too to modern notions of social justice, where we believe that merely punishing the criminal (with prison, etc.) will not eradicate crime, because we also need to eradicate the social conditions which breed criminal patterns of behaviour (‘One is not born a criminal, one becomes a criminal’, de Beauvoir might also have said). Likewise, we might believe (following the Ancient Greek philosopher Heraclitus and the German Romantic poet Novalis) that ‘Character is destiny’, which sounds like a form of fatalism indeed, though less so if we also agree with George Eliot that ‘Circumstances make character’. The first of these statements about character essentially means ‘Everything is given’, while the second means ‘Everything is made’. A third view would be ‘Everything is partly given and partly made’, and this seems closest to the view that Jane Austen puts forward in Persuasion, embodied in her character Anne Eliot, who, at twenty-seven, is pretty well middle-aged by the standards of heroines in novels, for whom the going rate was then about eighteen. The word ‘embodied’ is deliberately chosen, for the novel, in Richardson’s reading, insistently shows mind and character as embedded and embodied in brain and body. Anne Eliot, says Richardson, is paired with the ‘false heroine’ Louisa Musgrove, whose ‘mistimed leap towards Frederick’s arms’ (p. 145) results in her ‘headfirst fall onto the paving stones of the Seawall known as The Cobb at Lyme Regis’. The blow to the head alters her character for life, just as Anne’s character has been altered by her life’s disappointments (her mother’s death when Anne is fourteen, and the break-up of her romance with Frederick five years later). One suffers from a broken heart, the other from a broken head, says Richardson (148). The fall changes Louisa’s ‘nerves’ and her ‘fate’, says Austen, for mind is ‘embodied’, not free-floating in soul-like independence. Likewise, her descriptions of Anne Eliot’s reactions show mind and body, cognition and corporality, in close alignment: when Anne thinks of Captain Wentworth ‘unshackled and free’, Richardson says, it makes ‘her heart beat in spite of itself and brought the colour into her cheeks’ (p. 151). In Richardson’s reading, then, the subject matter of the novel shows a concern with ‘cognitivism’. In Persuasion, Austen is in dialogue with the thinking of her period about thinking, somewhat distancing herself from the extreme social constructivism seen in contemporaries such as Mary Wollstonecraft, Henry Godwin, and Mary Shelley. The cognitivist reading of the novel brings these issues to the fore, concentrating on how the novel centres on these notions of the construction of subjectivity.

实践中的认知诗学

Cognitive poetics in practice

然而，更常见的是，认知阅读关注的不是作品本身的内容，就像刚才讨论的例子中那样，而是关注读者对内容的解码中明显的认知过程。Cognitive Processes in Practice 中的两篇文章（Joanna Gavins 和 Gerard Steen，Routledge，2003 年）更接近于这种认知规范：Peter Stockwell 的“超现实人物”一章读了超现实主义诗歌，而 Craig Hamilton 的“A Cognitive Grammar of “Hospital Barge” by Wilfred欧文读了一篇欧文很少讨论的文章。斯托克韦尔将“图形”和“背景”之间的关键认知区别作为他的基础，我将使用他的术语和我自己的例子来说明认知主义论文中使用的那种程序。以下是一个短篇小说的开头句子：

More frequently, however, cognitive readings focus, not on the content as such of the work, as in the example just discussed, but on the cognitive processes which are made evident in the reader’s decoding of the content. Two essays from Cognitive Processes in Practice (Joanna Gavins and Gerard Steen, Routledge, 2003) are closer to this cognitive norm: Peter Stockwell’s chapter ‘Surreal Figures’ reads surreal poetry, while Craig Hamilton’s ‘A Cognitive Grammar of “Hospital Barge” by Wilfred Owen’ reads a seldom-discussed piece by Owen. Stockwell takes the key cognitive distinction between ‘figure’ and ‘ground’ as his basis, and I will use his terminology, but my own example, to give a sense of the kind of procedures used in cognitivist essays. Here are the opening sentences of a short story:

班轮开始远离码头。小船甲板上站着一个身穿紫色晚礼服的女人。她手里拿着一封皱巴巴的电报，邮戳是巴黎 14 点。15、30 1958 年 6 月 15 日，她的手臂搁在船舷上，双臂搁在船舷上，她的手指松开了——仿佛是下意识地——抓着皱巴巴的纸，纸飘落到海港的水中。
The liner began to move away from the quayside. On the boat-deck stood a woman in a purple evening dress. In her hand was a crumpled telegram bearing the postmark Paris, 14h. 15, 30 Juin 1958. Staring ahead, her arm resting on the ship’s rail, she let her fingers loosen – as if unconsciously – their grip on the crumpled paper, and it fluttered down into the waters of the harbour.

在文学文本中，一种常见的“吸引子”（即吸引注意力的方式）采取的形式是在（较大或静止的）（背面）背景下呈现（较小或移动的）人物，正如开头的一句话“班轮开始离开码头”。“地面”（脑海中的任何东西都不是船）遭受“忽视”（与“吸引力”相反），而班轮吸引了注意力。然后可以通过第二个图形/背景配对将原始“图形”“接地”（制作成背景，或“遮挡”）：“在船甲板上站着一个穿着紫色晚礼服的女人”：现在船（或，更确切地说，它的一个特定部分）是女人“形象”的“基础”，这个过程可以重复：“她手里拿着一封皱巴巴的电报，上面盖着邮戳巴黎，14 点 15 分，1958 年 6 月 30 日。在这句话中，还有三个快速连续的图形/背景“轮廓”：女人变成手的“图形”的“背景”，然后手变成电报“图形”的“地面”，最后电报本身变成了邮戳“数字”的“基础”。使用术语“轮廓”是因为它是图形相对于地面的“轮廓”——也就是说，图形和地面一起工作或相交——吸引注意力，或者通过它来吸引注意力。那么，在这里，我将使用技术术语（图形、地面、轮廓、吸引力/吸引子、忽视和遮挡），并通过一个简单的例子来说明它们是如何工作的。很明显我是专注于思想如何被文本的文字和图像“引导”，我完全没有评论审美问题——例如，这个开场效果如何？它是太快了，还是太鲜明了，还是太夸张了？也没有对文学史的问题发表评论——例如，诸如此类的问题：作者通常的开场白有多典型？作为技术和题材，它对当时的短篇小说有多熟悉？也没有对解释问题发表评论– 例如，诸如此类的问题：女人是谁？电报里有什么？这是一个关于失去和分离的故事吗？甚至正如这个简短的例子所暗示的那样，认知主义者往往对此类问题的兴趣不如对所涉及的认知过程机制的映射感兴趣。下一句是：

In a literary text, a common kind of ‘attractor’ (that is, a way of drawing the mind’s attention) takes the form of presenting a (smaller, or moving) figure against a (larger, or static) (back)ground, as in the opening sentence ‘The liner began to move away from the quayside’. The ‘ground’ (whatever in the mental picture isn’t the ship) suffers ‘neglect’ (the opposite of ‘attraction’), while the liner attracts attention. The original ‘figure’ can then be ‘grounded’ (made into background, or ‘occluded’) by a second figure/ground pairing: ‘On the boat-deck stood a woman in a purple evening dress’: now the ship (or, rather, a specific part of it) is the ‘ground’ for the ‘figure’ of the woman, and the process can be repeated: ‘In her hand was a crumpled telegram bearing the postmark Paris, 14h.15, 30 Juin 1958’. In this sentence there are three more figure/ground ‘profilings’ in rapid succession: the woman becomes ‘ground’ to the ‘figure’ of the hand, then the hand becomes ‘ground’ to the ‘figure’ of the telegram, and finally the telegram itself becomes ‘ground’ to the ‘figure’ of the postmark. The term ‘to profile’ is used because it is the ‘outline’ of the figure against the ground – that is, figure and ground working together or intersecting – to which, or by which, the attention is drawn. Here, then, I am taking the technical terms (figure, ground, profile, attraction/attractor, neglect, and occlusion), and illustrating how they work with a simple example. It will be clear that I am focusing on how the mind is ‘directed’ by the words and images of the text, and I haven’t commented at all on aesthetic matters – for example, how effective is this opening? Is it too fast, or too stark, or too melodramatic? Nor has there been comment on matters of literary history – for example, issues such as: how typical is this of the author’s usual opening ploy? How familiar is it, as technique and subject matter, of the short stories of its day? Nor has there been comment on matters of interpretation – for example, questions such as: who is the woman? What’s in the telegram? Is this a story about loss and separation? As even this brief example implies, cognitivists tend to be less interested in such questions than in the mapping of the mechanisms of the cognitive processes involved. The next sentence reads:

看着前方，她的手臂搁在船舷上，她的手指松开了——好像是无意识地——抓着皱巴巴的纸，它飘落到海港的水中。
Staring ahead, her arm resting on the ship’s rail, she let her fingers loosen – as if unconsciously – their grip on the crumpled paper, and it fluttered down into the waters of the harbour.

在这句话中，松开的手指是图形，其他一切都是地面。但还有另一个前景元素旨在吸引我们对特定细节的注意，因为正如斯托克韦尔所说，“吸引子可以由显示语言偏差的文本中的文体特征形成”（第 16 页），他的斜体）。松开手指的细节是由一系列快速传递的“分词”动词（以“ing”结尾的，如“凝视”和“休息”）引导的，焦点细节由有限的表示动词“她让”。但是这里我们有一个“中断结构​​”，它中断了预期的词序，从而将注意力吸引到副词短语“好像不自觉地”。发生这种情况是因为该短语的位置出乎意料，因为它打破了主语（“她的手指”）、动词（“松开”）、宾语（“他们的抓地力”）的通常英语词序。通常我们会期望状语短语“as if unconsciously”跟在它的动词后面，就像在像“He（主语）举起（动词）the dog（宾语）非常小心（状语短语）”这样的句子中。从预期位置移动，副词“as if unconsciously”是“陌生化”，失去了熟悉的外衣，突然显得非常突出。因此，传达的概念是该动作实际上可能根本不是无意识的，而是经过深思熟虑的，以便看起来不省人事。因此，“表演”和“看”的概念引入这样的想法，即有人正在观看，这个表演是针对谁的，可能是某个看不见的人，也许在远处（用双筒望远镜？）但她能感觉到，因为她非常确定某个人一定在那里。也许，还有另一个人要从港口取回报纸，为了看不见的观察者的利益，她假装不在场。很少有明确说明在文本中，但将注意力吸引到“好像”这个词会促使读者朝那个方向思考。然后，场景以这些方式开放发展，并通过语言的配置和我一直在追踪的感知巧妙地传达给读者，这会激发读者对语言提示做出反应的认知过程以及页面上的线索。

In this sentence, the loosening fingers are the figure and everything else is the ground. But there is also another foregrounded element which is designed to attract our attention to a particular detail, for as Stockwell says, ‘Attractors can be formed by stylistic features in the text that display linguistic deviance’ (p. 16, his italics). The detail of the loosening fingers is led up to by a series of ‘participial’ verbs (those ending in ‘ing’, like ‘staring’ and ‘resting’) which are passed over rapidly, and the focal detail is indicated by the finite verb ‘she let’. But here we have an ‘interrupting construction’ which interrupts the expected word order, and thereby draws attention to the adverbial phrase ‘as if unconsciously’. This happens because the phrase is unexpectedly positioned, for it breaks up the usual English word order of subject (‘her fingers’), verb (‘loosen’), object (‘their grip’). Normally we would expect the adverbial phrase ‘as if unconsciously’ to follow its verb, as in a sentence like ‘He (subject) lifted (verb) the dog (object) with great care (adverbial phrase)’. Moved from its expected position, the adverbial phrase ‘as if unconsciously’ is ‘defamiliarised’, losing its cloak of familiarity and suddenly seeming very prominent. So the notion is conveyed that the action may not actually be unconscious at all, but deliberated performed so as to look unconscious. Hence, the notions of ‘acting’ and ‘looking’ introduce the idea that somebody is watching, at whom this performance is directed, possibly someone unseen, maybe in the distance (with binoculars?) and yet sensed, as somebody whom she is pretty sure must be there. Perhaps, too, another person is to retrieve the paper from the harbour, someone of whose presence, for the benefit of the unseen watcher, she feigns unawareness. Little of this is explicitly stated in the text, but drawing attention to the words ‘as if’ nudges the reader’s thought processes in that direction. The scenario, then, is open to development in these ways, and this is subtly conveyed to the reader through the disposition of the language, and the perceptions I have been tracing, which instigate the cognitive processes of the reader in response to the verbal cues and clues which are on the page.

另一个值得评论的动词元素是短语“she let her fingers loosen”，它也包含一个特点，如果我们问这个短语在效果上与“her fingers loosened”有何不同，就可以看出这一点。我们可以通过将它与诸如“她强迫她的手指松开”之类的变体进行比较来开始回答这个问题，这个变体表明她不情愿地执行了这个动作，就好像在某种胁迫下，并且不希望被承担该行动后果的一方。因此，添加的“强迫”一词表明某种内在冲突：相比之下，“让”一词有什么影响？但这个问题很难准确回答。这可能意味着她屈服于一种冲动或必要性，但并不完全同意该行为——她同意了，但也许并没有完全满意自己这样做。这是推测性的，但很明显，这句话让我们第一次瞥见了角色内在动机或心理的复杂性，这开始将我们的注意力从外景转移到内景。

One further verbal element which is worth commenting on is the phrase ‘she let her fingers loosen’, which also contains a peculiarity, one which can be seen if we ask how that phrase differs in effect from ‘her fingers loosened’. We can begin to answer that question by comparing it with a variation such as ‘She forced her fingers to loosen’, a version which would indicate that she performed the action with reluctance, as if under duress of some kind, and not wishing to be a party to the consequences which will follow that action. So the added word ‘forced’ would indicate an inner conflict of some kind: what effect, by contrast, does the word ‘let’ have? But this question is hard to answer precisely. It may imply that she gives in to an urge or a necessity, without being entirely in assent with the action – she goes along with it, but without being entirely happy with herself for doing so, perhaps. This is speculative, but it does seem clear that the phrase gives the first glimpse of complexities of motive or psychology within the character, which begins to move our attention from the scene without to the scene within.

前面给出了认知方法的目标、风格和重点的印象，也许它的一些潜在缺点会很明显。例如，虽然展示在文本开头等关键部分起作用的认知过程很有趣，但如果主要目的只是展示或解释这些认知过程，则没有必要以这种方式贯穿整个故事认知过程。然而，如果读者的主要兴趣是故事本身，则需要进行更全面的分析，尽管对于大多数读者来说，这种分析很快就会开始显得乏味，当然，即使对于一个相当短的短篇小说也是如此。这些问题类似于文体学的问题，认知方法在程序上和智力上与文体学有很多共同之处。

The foregoing gives an impression of the aims, style, and emphasis of the cognitive approach, and perhaps some of its potential drawbacks will be apparent. For instance, while it is interesting to show cognitive processes at work on a key segment like the opening of a text, it is not necessary to go all the way through the story in this manner if the primary aim is merely to demonstrate or explicate those cognitive processes. If the reader’s main interest is the story itself, however, some more complete analysis will be needed, though this kind of analysis will soon begin to seem tedious, surely, to most readers, even for a fairly short short story. The problems are similar to those of stylistics, with which the cognitive approach shares a good deal, procedurally and intellectually.

此类问题的一种解决方案是寻找非常短的文本来进行操作，但缺点是显而易见的：克雷格汉密尔顿使用了威尔弗雷德欧文的十四行诗长诗“医院驳船”，但那首诗的文学价值对我来说似乎微不足道。另一种方法是寻找具有高度语言或程序怪癖特征的项目，例如埃琳娜·塞米诺 (Elena Semino) 的作品中的海明威 (Hemingway) 的“超短篇小说”(A Very Short Story)，或乔安娜·加文 (Joanna Gavin) 的章节中唐纳德·巴泰勒姆 (Donald Bartheleme) 的实验小说。在大多数情况下，读者在每篇文章中都学到了认知科学的某些方面（威尔弗雷德欧文文章中的认知语法，刚刚提到的两章中的可能世界理论和文本世界理论，以及凯瑟琳埃莫特关于情节的章节中的上下文框架理论流行小说中的曲折）。由于每篇文章的一半左右用于解释所讨论的理论，这将文学研究的中心大大转移到认知本身的研究上，并且需要有非常坚实和令人信服的基础才能做到这一点。认知主义者自己一直在说，认知主义诗学令人兴奋，但是，当然，这仍然是一个见仁见智的问题，正如汉斯·阿德勒 (Hans Adler) 和萨宾·格罗斯 (Sabine Gross) 在他们对特刊的回答文章中所说的那样Poetics Today关于认知诗学，“认知分析……对于非认知主义者来说常常显得乏味和说教”（第 19 页）。改变文学研究方向的既定理由是一种令人惊讶的道德主义——它使文学研究“少得多精英主义”（第 1 页），因为认知主义诗学“认为文学不仅仅是幸福的少数人的事” '（第 1 页）。此外，令人惊讶的是，认知主义者似乎赞同“​​功能主义者”对文学和艺术研究的挑战——“对经典文本进行另一种解释的实践”，他们说，“受到了挑战”纳税人”（第 2 页). 认知诗学为花纳税人的钱提供了“正当理由”，因为认知主义者表明文学“基于人类认知和经验的一些最基本和普遍的结构和过程”（第 2 页）。最终，他们的目标是“对整个问题进行心理解释”审美和艺术体验，或者，另一个热点问题，文学发明”。你可能想知道这种双重议程是否真的明智，你必须决定你最想花时间研究的是伟大的文学作品，还是人类思维的认知过程。“这是同一件事”，认知主义者会说，“你不能在没有另一个的情况下研究一个”。但在现实中，我们当然可以，而且（正如阿德勒和格罗斯所说）我们其他人在认知诗学上可以选择要么“采用它，要么[仅仅]注意它的实践者必须提供的东西”。不可避免地，大多数人会选择后者。但即使是后者也是必要的，“认知主义必须使自己与特定文本的分析相关，以吸引‘主流’文学研究”。理查森对说服力的讨论从认知的角度来看，在我看来肯定会为我们对该文本的理解增加一个新的维度，因此它通过了测试，但我并不完全相信更具技术认知主义的阅读总是告诉我很多我无法理解的文本已经通过更简单的路线到达。然而，认知主义者的巨大乐观主义有一些有趣的地方——他们似乎总是认为自己正处于一个伟大突破的门槛上，所以我对此保持开放的态度，就像对其他各种“理论之后的理论”一样.

One solution to such problems is to look for very short texts to operate on, but the disadvantages are obvious: Craig Hamilton uses Wilfred Owen’s sonnet-length poem ‘The Hospital Barge’, but the literary merit of that poem seems slight to me. Another is to find items which are marked by a high degree of linguistic or procedural eccentricity, such as Hemingway’s ‘A Very Short Story’ in Elena Semino’s piece, or the experimental fiction of Donald Bartheleme in the chapter by Joanna Gavin. In most cases, the reader learns in each essay something about some aspect of cognitive science (Cognitive Grammar in the Wilfred Owen essay, Possible Worlds Theory and Text Worlds Theory in the two chapters just mentioned, and Contextual Frame Theory in Catherine Emmott’s chapter on plot twists in popular fiction). Since about half of each essay is devoted to explicating the theory in question, this shifts the centre of literary study a long way towards the study of cognition itself, and there would need to be very solid and convincing grounds for doing that. The cognitivists themselves keep saying that cognitivist poetics is exciting, but that, of course, must remain a matter of opinion, and as Hans Adler and Sabine Gross say in their answering essay to the special issue of Poetics Today on cognitive poetics, ‘cognitive analyses … quite often seem unexciting and didactic to non-cognitivists’ (p. 19). The given grounds for shifting the orientation of literary study are of a surprisingly moralistic kind – that it makes the study of literature ‘much less elitist’ (p. 1), because cognitivist poetics ‘sees literature not just as a matter for the happy few’ (p. 1). Also, the cognitivists seem – surprisingly – to go along with the ‘functionalist’ challenge to the study of literature and the arts – ‘the practice of producing yet another interpretation of a text from the canon’, they say, ‘has been challenged by the taxpayer’ (p. 2). Cognitive poetics offers ‘justification’ for the spending of taxpayer’s money, because the cognitivists show that literature ‘is grounded in some of the most fundamental and general structures and processes of human cognition and experience’ (p. 2). Ultimately, they are aiming to give ‘a psychological account of the whole problem of aesthetic and artistic experience, or, another hot issue, literary invention’. You may wonder whether this double agenda is really sensible, and you do have to decide which you most want to spend your time studying, great literature, or the cognitive processes of the human mind. ‘It’s the same thing’, the cognitivists would say, ‘and you can’t study one without the other’. But in reality, we surely can, and (as Adler and Gross say) the rest of us have the option on cognitive poetics of either ‘adopting it or [merely] paying heed to what its practitioners have to offer’. Inevitably, most will choose the latter. But to see even the second as necessary, ‘cognitivism will have to make itself relevant for the analysis of specific texts to appeal to “mainstream” literary studies’. Richardson’s discussion of Persuasion from a cognitive angle certainly seems to me to add a new dimension to our understanding of that text, so it passes the test, but I am not entirely convinced that the more technically cognitivist readings always tell me a great deal about the text that I couldn’t have reached by a simpler route. However, there is something intriguing about the immense optimism of the cognitivists – they always seem to see themselves as being on the threshold of a great breakthrough, so I am keeping an open mind on this, as on other varieties of ‘theory after Theory’.

阅读认知诗学的内容

What to read on cognitive poetics

Adler、Hans 和 Gross、Sabine，“调整框架：对认知主义和文学的评论”，《今日诗学》第 1-26 页， 23.2，2002 年夏季（这是对上一项的回应）。

Adler, Hans, and Gross, Sabine, ‘Adjusting the Frame: Comments on Cognitivism and literature’, pp. 1–26 in Poetics Today, 23.2, summer 2002 (which is a response to the previous item).

Gavins、Joanna 和 Steen，Gerard 合着， 《实践中的认知诗学》， Routledge，2003 年。

Gavins, Joanna, and Steen, Gerard, eds, Cognitive Poetics in Practice, Routledge, 2003.

Richardson, Alan 和 Steen, Francis F., eds, Literature and the Cognitive Revolution，这是《今日诗学》杂志的特刊， 23.1，2002 年春季。

Richardson, Alan, and Steen, Francis F., eds, Literature and the Cognitive Revolution, which is a special issue of the journal Poetics Today, 23.1, spring 2002.

Stockwell, Peter,认知诗学：介绍， Routledge, 2002

Stockwell, Peter, Cognitive Poetics: An Introduction, Routledge, 2002

Tsur, Reuven，走向认知诗学理论，北荷兰，1992。

Tsur, Reuven, Toward a Theory of Cognitive Poetics, North-Holland, 1992.

附录

Appendices

附录 1 Edgar Allan Poe，“椭圆形肖像”

Appendix 1 Edgar Allan Poe, ‘The Oval Portrait’

我的贴身男仆为了不让我在极度受伤的情况下在露天过夜而冒险强行进入的这座城堡是那些混合了阴郁和宏伟的建筑之一，这些建筑长期以来一直让人们皱眉。亚平宁山脉，事实上不亚于拉德克利夫夫人的幻想。从表面上看，它是最近才被暂时遗弃的。我们住进了一间最小、布置最不豪华的公寓。它躺在建筑物的一个偏远的炮塔里。它的装饰很丰富，但又破烂又古色古香。它的墙壁上挂着挂毯，装饰着形形色色的纹章奖杯，还有数量异常多的非常活泼的现代画作，镶嵌在华丽的金色蔓藤花纹画框里。在这些画作中，这些画不仅在它们的主要表面上，而且在城堡的奇异建筑所必需的许多角落都依赖于墙壁——在这些画中，我刚开始的精神错乱可能引起了我的浓厚兴趣；所以我吩咐佩德罗关上房间厚重的百叶窗——因为已经是晚上了——点亮我床头的高大烛台的灯头——然后大大地拉开带流苏的黑天鹅绒窗帘它包围了床本身。我希望这一切都完成了，这样我就可以辞职了，即使不是睡觉，至少也可以交替地沉思这些图片，并文本细读在枕头上发现的一本小册子，这本小册子旨在批评和描述它们。但是在城堡奇异的建筑所需要的许多角落里——也许是我刚开始的精神错乱使我对这些画产生了浓厚的兴趣；所以我吩咐佩德罗关上房间厚重的百叶窗——因为已经是晚上了——点亮我床头的高大烛台的灯头——然后大大地拉开带流苏的黑天鹅绒窗帘它包围了床本身。我希望这一切都完成了，这样我就可以辞职了，即使不是睡觉，至少也可以交替地沉思这些图片，并文本细读在枕头上发现的一本小册子，这本小册子旨在批评和描述它们。但是在城堡奇异的建筑所需要的许多角落里——也许是我刚开始的精神错乱使我对这些画产生了浓厚的兴趣；所以我吩咐佩德罗关上房间厚重的百叶窗——因为已经是晚上了——点亮我床头的高大烛台的灯头——然后大大地拉开带流苏的黑天鹅绒窗帘它包围了床本身。我希望这一切都完成了，这样我就可以辞职了，即使不是睡觉，至少也可以交替地沉思这些图片，并文本细读在枕头上发现的一本小册子，这本小册子旨在批评和描述它们。所以我吩咐佩德罗关上房间厚重的百叶窗——因为已经是晚上了——点亮我床头的高大烛台的灯头——然后大大地拉开带流苏的黑天鹅绒窗帘它包围了床本身。我希望这一切都完成了，这样我就可以辞职了，即使不是睡觉，至少也可以交替地沉思这些图片，并文本细读在枕头上发现的一本小册子，这本小册子旨在批评和描述它们。所以我吩咐佩德罗关上房间厚重的百叶窗——因为已经是晚上了——点亮我床头的高大烛台的灯头——然后大大地拉开带流苏的黑天鹅绒窗帘它包围了床本身。我希望这一切都完成了，这样我就可以辞职了，即使不是睡觉，至少也可以交替地沉思这些图片，并文本细读在枕头上发现的一本小册子，这本小册子旨在批评和描述它们。

The chateau into which my valet had ventured to make forcible entrance, rather than permit me, in my desperately wounded condition, to pass a night in the open air, was one of those piles of commingled gloom and grandeur which have so long frowned among the Apennines, not less in fact than in the fancy of Mrs Radcliffe. To all appearance it had been temporarily and very lately abandoned. We established ourselves in one of the smallest and least sumptuously furnished apartments. It lay in a remote turret of the building. Its decorations were rich, yet tattered and antique. Its walls were hung with tapestry and bedecked with manifold and multiform armorial trophies, together with an unusually great number of very spirited modern paintings in frames of rich golden arabesque. In these paintings, which depended from the walls not only in their main surfaces, but in very many nooks which the bizarre architecture of the chateau rendered necessary – in these paintings my incipient delerium, perhaps, had caused me to take deep interest; so that I bade Pedro to close the heavy shutters of the room – since it was already night – to light the tongues of a tall candelabrum which stood by the head of my bed – and to throw open far and wide the fringed curtains of black velvet which enveloped the bed itself. I wished all this done that I might resign myself, if not to sleep, at least alternately to the contemplation of these pictures, and the perusal of a small volume which had been found upon the pillow, and which purported to criticise and describe them.

很久——我读了很长时间——我虔诚地、虔诚地凝视着。时间飞快而光荣地过去了，深沉的午夜来临了。烛台的位置让我不高兴，我艰难地伸出手，而不是打扰我熟睡的贴身男仆，我把它放好，让它的光线更充分地照射在书上。

Long – long I read – and devoutly, devotedly I gazed. Rapidly and gloriously the hours flew by, and the deep midnight came. The position of the candelabrum displeased me, and outreaching my hand with difficulty, rather than disturb my slumbering valet, I placed it so as to throw its rays more fully upon the book.

但这一行动产生了完全出乎意料的效果。无数蜡烛（因为有很多）的光线现在落在房间的一个壁龛里，这个壁龛迄今为止被其中一根床柱深深地遮住了。因此，我在明亮的光线下看到了一幅以前完全没有注意到的画面。那是一个刚成年的年轻女孩的画像。我匆匆看了一眼画，然后闭上了眼睛。为什么我这样做一开始甚至连我自己的感觉都不明显。但是当我的眼皮一直这样合上的时候，我在脑海里想了想我为什么要这样合上它们。这是一种冲动的动作，目的是为了争取时间思考——以确保我的视力没有欺骗我——以平静和抑制我的幻想，以获得更清醒、更确定的凝视。片刻之后，我再次凝视着这幅画。

But the action produced an effect altogether unanticipated. The rays of the numerous candles (for there were many) now fell within a niche of the room which had hitherto been thrown into deep shade by one of the bed-posts. I thus saw in vivid light a picture all unnoticed before. It was the portrait of a young girl just ripening into womanhood. I glanced at the painting hurriedly, and then closed my eyes. Why I did this was not at first apparent even to my own perception. But while my lids remained thus shut, I ran over in my mind my reason for so shutting them. It was an impulsive movement to gain time for thought – to make sure that my vision had not deceived me – to calm and subdue my fancy for a more sober and more certain gaze. In a very few moments I again looked fixedly at the painting.

我现在看到的是正确的，我不能也不会怀疑；因为那幅画布上的蜡烛的第一道闪光似乎驱散了偷走我感官的梦幻般的昏迷，并让我立刻清醒过来。

That I now saw aright I could not and would not doubt; for the first flashing of the candles upon that canvas had seemed to dissipate the dreamy stupor which was stealing over my senses, and to startle me at once into waking life.

我已经说过，那幅画像是一个年轻女孩的画像。这只是一个头部和肩膀，以技术上称为小插图的方式完成；很像苏利最喜欢的脑袋的风格。手臂、胸脯，甚至是光彩照人的发梢，都不知不觉地融进了构成整个背景的朦胧而深沉的阴影中。框架是椭圆形的，镀有丰富的镀金，并采用莫雷斯克风格装饰。作为一件艺术品，没有什么比这幅画本身更令人钦佩的了。但突然间如此强烈地打动了我，可能既不是作品的执行，也不是面容的不朽美丽。最重要的是，有没有可能是我的幻觉，从半梦半醒中惊醒，把这颗脑袋误认为是一个活人的脑袋。我立刻看出设计、渐晕和框架的特殊性一定立即打消了这样的想法——甚至一定阻止了它的短暂娱乐。认真地想着这些要点，我半坐半躺地呆了大概一个小时，带着我的视觉铆接在肖像上。最后，我对它的效果的真正秘密感到满意，然后倒回床上。我在绝对栩栩如生的表达中发现了这幅画的魅力，它起初让我吃惊，最终让我困惑、屈服和震惊。怀着深深的敬畏之情，我把烛台放回了原来的位置。如此一来，我深深激动的原因就被隐藏起来了，我急切地寻找讨论这些画作及其历史的那本书。转向指定椭圆形肖像的数字，我在那里读到后面模糊而古怪的文字：

The portrait, I have already said, was that of a young girl. It was a mere head and shoulders, done in what is technically termed a vignette manner; much in the style of the favorite heads of Sully. The arms, the bosom and even the ends of the radiant hair, melted imperceptibly into the vague yet deep shadow which formed the back-ground of the whole. The frame was oval, richly gilded and filagreed in Moresque. As a thing of art nothing could be more admirable than the painting itself. But it could have been neither the execution of the work, nor the immortal beauty of the countenance, which had so suddenly and so vehemently moved me. Least of all, could it have been that my fancy, shaken from its half slumber, had mistaken the head for that of a living person. I saw at once that the peculiarities of the design, of the vignetting, and of the frame, must have instantly dispelled such an idea – must have prevented even its momentary entertainment. Thinking earnestly upon these points, I remained, for an hour perhaps, half sitting, half reclining, with my vision riveted upon the portrait. At length, satisfied with the true secret of its effect, I fell back within the bed. I had found the spell of the picture in an absolute life-likeliness of expression, which at first startling, finally confounded, subdued and appalled me. With deep and reverent awe I replaced the candelabrum in its former position. The cause of my deep agitation being thus shut from view, I sought eagerly the volume which discussed the paintings and their histories. Turning to the number which designated the oval portrait, I there read the vague and quaint words which follow:
